description:
Like the name of the hike suggests, Lands End trail is at the very far end of San Francisco. I love to keep active and couldn't have asked for a better way to get out and catch up with friends while taking in the gorgeous scenery.

The network of trails takes you along the long abandoned Sutro Baths (once a public swimming pool), caves and a labyrinth. It's a fantastic way to celebrate a warm(ish) San Francisco day. And after a few hours hiking here, I didn't feel so guilty about all those cookies and other snacks that I ate at the farmer's market earlier in the morning.
author: Phillip Z.

description:
Cute little hike with a sweet view if there's good weather, parking is easy if you don't mind walking a bit to the labyrinth. Lots of photo ops in this one little area, there's a large parking lot but also street parking.

All the reviews on here are super helpful and informative about how to find it and where to take pictures, so feel free to read people's advice before you go! super helpful.

Tips for if you want a picture with the labyrinth - while you hike, there's an easy small climb/trail that gets you down to the labyrinth. While we were there, this group of girls yelled up to us to see if we could take a picture for them (you know that situation where you want a group pic but you don't want to hand a stranger your phone and then climb all the way down while they have the chance to run off with your phone and you can never catch up to them?)

We took the pics for them and then airdropped them, I think this is a great alternative option if you're trying to get a group pic but don't want to hand climb back up and down or risk a stranger running off with it LOL. I felt like I had to put this in my review.

Awesome views, cute little trails with multiple stops depending on how far you want to walk, many options (which I love). Enjoy!
author: Irena S.

description:
I recommend this trail. Easiest way to get here would be to drive by the ocean beach and find parking. Parking are on both the sides of the road. You can go to the cliff house and the sutro baths which is very unique here. Take the stairs down to go see the Sutro baths. 

If you keep walking and go the other direction then you will go on the trail. It's an easy trail with some stairs back and forth ~4miles long. The views are spectacular as you walk along the Pacific Ocean. They have some benches for resting and to enjoy the views.

Take your dog along as it's a dog friendly trail just make sure you take the leash along.
author: Darshana S.

description: Great little trail with wonderful views, beach access and fun for all. Took my daughter here for some daddy daughter time. Read up first so you know some history and you'll be able to talk about things with your children, friends, other family etc.  She enjoyed stacking rocks at the beach, and hiking different trails. Restrooms available beer the snack shop at the parking area.
author: Charles R.

description:
This is a great trail to hike as a resident or as a visitor! The trail itself is long and has multiple end points, depending on what you want to get out of it: view of the burned down bath house, museum/National Park Office/Cliff House, the beach, Labyrinth, etc. - the options are endless. The thing I like most about the trail is that even on a foggy day, it's enjoyable!

I think this would be a great park to come to at sunset and I will be back to test my theory! Because the views of the bridge and the highest point over the water are right off the street, it would be easy to get around at night after the sun has gone down.

Be warned though, the trail is sandy and you will get sand everywhere if you go far enough. 

Parking is free and plentiful along the roads near the entrance of the park.
author: Bri T.

description: Good hike, I parked at the uss memorial parking lot....way smaller then I thought....labyrinth was also small, but great scenery and great picture opportunities!
author: Henry N.

description:
I've been here hundreds of times, so I'm surprised that I haven't written a review for this place yet!

Land's End is a gem. Whether you like to hike, take pictures for the 'gram, or simply enjoy the view with a cup of coffee-there's something for every one. Personally, I come here for long walks & to enjoy the scenery. 
I feel safe enough here to come on my own, which I do often. There's a large parking lot, but if spaces run out, street parking is also available. Make sure you hide all your valuables and lock your doors, cause you never know. They also have restrooms-large, clean, but close at around 5. 
There are many photo opportunities here-Sutro Baths, Golden Gate Bridge, Mile Rock Beach, the Cliff House, Giant Camera, the Labyrinth...I could go on and on.  Often times I see couples having their engagement photos being taken around this area. 

I recommend sticking around for sunset-the views are breath taking! Pack some snacks, drinks, and a blanket, and you're set! Also, wear comfortable shoes that you don't mind dirtying, and pack a jacket just in case!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Fantastic Trail with amazing views. There are some many options so it does not matter your hiking level. Pack a lunch and go explore. Move at your pace and enjoy the views .
author: Manny G.

description:
Amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge! Nice trail to get your heartbeat up. It's an easy trail that will take you to the bridge or Cliff's house depending on where you start. My boyfriend and I started at the USS memorial and made our way to the cliff house and then back to the bridge lookout point. 

I could have spent way more time here but we had to the airport. The trails are large and we'll manicured. There is history along the way to learn about the original use of this area. If you don't stop, it use to be an electric trolley path but was destroyed after an earthquake. The cost to repair was too large so hiking trail it is.
author: Malisa R.

description: New favorite trail!! This has been on my bucket list for quite some time. Loved the variety of hikes to do here and the labyrinth is a great destination.
author: Jannette U.

description:
***My 600th Review***

I love traveling in search of the most beautiful hiking trails around. My travels have often taken me to many different parts of California, out of state, and hopefully it will soon take me out of the country. Although I love traveling for these sorts of things, I sometimes fail to realize what I have right here at home. Land's End Trail is one of those trails that OTHER people travel far and wide for. On any given day you will see hundreds of people walking along this path, many of whom are tourists from other states and countries. 

The Land's End Trail is one of the most beautiful hiking trails in the Bay Area. It begins at the Land's End lookout and can be taken via the coastal trail all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge. As you begin your journey, you'll pass by the historical Sutro Bath ruins. Here, you can admire the Sutro caves and what is left of the Sutro Baths. You'll be blown away by the sweeping views of the ocean and California Coastline. 

As you continue your journey, you will pass Eagle's Point which provides a stunning view of the beautiful ocean down below. There are several pocket beaches along this path, one of the most popular being Baker Beach. There are a few great memorials such as the USS SF and World War II Memorial that you can stop by and admire. You can walk through the Presidio and get up close and personal with the old military batteries. My favorite part is reaching the Golden Gate Bridge! When it isn't cloudy out, this trail provides some of the most immaculate views of this bridge! 

Every single turn on this trail is breathtaking! What I love most about Land's End is that it's suitable for just about anyone. It's a great hike for the entire family mixed with tons of California history. Perhaps this is why it never truly feels like a "hike" for me, but rather an enjoyable brisk walk through the beautiful city of San Francisco. There are a few inclines here and there, but for the most part it's flat and mixed with a combination  dirt and paved walkways. This is a great place to take pictures! You'll want to capture these views forever.

Unfortunately with the crowd comes traffic and the fight to find parking. This is probably the worst parking lot that I've ever had to park at. During peak hours, it could take over a half and hour just to get OUT of this parking lot, and that's even if you can find a spot! The lot fills up quickly so if you're not out there by 8, good luck! I would HIGHLY recommend that you take public transportation or even a ride sharing service. Trust me, it will save you so much headache!

If you've never discovered the beauty of Land's End Trail, the time to do it is now. It's an experience that you'll never forget.
author: Shayla B.

description:
Quick update to make things easier. The address listed starts you off by the Sutra baths. I took a picture for those who want to start at the entrance of Lands End. 

The address is a residential mail box located a couple of feet away. The views never get old.
author: Kathy V.

description: The trail of the best views on planet earth. I enjoy jogging and walking the Lands End Trail. Great vantage point for a picture of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Juan V.

description: Easy hike. Love it. Make sure you bring a sweater/hoodie. It does get pretty chilly. Wear comfortable shoes and bring water! We went on a Saturday. Took us about an hour round trip. It wasn't too crowded. Free parking and plenty of parking.
author: Rach S.

description: A leisurely hike with a gorgeous view of the Golden Gate bridge from multiple angles. The walk is not that strenous unless you go up and down the stairs at the end of the trail. Otherwise it is pretty flat and there are benches along the way for you to sit on. Also there are plenty of trees providing shade for you along the route. I love to take all my friends to Lands End whenever they visit SF.
author: Katherine N.

description: This is probably my new favorite spot! The view is stunning. Most of the path is sandy. I think that there are various spots to stop by in the trail (the beach, the sutra beach, the labyrinth, the lookout, etc.) so your hike can be different every time depending on your destination! If you hike far enough, you will go through a bunch of stairs, which can be a bit strenuous. Other than that, this place is amazing.
author: Yuan Z.

description:
Beautiful Trail
I thought my youngest (age 4) might get tired of the walk but he enjoyed it! Perfect family activity and the view is perfect
author: Marty N Giovana P.

description:
This trail is well proper for the week-end or folksy wayfarers. It hugs the coastline along a 3 miles stretch. There are no exposed switchbacks as the trail is rather leveled. A few stairs will accompany you along the hike. 
I won't commit to more tributes about the discernible features of the place as the innumerable photos would argue for me.
author: Pheng L.

description:
Really nice and simple trail. There are several different trails that you can take. To get to the rock maze, you go to the pebble beach trail and walk down ALL OF THOSE STAIRS. It can get pretty windy at the maze area, but the view, if it isn't foggy, is BEAUTIFUL! The Golden Gate Bridge is clear and you can see a lot of SF from that spot. If you climb the big rock above the maze, you get an even better view of the city. 

The pebble beach is strange as there are many rocks piled on top of each other. It's a nice place to relax after walking a bit. The stairs on the way back to the top can be pretty tiring, but it's definitely a doable hike. We saw many doggies along the way too! 

They have a parking lot here, but it fills up fast. We were lucky enough to find street parking right in front of the bathrooms. I like to take visitors to this place if they are looking for a hike. :)
author: Heather I.

description: I stumbled late here on a Saturday in search of my Meetup group. I ended up walking the area by myself and taking pictures with my Nikon CoolPix Digital Camera. At least I learned something new.
author: Julio B.

description:
Beautiful hike and great pictorial scenes. As they say a picture can say a thousand words. Well this place has a lot of scenes and more then a thousand words. 

An awesome trail and a great way to exercise and get some fresh air. The ocean view and breeze is refreshing and always a great walk
author: Andrew M.

description:
What can I say: when you have nearly a week off work and leeway to lick some wounds and hike sores... You GO!

My main concern with most of my SF ventures is driving and parking my boujee luxUV around the city. On most occasions I'm an early bird driver and arrive around 7AM. That means doable street parking and a fighting chance for a decent out-the-door wait at my new beloved Andytown Roasters.

Lands End is no different. Matter of fact, there's even ample parking during lunch time when all the tourists and field trip groups come on weekdays. To my surprise, the ride remained unscathed the four hours there despite the signs of frequent break-ins.

Now that's out, the featured trail spans a meager 1.7 miles from the visitors lot to Richy-McRichardson Richmond District. I can do that stretch (ahem) in my sleep and the final destination was always Baker Beach towards GGB. That took going through the Bel-Air of SF neighborhoods and some confusion walking past the same landscapers four times to get there.

It was overcast (duh) but a lot of pups and owners were out enjoying the breeze and each's company. You have your detours in Mission Rock Beach, the over-IG'd rock Labyrinth and the Sutro Baths. Those will all preoccupy your time on the usual one-hour hike.They're all worth seeing for the first time but best when the weather's playing nice.

I'll downplay it just as a Sight to See for Review 300. Probably more enjoyable when the sun's out and you're with a photo-opportunistic/genetic friend. I'll be back for the Baths and hidden tunnel next time.
author: Jason A.

description: What a fun trail! I wanted to come here to find Land's End Labyrinth, which is easy to find using google maps while on the trail. We visited on a sunny weekend day, and while it was busy, we were able to keep a good pace because the trail is so large and easy to navigate around groups of slower walkers. We found Land's End Labyrinth (head toward Mile Rock Beach), and discovered it to be very windy out there right next to the water. Great views of the bay, ocean, and Golden Gate Bridge. Trails and area seemed well maintained. Loved it.
author: Katie P.

description: Large private parking lot. Beautiful scenery throughout, cradling the water and views of the Golden Gate Bridge. The grounds are so beautiful many come to take wedding pictures. A bit strenguous with steep inclines and long stairs, but otherwise a good, pet-friendly hike.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Fairly easy trail but there are some incline steps especially if you decide to take the path to the beach about midway through the trail. It looks like dogs are allowed here since I saw plenty of people walking theirs while I was making my way through the trail. Be sure to bring a camera (phone or otherwise) since it's so picturesque with the water crashing against the cliff along the trail and plenty of places to take some nice pics of the Golden Gate Bridge. It's not too crowded but don't expect privacy unless you go onto one of the side trails. I think I even saw a tent pitched... Anyway if you're visiting SF or live here and took it for granted, stop whatever you're doing and go. Now.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
This is one of SF's quintessential hike in which you can infuse yourself into nature, observe stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge, and explore the nearby beach. It is a fairly easy hike that your grandma can do. The full loop is about 3.5 mile, but it's not necessary to do the whole thing. You can just hike to the famous labyrinth and back. The labyrinth is located next to Mile Rock Beach. There will be a sign pointing you towards the beach. Once you descend down the stairs, instead of veering left and continuing down towards the beach, you need to head straight, up the hill, to get to the labyrinth. Although the Land's End Trail is nice, I still prefer hanging out at Sutro Baths, which is located towards the beginning of this trail. Definitely head down there and explore the bath ruins and secret cave. 

The Land's end trail is a heavily trafficked trail, so expect to dodge people left and right at some point. No, it's not really that crazy, but expect a lot of people. Parking can be difficult if you come at peak time. There are multiple parking lots in the area and street parking as well. And it's all free! 

If the weather is not foggy, you will have a clear view of the Golden Gate Bridge. It can get foggy on the coast however, so check the forecast if you want an unobstructed view.
author: Julia K.

description: It is so beautiful, one of my favorite spots to walk I love this area, the walk helps to keep you warm but a sweater is good to have.
author: Nicole R.

description:
What a beautiful hike. This hike is easy. There is some stairs and some slight incline but overall not too hard. It is very dog friendly. When I went it was a warm day and there was a cold breeze so it was perfect. I have definitely heard that you should wear layers if you go in the colder months. I highly recommend going here!!

PARKING: If you park at visitor center it is free. We got there around 9:30 AM and there were still spots available. When we left around 11:30 or so the parking area was a mad house and cars were swarming the little parking lot.
author: Caitlin W.

description:
Amazing morning hike trail! We arrived around 8:30 and the parking lot was empty. There are several signs warning people about car break ins. So be careful with your stuff. 

Bathrooms are clean and well stocked with paper and seat covers. It's a bit cold, but must nicer than other national park bathrooms I've seen. 

The trails are just gorgeous. It's majestic how beautiful this piece of the coast is. 

Several runners on the trail. It's a great cross training trail. Lots of walkers of all ages.  No bikes allowed on most of the trail. 

Can't wait to come again!!!
author: Ceecee M.

description:
This was a beautiful scenic hike :) Make sure to wear closed toed shoes with traction especially if you're heading to the labyrinth where you might be going up and down the big rocks. 

My friends and I visited on a Sunday morning and it wasn't overly crowded but there were a lot of people on the trail. We started at the trail head near the Visitors' Center.

It's a pretty easy hike which may or may not involve stairs (if you're going down to the labyrinth, the beach near it, or if you take the trail all the way down to the other end by the residential area). It offers nice views of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge throughout which was great for taking photos.

My friends and I got a little lost on the way to the labyrinth, but if you see the signs that says "Mile Rock Beach" before you head downstairs, you'll know you're on the right track. After the stairs, you can either take the path going down to the beach, or head straight and then hang left to get to the cliff. Keep going and you'll reach the rocky cliff where you'll have a nice view of the bay and the labyrinth from above. Happy hiking! :)
author: Marianne E.

description:
Seriously. Who gets 5 stars on Yelp?!?

Lands end is such a cool trail to take AND the view is ridiculously breathtaking. From start to end, there were side trails to check out different things which kept it interesting. It was the perfect hike to do with my family because it wasnt too strenous on the joints and the kids had a blast!!! 

Everyone musr check out at least once!!!
author: Samantha T.

description: Beautiful nature spot. :) would recommend a bit hard for people with knee, hip, leg injuries there are a lot of stairs and uphill downhill paths.
author: Zoe M.

description: I really enjoyed this trail, it is by the ocean and you get a great view of the golden gate bridge from across the water. We walked to the labyrinth and it was nice to go up on the hill and overlook it from above. I would classify this trail as easy, there isn't too much incline or decline and the terrain isn't rocky or uneven. It was definitely a scenic "hike" with a lot of photo opportunities. When we went it was a bit overcast and foggy but we still enjoyed it and were able to see the bridge. There was a ton of parking when we went around 10-11 am on a weekday and it was nice that we didn't have to pay for it!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
One Of The Best!
After about 40 trips here I finally took this hike. The views of the bay and GG Bridge are breathtaking, mostly because we never see if from this angle. The dirt path is gorgeous with plenty of access points. THIS IS HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

FYI- for an all day hike, we took the bus to Geary and 26th, walked to Baker Beach (almost in the shadow of the bridge), and then through the Lands End Trail. We had a snack at the Cliff House (what a view) and walked through GG Park, shopped on Haight Street and walked downhill back towards Union Square. It's a solid 6+ hours and fantastic!
author: Scott H.

description:
Terrific trail for visitors, old and young.  

Most of main trail is wide enough for two way traffic, flat, gravelly and where it narrows, rocky.  Not recommended for wheeled travelers.  GMonkey see several dogs off leash, but whaddaya gonna do?  All were friendly and well behaved.  Owners picked up droppings, so GMonkey thankful.

Take it to the beach, take it to the cliffs. See it all and be ready for some stairs. Bring water, hat, sandwich, let go of your troubles and spend quality time with true beauty and this trail. Share this beautiful place so it will outlive us all. Stay for the sunset. 

Count your blessings and savor them.
author: Ghost T.

description:
My favorite hiking destination in SF. I bet everyone says this...but its popular for a reason! There are a lot of different things to see when you'e hiking along this path. The Sutro Baths are at the very beginning of this hike right down by the parking lot. If you go down towards the hiking trail in the opposite direction, you can make it to the view points that are in the photos. There are multiple spots to stop and take in the view. Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes when you go because you can walk for a while! I wore rainbows once (mistake) and my feet were covered in dirt when I came back to the car.

Parking is a little tricky sometimes if you go during the peak hours but there is a huge lot that you can park at for free. There are random roads that you can also park at and walk if its backed up. They also have a welcome center that you can walk around if you're interested in the history of the place. Make sure you bring water and a camera! I highly recommend walking the whole trail and stopping at multiple points to take in the entire view!
author: Ori N.

description:
I really loved this trail. We started at the lookout. We checked out the gift shop there, which is really good. We didn't buy anything, but that's just cause we are really tight with money. Trust me. They have a lot of neat stuff there. 

We checked out the Sutro baths. Amazing what the place looked like when it was in its heyday. Now, only the ruins remain. Water still flows into it. I wonder where it comes from.  There is a rock a little offshore that sea lions live on. It also has a ton of bird poop on it. 

The trail itself was quite nice. Not difficult at all, and it contained a lot of viewing points. I also appreciated how much of it was covered. Still, we should have put on our sunscreen.  We got burned. You don't need hiking shoes, but walking shoes are recommended. The trail goes along the coastline. We continued through a really exclusive residential area of million dollar homes. I'm talking upwards of $16 million and ended up at Baker Beach. In total, we ended up covering over 6 miles. As a reward,  we got a really nice photo opportunity in front of the Golden Gate Bridge. Baker Beach had a few nude sunbathers, which was a little gross. 

I'd definitely recommend checking out this trail. Pack some water, and make a day out of it. Beautiful sights. Oh, yeah. We even saw some whales spouting!
author: Sean A.

description: I absolutely love this trail, and can not wait to come back on a day when it is not raining. It has some of the best views in the city and the trail is not very strenuous. Dogs can be walked along the trail as long as they are on their leash. Come early so you do not have to worry about finding a parking spot. Parking is FREE! There is a restroom at the start of the trail, and if you are adventurous you could explore China Beach when you reach the end before you turn around to head back.
author: Keisha K.

description:
You can read all the other reviews and see the pictures to get a sense of how wonderful and scenic this place is. It is a nice and easy hike too, down to Sutro Bath, the cave, Pebble Beach, and the coastal trail that leads to the golf course on the other side. You can also take your leashed dog here. 

I'm reviewing this place to let you know that it has gotten incredibly crowded lately. Yesterday I came here, found a spot, but the trail was incredibly crowded and it really took away from the beauty and serenity of this place. One the trail, people were so densely packed it felt like walking in a march or a parade. Just a huge throng of people that does not cease. You cannot go a few seconds (if at all) without bumping into another large group of people. 

I used to come here a lot in 2008-2010 when I lived closer. Now in 2017, on a clear, sunny weekend, it is impossible to find parking anywhere near here. I've had to leave twice already this year due to not being able to find a parking spot. 

Overall, a very beautiful place with a great easy hike, but too crowded.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
A beautiful hike. My new favorite hiking spot. I have a week knee due to a recent sporting issue.  Luckily it was strong enough to manage a slow hike day. Large wide dirt trail and about 2 or 3 miles of moderate hiking. The views? I recommend looking at the photos as they speak for themselves. Simply breathtaking. I was reminded why the bay is a privilege to live in.

As another reviewer noted, this trail passes through Mile Rock beach, China Beach and Baker Beach and connects to a trail that can be taken all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge.  The Sutro Bath views and Golden Gate views are the highlights for most viewers.

We were all more than impressed
 How can you not be? It's also dog friendly, kid friendly, food friendly, and parking friendly.  All in all an immensely good day.
author: Cameron M.

description: This is a very easy hike with stairs at different points of the trail. It was perfect weather when we went last Saturday. The ocean breeze and very low winds were perfect. Lots photo ops opportunities. We parked on the legion of honor side and hiked to lands end where sutro bath house is located. Climbed some rocks to take photos and there were big  hitting the rocks. There is a clean restroom at lands end with a cafe and other restaurants.
author: Koger V.

description:
In a word, amazing. This trail is easy to traverse (so easy that tons of people do it at night in the complete darkness!) *Note: there are no lights on this trail so if you don't have a light source (phone or flashlight) or don't like to hike in the dark make sure to get back to the lot by sundown! My sister in-law recommended this spot to me after our lunch together. While I grew up in CA and frequented San Francisco I didn't do much hiking back then. She immediately suggested coming down to this spot for great views of the water and the majestic Golden Gate Bridge. 

I loved every part of this trail and stopped frequently to take in the greatness of the views around me. There is a crisp breeze that sweeps up the hill from the water's edge reminding you that the formidable Pacific crashes not far below. In fact you can go down to the water midway down the trail by the labyrinth. In terms of accessibility, the main part of the trail is paved by the park and then hard packed dirt is pretty flat most of the rest of the way. 

You don't need hiking shoes to do this hike, and it is easy enough for kids to toddle along if you choose to bring them (oddly I didn't see many kids when I was on the trail). I highly recommend this spot, even if you just want a quick peek of the water and bridge. There are views as soon as you get out of the parking lot here so you needn't go far to be impressed.
author: Tammy Y.

description:
I've visited San Fran since I was a kid but never had made the trek to any of the local trails. 

Overall: Great, relatively easy scenic trail for visitors and locals alike! Did the full loop (3.5 miles). Would also recommend stopping by the legion of honor and sutro baths!

Parking: Fantastic- Large parking lot
author: Monica C.

description: Omg sooooo beautiful. The views are stunning. This is a definite must if you have a rental car.  The views are breath taking!!! Even though it was foggy the day we went, we were so glad we made a point to stop!!! It feels like you are some place other than San Francisco.
author: Anne W.

description:
If you are visiting the Outer Richmond, don't just drop by The Cliff House, Sutro Bath ruins, and Ocean Beach.  Put on your walking shoes or sneakers and the a hike on the Lands End trails.  You can start your trek at the westernmost end, just below the USS San Francisco Memorial.  Working its way alongside the cliffs, the views of the Marin Headlands, Golden Gate Bridge, and Fort Point are spectacular.  There is a nearby lookout for photo opportunities where you can snap photos of the coast and ships entering and leaving the bay.  Don't forget to walk the Labyrinth maze which has been reconstructed several times by fans.

Those of you who are adventurous can make your way down to the small rocky beach, Mile Rock Beach, but do stay on the trails.

Midway, you can stop by the Legion of Honor museum where they have a nice cafe, or view the sprawling Lincoln Golf course with its great coastal and city vistas.  At the eastern end, there is another lookout, near Sea Cliff neighborhood.
author: Jeff P.

description:
This is a mostly flat, moderate to easy trail with the most gorgeous views of the bay. I was more than impressed!

Kid friendly, gets real busy after 10am on weekends so go early if you want to experience more solitude.
author: Alicia P.

description: I suggest, arrive here early on the weekends !!! Like 8:30am ishhh for the following, parking, less crowd and spectacular background views in your photos as to where no one is photo bombing your photo or in the way lolx. I took my kids here and they enjoyed every minute of it. Got here like 8:30am and was on our way back to the car by 10:15am. Bring snacks and water too for the short walking trail.
author: Diann U.

description:
Simply put, Lands End Trail is an easy hike that gives you gorgeous views of the waters and Golden Gate Bridge.

We started off at the Cliff House, explored Sutro Baths, and made our way to the Golden Gate Bridge. At every opening/clearing, we stopped to take pictures with the bridge in the background.

Beautiful weather will get you gorgeous photos, so plan accordingly!
author: Christine S.

description: I bring all my out of town friends here, easy to walk and fun to visit and some of the best pictures in the city!
author: Aili P.

description:
Such a scenic hike. A bit far but well worth it.

Do try out Sutro bath as well when here.
Parking is scarce so Uber would be a best option.
author: Deebs M.

description:
The most beautiful trail I've had the privilege to walk on. I fell in love with Lands End at first sight, and I wouldn't have known this place had existed without a few recommendations from a couple of friends. 

The trail wraps around the coast with majestic views of the ocean and the Golden Gate Bridge. I also recommend taking the trail down to Sutro Baths and also the Labyrinth! 

I recommend wearing comfortable shoes because there's some climbing involved. It's a very smooth hike and nothing too difficult!
author: Cathy M.

description: This trail is fairly shaded and fairly easy. I love it because you literally have the view of the ocean and you can stop to whale watch, even sit at a bench for some lunch. There's the rock maze and sutro baths. There's Baker beach and ocean beach within the area. The weather for the hike is almost always perfect for me (never too hot, maybe a bit windy). I think it would make a great hiking date. You may get a little winded from all the stairs, but it's not too bad.
author: Linda S.

description: Everything natural is beautiful. I've been there a few times and it is still the same beauty, but the more I've gone, the more I find the crowd to increase and garbage. I hate seeing all the garbage on the trails. I was literally body to body when we last went which is okay I guess if you're just there to check the scenery and if you're on a tourist hype. Its a very easy/moderate hike, def a stroll in a park (unless you havent gone for a hike or walk in a while or encountered any activity with any stairs then you might have a little bit of a challenge because there are stairs) - Otherwise, its a beautiful place and a must see, but the trash left by people make it hard to enjoy as much.
author: Tuitama'i F.

description: This place is beautiful. Wonderful place to take a walk and take pictures. Love it! One of my favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Susana M.

description: Get in early. Free parking! Beautiful trails. Head back south a half mile and run on the beach!! A little bit of everything!
author: Aaron T.

description: What a lovely set of trails.  I'm not sure the one we walked is really Land's End- but it was definitely part of it.  We took a trail from the Legion of Honor over the cliffs and through some lovely green space- and ended up at Land's End and the Sutro Baths.  It was a great way to get to the Cliff House from the Legion and stretch our legs.  It's only a mile- and you'll see so much along the way!  We saw the Guadalcanal memorial, and the Golden Gate- there's a great spot for pictures!  We overlooked the Sutro baths.  We saw a lot of adorable dogs.  This seems to be a very popular dog walk with lots of happy dogs.  Enjoy it.  It's one of the most beautiful walks I've ever done.
author: Alex M.

description:
Wonderful hike and views however - please be careful and do not leave ANYTHING in your car if you are parking on the street by the golf course (beginning of the Coastal Trail, ends at Sutro Baths). Obviously SF is known for car windows getting smashed, but you would think at a park in the daylight this wouldn't be too common. Unfortunately it happened to me and a handful of other families. 

TLDR: People smash car windows/rob your belongings for anything, especially in this area (Sea Cliff/golf course by the trail entrance).
author: Kelsey V.

description:
Beautiful trails, nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Free parking, nice trails to walk around.

I heard about nick name mans end but I didn't see anything as it was during day time.

Walk to the Legion of Honor museum while there. Just so lovely place to spend afternoon
author: Yuko H.

description:
Man, I love the bay and Lands End Trail only gives me more reason to.

Beautiful doesn't even come close to describing it. It's a relatively easy trail to "hike." You'll mostly just be walking on flat terrain with slightly elevated areas and stairs. There are views of the ocean almost the entire way. If you want to take a break, stop by one of the many beaches along the way to just hang out and enjoy nature. Try your hand at rock balancing too! Of course, I had to check out the labyrinth which was way smaller than I thought it would be. But still, PERFECT views of the Golden Gate Bridge.

Get there early because as it gets more crowded, it'll get harder and harder to find parking. They do have a free parking lot and some street parking but it gets filled quickly. Sometimes you may need to park in the neighborhood. It does get windy here though, so bring a jacket! There's a couple restaurants nearby if you get hungry after too.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Breathtaking would be an understatement, when describing this trail for two reasons:

1) It's a very modest hike (physically), for someone somewhat fit. Your heart rate won't elevated too much throughout, hence not taking your breath away. (Ba dum, pssh.)

2) The views of the beautifully colored cliffs, the Golden Gate Bridge and surrounding South Bay, flowers, etc... are more than breathtaking. Whatever that adjective is, they are all that.

I, fortunately, following a post-dim sum feast, stumbled onto El Camino Del Mar and saw one of the entry points for this trek. And wow, I'm not sure how I can ever visit SF without doing it again. Things to know:
*****
I. LOCATION & PARKING
Obviously, with any route, there are multiple points of entry. I didn't see many lots on the east or north points, but definitely a few exist near Point Lobos. 

About the trek itself, it stretches several miles (three or four?) around the southern bend of the South bay. So it's relatively short.

II. SIGHTS
If you start from the east of the trail, you'll have plenty of opportunities to snag a magnificent shot of the Golden Gate Bridge, in all of it's glory, and the amazingness surrounding it. They thoughtfully planned out locations where folks can snap Instagram-worthy pics, and you betcha I made a dent in my phone's battery.

Continuing west, find a few jagged cliffs and Jurassic Park-esque forestry where you'll have the opportunity to eitherhike down to a Miles Rock Beach or USS San Francisco Memorial. I guess you could do both, but who has time for that? lol. --I only recall one barely challenging climb, which had a staircase made of ladders, but it didn't take to long to ascend to the top. 

Eventually, you'll make your way to the Sutro Baths - a weird amalgamation of cement stones, caves, graffiti, a pond infested by seagulls. It's probably the least interesting stop on the route. Not pristine, either.

Make your way a little farther, and you'll find the ever-stretching Ocean Beach. 

III. LEVEL OF DIFFICULTY
Again, as I wrote, it's not very difficult at all, and it only requires a solid pair of shoes. I wore my Puma Suedes, a street style shoe without good grip, and made it through without any problems. I even carried my Macbook Pro, and other electronics, in my backpack. Ooh, and a to-go thing of dim sum, and barely broke a sweat. Really, it's so easy.

I would suggest bringing a bottle of water, though. 

IV. OTHER TIDBITS
-There are no bathrooms on this trail.
-Charge your phone, because you'll take a lot of pictures.
-It's a nice three or four mile trek.

V. OVERALL
I would absolutely recommend this hike to anyone that enjoys spectacular views, fresh air, and the feeling of being kick ass. And even if you are an experienced hiker, it's worth the glorious views alone. Do it.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
One of the many spots to check out along the California coast line! Be sure to walk down to the Sutro baths, and old ruin site of a bath house back in the early part of our century. Be sure to walk along the trail towards the Golden Gate Bridge for the best view, but hope for a clear day or all you'll see if fog- which is a beauty to see in its own right! 

Tips- get here early!!!! Parking at the visitor center goes incredibly fast. That said there is plenty of street parking if you're willing to walk...it's worth the walk!
author: Graham W.

description: Wow! This trail is awesome. Beautiful sights! Was so caught up with the beauty of the trail, I found myself at the Golden Gate Bridge. I will definitely be back!!!
author: April J.

description:
I love exploring San Francisco and this is definitely THE most amazing hiking trail I have been to in the city. It's just so beautiful! You'll see a lot of trees, you'll have an ocean view, and you may even find their hidden stone maze here. It's so amazing! I have been here for like 3 times. Will come back once in a while to embrace the nature. 

FYI, it's not a difficult hiking trail. It will definitely raise your heart beat, but not to the level that you feel you can't finsih it. Good for people in all ages. Dogs friendly as well!
author: Susanne S.

description: So worth it! Great hike that we took from Land's End to Baker Beach. You will never get the sand out of your shoes, and a couple of spots are tough to climb when sand has piled up, but it was something I am glad that I had the opportunity to do.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
Wow. This place is amazing. Easy short scenic hike. There are quite some stairs in the hike for a good walk/exercise, but nothing too crazy or extreme. The scenic views made this hike very enjoyable and easy. I definitely recommend this hike for beginners,or not even hike, but to stroll and relax. 

Halfway in the hike, you will see some stairs  going down to your left. Take them! When taking the stairs down, you'll notice a split. To the left (stairs), it'll take you all the way down to the mile rock beach. To the right (paved trail), it'll take you to the famous labyrinth. 

We started the hike at 7:30 am and finished at 10:30 am. When we arrived in the am, there were plenty of parking in the lot across from the visitor's center and it was starting to get full as we were leaving. 

There is a cool cave right at the starting point that we missed. Don't miss it! I can't wait to come back!
author: Jamie C.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? 

The vista points along the trail at Land's End offers some of the best views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Pacific Ocean, the Marin Headlands and Point Bonita. No matter what -- take a camera! If possible, take a GoPro too!

This place feels somewhat secluded. However, there are enough people around most of the time to dispel any fears as you hike, run or walk.

Things to see along the trail: 
- The Labyrinth 
- USS San Francisco Memorial 
- Holocaust Memorial
- Golden Gate Bridge
- Marin Headlands/Point Bonita (across the gate)
- Cliff House (nearby)
- Visitor's Center for Golden Gate National Park Conservancy (nearby)
- Ruins of the Sutro Baths (nearby)
- Cave near Sutro Baths (nearby)

Tips: 
- FREE PARKING: It can be difficult to find a spot. I find that the Visitor's Center will give you the best chance to find a spot. It's FREE...but can take some time lapping around the parking lot to find one.
- WET & MUDDY: During the winter, make sure that you bring shoes that you don't mind getting muddy. The winter is the rainy period for Northern California. This winter (2016-2017) has been especially drenched.
- COLD & WINDY: During the summer, spring, fall and winter: Check the weather before leaving. It is usually cold and windy year-round.  Mark Twain famously quipped, "The coldest winter I ever experienced was a summer in San Francisco."  This is especially true along the coastal trails at Land's End.
- MAP: If you park at the Visitor's Center, you can get a free map that includes the trails. 
- PETS: This is a pet-friendly trail -- and many people take their pets. If your pet is not accustomed to meeting other people or pets, you will need to be aware of this.
author: Chris M.

description:
If you're looking for a short hike with an simple view then this is your spot. I love coming to Lands End! 

Start off at Sutro Baths and work your way from there. About 5-10 minutes going into coastal trail, don't miss the "Mile Rock Beach" where you'll see the labyrinth. This is where all the rocks are placed in that maze that you see all over Instagram & Facebook!

The hike is super short. I would say less than 2 miles? My friends and I ended up ending up all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge which was about 12 miles round trip.

Another perfect spot for you SF tourists and locals to go to!
author: Danny L.

description:
I love walking through this trail catching up with a friend, running on the dirt path up the stairs, or gazing at the Golden Gate Bridge from afar.  It's a nice leisure stroll to get your mind off things and for a moment, you start to forget; you forget about the stress from work, you forget about the guilt from eating 3 donuts, you forget about that time when you embarrassed yourself from laughing so hard something came out of your nose, you forget about how you can let someone else's choices in life affect you, and at the moment when you're staring out into the ocean, you say to yourself, "hey, at least it was a booger and not a fart".

In the words of Bob Marley,

"In every life we have some trouble
When you worry you make it double
Don't worry, be happy"
author: Linda N.

description:
Easy to moderate 

hiked this about 3 weeks ago.Beautiful place to hike with amazing views of the golden gate Bridge. 

Even if you don't live in the city you should at least come and hike this once or twice, it's worth it.  

We parked in the new parking area close to the Cliff House.. Plenty of parking and plenty of people out enjoying this beautiful place so you won't feel alone of you're hiking solo. 

The hike itself is pretty easy to navigate through with great views all around.  There is incline at a few spots, stairs and down hill so make are you have good shoes on.  

Bring sandals in case you want to dip your toes in the ocean!
author: No H.

description:
Just when I thought I couldn't love the city by the bay any more.

The hike is so easy just about anyone can do it. Even my out of shape self did some huffing walking up those stairs but, just take your time to enjoy the outdoors was fantastic. 
Rain or shine, just be sure to wear shoes you don't mind getting muddy.

The view was stellar. On a beautiful day, we had unobstructed views of the Golden Gate. No fog. Just sun and sea. 

On the cliff, there's a man made rock labyrinth. It's neat and unexpected. 

We climbed a hill next to the labyrinth for a higher view and just talked and took the scene all on. 
I wish we had packed some food to have a small picnic up there.

Love being able to see the city by the bay, LITERALLY, right by the bay!!!
author: Laurie V.

description: Easy hike, great views. Not really a dirt hike, more like a nice walk on cement with great views
author: Dee P.

description:
Parking - Plenty by the welcome center on a Thursday afternoon at 2PM.

Trail - Start at Sutro Baths and work towards the Labyrinth. Dog-friendly. 

Difficulty - It can be as easy or hard as you want. Some trails were flat. We were silly enough to go all the way down and climb a hundred stairs back up two times.

Weather - 50F, gentle ocean breeze, but after walking up on an incline, my body felt like 102F.

Photos - Save the stops until you get to the Labyrinth. The view from this spot is the best. 

Time - After climbing back up to ground level from Land's End, the total time was 1 hour and 30 minutes. This included way too many stops for the same touristy pictures and mini breaks because I'm terrible at incline.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
Ran from inner sunset (~4.5miles) to Lands End, with a stop at Sutro Bath. 

Even though Karl the fog was chilling, and partly swallowed the golden gate bridge, the labyrinth was still in sight and worth the stop!

I was more inspired by the story of how the labyrinth came about. The local artist's original work was destroyed presumably by vandalism. But with the help of 50 volunteers, they were able to rebuild it in weeks. The landmark for me signified the power of community.
author: Linda K.

description: I have done this walk a few times, well worth doing if you are from out of town and want to sight the Golden Gate. You need to be lucky with the weather as there is usually fog plus bring a few layers in case of the changeable San Francisco weather. The trail is fairly easy with some undulations but should be suitable for nearly everyone if you aren't in hurry.
author: Matt B.

description: Some nice views and pretty easy trails. Be ready for stairs though. Lots of stairs everywhere but they are easier because they are very large steps, if that makes sense. I would recommend going on a day that there isn't fog so you can get the full experience but regardless I enjoyed the walk. Parking can get full but I was able to find a spot everytime, so far.
author: Shannan E.

description: Eay trail with awesome views. Start from Ocean Beach, end near Golden Bridge
author: Luna M.

description:
This is a beautiful trail leading from Lands End Lookout (near Ocean Beach/Sutra Baths) to Eagle's Point (near the Presidio). It's about .7 miles end to end, so the round trip is a respectable walk or run. You pass by some of the most beautiful scenery SF has to offer -- the Sutra Baths, the Lands End Labyrinth, several lookouts and memorials, rock beach, and of course the best best views of the Golden Gate Bridge. There's one uphill with stairs on the way to Eagle's Point, and a second set of stairs if you want to get down to the water. 

The trail itself is not difficult and is well maintained. It's either paved or well-trodden dirt path. Many people are out running, walking, on dates, and taking their pets out. It's a great way to see the city and how locals live. 

Highly recommended!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
A gorgeous 1.7 mile trail in western San Francisco. Driving here and parking was easy - they have a big lot with a visitors center and bathrooms. Once you get on the trail though, there are no more bathrooms, so make sure you are prepared. Also bring water! On a sunny day the walk can be dehydrating.

The trail itself is not too strenuous. There are gorgeous views of the bay and a distant view of the a Golden Gate Bridge (which is usually shrouded in fog). There are some steps but not too many. I would recommend taking the detour about half way through down to the beach, which is beautiful and has many rocks with waves crashing on them. There are a fair number of steps down though, so make sure to factor the climb back up in as well.
author: Amy C.

description: Very beautiful trail. Super easy, chill. I'd recommend bringing snacks. We brought 7 layer dip and chips, and literally everyone on the trail was jealous. It's totally not too hard of a trail, and snacks and the sunset makes it all the better.
author: Marcus-Alex G.

description:
This is such a beautiful trail. It is more of a stroll, not an intense hike - but do bring a good pair of walking shoes, a light jacket, maybe some snacks & lunch, and of course, a camera.

Dogs are allowed, so it would be fun to bring your four legged companion along! Every path you take the views are amazing. If you want to go straight to the stone formation/Labyrinth, keep walking towards the view of the Golden Gate Bridge. There will be some big stairs, but nothing too intense.

 I personally thought the rock formation was going to be bigger..but it was still cute! It's all about the angles in the pictures that make it look bigger of course ;) We also witnessed a proposal by the edge of the cliffs as well! So romantic!
author: Jaclyn M.

description:
Love this place!  First time here and it was the perfect day to come for a coastal stroll on Valentine's Day.

Try to come early, parking can be a nightmare later in the morning and afternoon.  Smh.  I got there around 1030am.  The view was just astonishing.  Sparkling blue pacific aligned with the sun rays and crashing waves.  

We came here specifically for the labyrinth artwork.  There's really no signs for this, so follow the coastal trail.  We did a few detour to see certain things, but didn't want to go all the way down and have to climb back up.  (Totally not leg day, hehe) 

Keep an eye out for some stairs to the left, those are the stairs to the labyrinth...otherwise you'll end up at baker's beach and the Golden Gate Bridge!  

Gotta go!  Amazing views.
author: Lisa V.

description:
A short walk loaded with all kinds of great views.

Park as early as 9am at Lands End Lookout Visitor Center.  (beat the crowds)
Buy a cup of coffee there if need to warm up.
Walk down to Sutro Baths ruins, continue to end of path to tunnel on right.  Enter tunnel to listen to the acoustics of crashing waves.
Go up the trail toward NorthEast, on top of the tunnel, look North to see the white structure where Mile Rock Lighthouse used to be.  It is now a helicopter landing pad.   
Continue up the stairs to Coastal Trail.  Stay along the coast when encounter splits on road.
After a yellow bench on right side and before an emergency call box on left side, turn left down the trail to Mile Rock Beach.
At the end of the first stairs, go straight instead of left.  Go to the end of the buff on left to see the labyrinth directly below.
Then go down to the beach to stack stones and/or climb boulders.
Go back to continue on the Coastal Trail, go up then down stairs, then turn right to single track trail up to Legion of Honor.
Return back to parking lot via El Camino del Mar Trail.
author: Connie W.

description:
Absolutely stunning view at Lands End trail. To get there from the Legions of Honors, you will cut through a golf course. 

It is a very easy trail, not really a hike, more like a stroll. There are stairs and gradual inclines, but are not too bad. Although nothing technical, I would suggest wearing shoes with good grip, as the trail does get muddy sometimes, especially if you are going down to the rocky beach area. 

Once you get down the stairs towards the Labyrinth, there will be a fork, if you keep going down you will go to the rocky beach area, where you can enjoy the scene of huge waves hitting the shore, but you can't see the GG bridge too well from this site. There are also many colorful rocks at this beach. At the Labyrinth, you get amazing view of the golden gate bridge. During peak hours, there are quite a lot of people at the Labyrinth, so you might need to wait in line to take pictures. And of course, come on a sunny and clear day so you can enjoy the best view possible!

This is a great spot for light hiking, or running. I would definitely come back again for the breathtaking view!
author: Karen C.

description:
Nice walking trails, particularly in the evenings.On a blustery day or when the trail is wet (frequently) the exposure might make some people uncomfortable. And not to forget, the name exactly fits the landscape
.
author: Frank M.

description: Pictures don't do justice for the views and experience of Lands End. It's a beautiful hike through the city with breathtaking views of the rocky cliffs, the bay and bridge. Take time to explore the Cliff house and the bath ruins. Such interesting history. This is a must do while in San Francisco.
author: Amy T.

description:
Like many Yelpers... Absolutely breathtaking and amazing views. Great sceneries for photo ops and be sure to bring a light jacket, it does get chilly. 
Happy Trailing
author: Miyah L.

description:
Lovely trail, a great way to burn off some calories and spend a couple of hours. 

=== Trail
Moderate trail, most part of the trail is accessible, some portions of the trail requires climbing up and down stairs. They are open from 8am to sunset, though it seems that because it is a city location and fairly litted, the docents mentioned they are not that hard on imposing the time restriction. Access to the park is free which is nice.

Started off by dropping by the new Lands End Visitor Centre, a very modern and nicely decorated visitor centre. The docents are super patient with the endless flow of traffic. Picked up some maps for other parks too.

We started walking from the visitor centre, down to the Sutro Bath and up the stairs to start on the Coastal trail. There are alternative options to get to the coastal trail if you would like to avoid the stairs. 

Had wanted to check out the Lands End Ladyrinth, unfortunately, we went the WRONG way and missed it completely. As we didn't feel like going up and down the 360+ steps, so we took a snapshot of it from above instead. There are no good signages to tell you how to get there! Best is to ask!

=== Parking
There are street parking available nearer to the Cliff House and a decent sized parking lot at the visitor centre. You may have to spin a couple of rounds before landing one but overall it shouldn't be that hard. Saw a couple of signages that highlight car thefts are common in that area, so reminder not to put anything valuable in your car or at least hide them.

Overall, love the walk, pretty sure we will come back another time. 
Oh yes, it does get a little chilly, so wear/bring layers!
author: Cindee T.

description: It was overcast the day we went, but not too hot or cold. Fairly easy hike, not too strenuous except for the long ass trail of STAIRS going to the Rock Beach! Other than that, the trail itself is pretty flat. It took us 2 visits to the Rock Beach because we were trying to find that infamous Labyrinth but we finally found it! The sutro baths were pretty cool too! You can definitely hit all the photo ops along the entire hike. Parking can be difficult, but everyone is usually in and out so you're bound to find a spot eventually, just be patient. Otherwise there's always the residential area.
author: Marissa C.

description: This place is absolutely breath taking, not too crowded on a Thursday afternoon and the weather was perfect! So many trails , the perfect place to come get some exercise and enjoy the view. I'm so glad we left this as our last thing to do in San Francisco, it was the perfect ending to our trip.
author: Jessica L.

description: On vacation in Northern California we decided to stop here while we waited to check into our hotel. The trail is very scenic with great vistas along the coast. Be prepared for some steps-both up and down. We visited on a weekday afternoon, about 2:00, and the parking lot was active. Upon returning to our car we discovered that it and the vehicle next to ours were broken into--windows smashed and valuables stolen. The park police officer who handled our report stated that this is a common occurrence. If you visit this trail, be sure you don't leave anything of value in your vehicle.
author: Sally D.

description:
A beautiful trail with nice views of the ocean and the Golden Gate Bridge. It's a really simple hike, but more of a walk in the park with some small hills, stairs, and off trail paths. The best part of it all is that it's right next to Sutro Baths, another popular tourist hotspot. Two birds with one stone am I right? I would compare its popularity to be the Mission Peak in Fremont of San Francisco. This place always attracts tons of tourists so walking along the path can get really busy and slightly congested. I would suggest starting your hike from the parking lot. The other end starts at the Legion of Honor Museum, which is more situated in the residential area of Outer Richmond. Also, be sure to see Land's End Labyrinth on your way down the stairs! It's an amazing piece of art highly cherished by the local community. 

TIP: (1) Come here on a foggy day if you want quality photos of Karl the fog engulfing all the Cypress trees. (2) Don't be afraid to be adventurous and wander off trail. (3) For families with a baby, don't bring a stroller. It just becomes unnecessarily difficult for you to carry and push the darn thing.
author: Kevin S.

description: Tip: park at the USS San Francisco Memorial, walk down the steps, turn right to go to the Mile Rock hike, walk down the stairs and when you hit the next fork in the road -- don't go down the stairs on the left, go straight to the right on the dirt path and you'll hit the lands end trail with the labyrinth!!
author: Amy N.

description: Let's just say... SF is our overall go to place if we are in the need to take our dog out, or in need for a hike! Hiking and Dogs mix when coming to San Francisco as it is the most dog friendly city in Northern California (that I know of). Lands End is my go to place from now if any of my family members or friends would like to go hiking and just enjoy the scenic views. We went here a weekend ago for the 2nd time, and it never seems to disappoint me! Will be going back this upcoming weekend to take a very good friend of ours to go hike and just hang out. Too bad we are coming from either San Jose or Tracy, but we def do not mind making the trip!
author: Patrick D.

description:
We are so lucky we live in the Bay! So many places to see like Lands End. I'm a Bay Area native and this was my first time coming here.

It is super touristy but a gorgeous and easy trail. 3 miles round trip. The hike showcases a beautiful view of the coast leading to lovely views of the Golden Gate Bridge.

We hiked from the Lands End Lookout all the way to China Beach which was almost 5 miles total round trip.
author: Earlene C.

description:
Gorgeous and beautiful! 

They have signs warning you to lock up your car as there have been several burglaries.  As always be mindful.  

There are a ton of tourists around.

Some tips:

1.  Wear sunscreen and a hat.  I saw so many people red like crabs on the way back...
2.  Wear comfy shoes.  There are alot of stairs and it's dusty. I saw a couple of girls wearing heels...lol..really?
3.  Bring a backpack with snacks and water.  You will need to drink.  And you can have your snack while gazing out into the beautiful ocean.
4.  When snapping pictures with your cell phone by the water, make sure you have a good grip on your phone.  A girl dropped her phone into the ocean by the sutro baths.  Hey, it could have been worst...she could have fallen in.
5.  Enjoy your beautiful surroundings and have fun!
author: Veronica A.

description:
I've been hiking this trail since little, it's literally my backyard when growing up.  Fondest memory was when my girlfriends and I (teenagers) got the news that Jon Bon Jovi was getting married, and it broke our hearts.  My girlfriend went a little crazy and wanted to jump into Ocean Beach.  I'm like you can drown your sorrows, but I'm not about to die over Bon Jovi lol.  I took a nice stroll with other friends who were sane, and we had a nice evening with bonfires.  To our amazement, we weren't the only ones heart-broken by the news.  

Thanks to this stunning Lands End trail, life goes on.  I remember that year being all bad, as Loma Prieta happened in October (my bday month) during World Series Battle of the Bay (aka Earthquake Series), and I was about to enjoy my turkey sandwich on Dutch Crunch from Fredy's Deli (now Kawika's Ocean Beach Deli) 'til everything shook.  I was just praying for no Tsunami please.  Once again, thanks to Lands End trail, Sutro Heights Park, old Sutro Bath ruins, and Ocean Beach, I survived and didn't fall apart.  The serenity, world-class views, beautiful cliffs, and rewarding hike always allows me to relax and put my worries aside.
author: Christine R.

description: I found this by searching for kid friendly activities in San Fran. My gps took us to an alternate parking location so we didn't get to check out the center. The spot we started at only had stairs to go down which made having our stroller comical. It was windy but a gorgeous morning and way to end our little getaway. There were a lot of dogs with about half of them unleashed which was irritating since a couple ran up on my two year old. Most of the people were friendly that we encountered, one lady yelled from the top of the stairs for me to hurry up (as I held my two year olds hand) so she could literally walk up and down the stairs. We'll definitely be back next time we're in town. Listening to the ocean and admiring the scenery far than made up for the couple of head scratching moments.
author: Sheri E.

description:
What a beautiful place to spend a few hours! The views along the trail to Eagle's Point were breathtaking. Every turn gave us a more spectacular angle of the magnificent Golden Gate Bridge. The "hike" was easy yet it took us forever since we kept stopping to take photos.

We met many friendly people and dogs along the trail. We took the trail roundtrip, however, you can exit it at Eagle's Point.
author: Yi Z.

description: A stunning walking trail. This is a true gem, with amazing views of the coast and Golden Gate Bridge. It can be crowded depending on the day and weather. Several different trails you can take, highly recommend!
author: Reis J.

description:
Beautiful hike! We took the coastal path. There's lots of stairs down but it's worth it for the beautiful beach at the bottom! Lots of rocks and sea glass. You can climb up the rocks (but be careful). 

There are other trails you can take but we wanted to see the beach at sunset. Also there is an AMAZING view of the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Olivia B.

description:
An amazing place with an awesome view of the Golden Gate Bridge. 
There are also a couple of beaches in walkable distance. 

I can not wait to head back!
author: Lovejit K.

description:
I've come here several times with my friends and bf. This is one of my favorite touristy hikes in the bay area because there are so many places to explore and look at. 

Parking here is plentiful during the weekday, I would not try and come on weekend because I have a feeling it would be packed. 

There's a cute little gift / coffee shop on top of the cliffs before the sutro baths and hike starts. 

I love the sutro baths the most !!! I think it is so cool how they left this piece of history in this area and it has become a beautiful place to take pictures and explore. 

The hike here provides great views of the golden gate bridge and leads to some magnificent houses on the other end of gg bridge.  I love this hike!! Bring water and plenty of layers it gets windy and cool.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Directions to labyrinth: The closest/easiest way to do this is to park at the Lands End Lookout/sutro baths parking lot (point lobos & 48th or point lobos & el camino del mar). Walk the coastal trail, 0.8 miles. There will be a sign that says Mile Rock Beach and points down towards a long staircase. Go all the way down the stairs. It will come to a fork, the left trail goes towards mile rock beach, go straight and you will see the labyrinth. People often miss the labyrinth because they look down and do not see it at first, don't just look down, WALK down and you will see it. 

This easy, lightweight hike is cool because of the close parking and it's accessibility to all (dog friendly!). It's also great because you can start at the beautiful Sutro baths and depending on how far you want to walk, you can see mile rock beach and the scenic labyrinth with backdrops of the golden gate bridge. The Land's End Labyrinth was created by Eduardo Aguilera in 2004 as a place to find peace and meditate, but it's definitely become more of a tourist attraction. Depending on the time you go, there will usually be a few people there and you'll have to wait for a turn for a photo.
author: Maleah M.

description:
I've been here countless times with different groups of family and friends. Everyone I've taken here has enjoyed the hike and the view!

I love Land's End due to the fact that I am completely surrounded by nature. Dependent upon where you are on the trail, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Sutro Baths, and the labyrinth. This is not an easy nature walk, but the small hike is worth it! The hike can vary in difficulty depending on the path you take. For a more relaxed time, follow the signs!

Park at the parking lot on top of the hill, not the one below with all the tourists. From there, walk into the trail and you will see signs along the way. Follow the directions to Mile Rock Beach and you will pass the labyrinth on your way down to the shore. The labyrinth is a great photo op as well. Also, try to maneuver your way into the center if it is your first visit there. The beach is more like a strip of shoreline. Be ready to take off your shoes and get wet! Be careful since there is lots of algae and thus it is extremely slippery out there. 

I definitely recommend visiting Land's End on a clear day. You won't see much if you come on a foggy day! Also, wear sneakers you're not afraid of dirtying!
author: Kristi T.

description:
If you're in San Francisco, you have to walk along this trail. My coworker recommended this to me and I'm so glad she did. The views of the bridge and ocean are amazing!!! It's not a difficult hike and it's absolutely breathtaking. There were other people walking the trails and sightseeing so it didn't feel secluded.

Not sure how good/bad parking is because I took a cab from my hotel. I definitely recommend wearing comfortable shoes.
author: Ayeisha C.

description: Beautiful place to enjoy views of the beach and  Golden Gate Bridge. The trail to get to the best sights of the bridge are a little steep and involves some stairs, but not too difficult. The only complaint I would make is that the trails are covered in fine sand. So it makes walking up the stairs a little more strenuous and if you are walking behind someone, most likely bc there are a lot of tourists, it kicks up dust into your face. Nothing a good shower won't fix!. Worth it if you want to sight see!
author: Joanne C.

description:
This is a beautiful "secret" spot to enjoy within miles away from the city. This is also near the Cliff House where you can enjoy the food and scenery. At the Cliff House you are surrounded by the beauty of an ocean view, a fisherman, and the Sutro baths. 

The history behind the Sutro baths was developed in 1894 by a self- made millionaire Adolph Sutro, who wanted to make a haven for people to enjoy recreational swimming. His baths could allow up to 10,000 people at one time! Crazy! Due to be Great Depression the popularity died down. A high rise fire destroyed parts of the facility in 1966 and what is left is the remains of the baths. 

Take the mile hike to the labyrinth and view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Along the trail you can see the VA hospital, take a few stairs up to the U.S.S. San Francisco memorial (very tiny), and finally to Lands End Point.  There are sandy stairs to the left that go down to the labyrinth trail and another trail to the right that is just sandy trail. The ocean current winds bring down the temperature to a bitter coldness. Walk in the little maze and take a few pics. Watch the cargo boats go by. Gaze at the Golden Gate Bridge view into the fog. You may continue the trail to Dead Man's Point and Eagle Point Overlook. 

This was a nice easy hike with great views. I'm glad I took a visit here. Btw, for an additional bonus, the parking is free.
author: Tzarina W.

description:
If you've been searching for the perfect place to take a nice stroll next to the Pacific Ocean with the Golden Gate Bridge in plain sight, and trees that will give you temporary shade from the sunlight, with recurring detours to small beaches (if you so choose to venture in those directions) - LOOK NO FURTHER. Lands End Trail is the happy gateway between land and water without having to get sand all up in your shoes. 

You will ask yourself, "Am I still in San Francisco?" I mean, I wouldn't have believed you if you said yes...even with the Golden Gate staring straight at me.

You have no choice but to immerse yourself into the beauty that is the San Francisco Bay..with perfectly paved trails and stairways leading you into corners that were made with photo-ops in mind. 

Parking is free near the look out and the trail begins at Sutro Baths, which by the way, is rich in history. There are caves and rocks to explore during this first half of the trip. The helpful guides in the visitor center will make sure that your trip is mapped out. I've been here only twice, and I haven't made it passed the Labyrinth due to time constraints. Bring your tourist friends! Instead of driving all the way to the Presidio or Marin Headlands for the Golden Gate. I feel like this place is overlooked because it requires some walking.
author: Melanie B.

description:
If you are in sf, you should stop by this trail to walk around to see ocean beach.
It was a huge free parking lot.
A lot of people were doing exercise or walking around to get fresh air.
Highly recommended!!!
author: Jane K.

description: Great hike! It's a pretty easy trail with a few inclines from some hills and a few flights of stairs, but overall it is very beginner-friendly.  There are multiple beaches that you can reach from various trails and overall you will have a decent view of the bridge.  When we came here, there were a lot of other people who brought their dogs.  There is also a cafe by the visitor center, so if you forgot to pack some food or want a hot cup of coffee, you are in luck! Lastly, the visitor parking lot is easy to park in on weekdays.  On weekends, it will be hard to get a spot at all.
author: Justin L.

description:
LOVE Land's End Trail.

It's great because it's such a diverse trail. At one end (South/West) you have the beautiful Sutro Baths (where everyone takes the "love rock" picture after walking through a cave). On the other end, you have a short trail hike to the rock formation/maze with a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

Either way, you get a fantastic view of the bridge, lots of greenery, and great spots of shade/sun, and a definite work out. I've seen locals and tourists come regardless of the day...and you can catch super young kids like 5 years old taking baby steps with their crazy (or courageous) family members, or athletic 20-something yuppies running the trails like bosses. 

Land's End is one of my favorite trails in SF, and its great miles-long hikes and hard-to-beat views are why I keep coming back.
author: Jodi H.

description: Great way to spend a couple of hours walking along the marked trails and down to the Sutro Baths and beach!
author: Julia C.

description: I've been here the past three weekends at various times, definitely the earlier you can go the better. Parking can be abysmal if you arrive around lunch time, or if it's a sunny day out. They allow dogs, which is fantastic! The upkeep could be better... there's graffiti and lots of muck on the path that I wish the city would clear. Also if suggest that if you are actually looking for a legit workout, you arrive early or come later in the evening. It's impossible to run, or even walk fast for that matter,  with all the kids and people lazily strolling on the path. Otherwise it's an SF institution!
author: Hayley H.

description:
Land's end is really awesome. You have many trails around this area! This trail goes from Sutro baths all the way through Legion of Honor to Land's end eagle point. There are alot of tourists in the beginning of the trail but don't be discouraged! They just come to look at the view just down the steps! 
The best part is going down the trail, down to the beach which takes about 15 or 20 minutes of casual walking. It's easy walking and I would know because I was wearing sandals all the way to the beach. You will reach a split in the path where downhill will take you to the beach and uphill will take you to the rock labyrinth! Let's head to the beach first! When you get to the beach, there are some nice places to sit but be careful because it is mostly windy here and you will get cold because Land's end literally faces the outer bay which faces the ocean.
You can venture further out to the beach but the sand turns into rocks so be careful not to sprain your ankle or fall because seagulls have no empathy for fallen humans. They will just fly by you without assisting you. Those jerk birds. You will come across broken concrete structures that's covered in graffiti artwork. It's actually quite beautiful if I don't say so myself! By now you can keep walking, climb over the rock formation and you'll come to a giant rock in the sea in the background. This is where people don't come so you can have peace and quiet!
Going back to the split on the road, we will go uphill where it will lead us to a cliff overlooking the golden gate bridge with a rock labyrinth and this place is also windy! On a clear day you can see the Golden Gate bridge and even Sausalito!
This is a great little gem hidden away in SF away from the city, tourists and businessmen! Just bring a jacket or the cold air might make it your end
author: Jason H.

description:
Let me clear when I say that this hike is NOT easy. If you stay on the normal path then yes most people can do it without breaking a sweat. If you decide up or down stairs than you are in for a work out. 

On another note it is a hike. I loved path. I do wish there were more maps the further you go. However it was beautiful and it felt special to be along the coast hiking.
author: M L.

description:
Hiking date spot?! Check.
Dog approved?! Check.
Breath-taking views?! Check.
Romantic?! Check.
Free parking?! Check.

We parked where Legion of Honor is at and just walked through the trail where the Golf Course is at. It was such a nice walk/hike plus the gorgeous sunny weather! You could totally bring your furry friend for a walk/jog/run.Also, enjoy the beach to play fetch with your furry friend. 

Them stairs though.
author: Aarize D.

description:
First time coming here in the month of January, weather was fairly decent and we had some great moments just sitting there watching the waves crash into the coast.

We caught a lovely view from the top looking down below at the balcony where the majority of people were and just felt at peace. 

Forever love this spot and will recommend to anyone who plans to visit the SF Area!
author: lidia e.

description:
The last time here was our first and as tourists.  It probably took an hour just to get to the steps because we stopped every minute or two to gawk and gaze and marvel at the all the beauty.  And dogs. :)

We went again on Sunday, as new residents to the peninsula and WITH our dog. We knew from experience that we'd get little exercise without being intentional, and that we were. We took in the steps, walked mostly at a good clip but stopped several times on the way back to count whale blows and note the sailboats that were sitting still, fighting the tide that was about to change.  

Friendly people, fragrant eucalyptus and beauty EVERYWHERE! 

Tip - go into the park store before leaving for a knockout scone or the wonderful SF original, "It's-It Ice Cream". 

Tip - no bikes on trail! We saw a few rebels.

Tip - lots of dogs off leash which we love, but... better to leash them and keep very close on steps due to all the runners.  We saw a few near disasters involving runners and dogs on and off leash. And same for little kiddos. The runners seemed aware and respectful of shared space but not so much, the wanderers.

NO BIKES PEOPLE!

Been here a dozen times since starting review. Love Lands End!
author: Carol L.

description:
Land's End Trail in San Francisco is beautiful and awe inspiring. The views of the Bay and The Golden Gate Bridge are breathtaking.  My family and I traveled here to see the sites and have a little picnic lunch. What we found were tall lush trees, beautiful flowers and great views.
