We went during the week so it wasn't too crowded. There were walkers, runners and sight-seers.  We didn't come upon any picnic areas but many people just made a spot in the foliage and eat while watching the water. At the start of the trail there is a nice information plaque and a
Set of benches to sit and watch the beach below. We didn't have a chance to godown to the labyrinth as the fog rolled in just as we were approaching it. There was plenty of on the street parking and a golfing area too. We will definitely be going back again.
author: Anjanette W.

description:
No other place soothes my soul and brings me peace than hiking at Lands End Trail and visiting Sutro Baths at Ocean Beach. Has been my all time favorite place to spend time at since my first glorious visit during my childhood years. There are many places to walk/hike to and breathtaking scenic views from all around. The trail starts just up the hill from the famous Cliff House and will take you along with a starting view of the grand and majestic Golden Gate Bridge. The trail will lead you past to a long stairway downwards to what I like to call the rock beach since there are soooo many beautiful rocks of all sizes when you reach the bottom of the stairs. This used to be a fairly quiet area with not too many visitors near the beach down below however now is rightfully and happily enjoyed by thousands of regulars and tourists as well. There are many stairs that will provide an awesome and well deserved workout as you venture onward and upward then again downward along the path to the Lands End trail. 
Ocean Beach is a site in itself with the most beautiful sunrises and sunsets.
author: Yoh M.

description:
I came from out of town, with friends, to check out the hiking trail at Lands End. We took the suggested path listed on their website and started off at the Visitor Center to enrich ourselves with knowledge for the hike. After we made our way to the Sutro Baths which we all thought were pretty neat! Shorty after we began our hike. We all enjoyed the different types of greenery along the trail. I loved seeing the colorful blooming flowers that were littered throughout. The trail provides lovely views overlooking the ocean and in the distance you are able to see the Golden Gate Bridge. Absolutely breath-taking! 

This hiking trail is much more scenic rather than strenuous. However, you will find that the trail contains a lot of stairs. The longest one being the stairway going back up from the Lands End Point. It will surely make you break a sweat!  

The trail has so much to offer! From the Sutro Baths, USS San Francisco Memorial, Meditation Labyrinth, and everything in between! I'm just glad that I was finally able to mark the meditation labyrinth off my bucket list of things to see.
author: Martha H.

description:
This was very disappointing as there are entirely too many people to really enjoy the views of the ocean and Golden Gate Bridge.  
The parking lot fills up very fast and you may have to park quite far and walk up the hill to get there. The Sutro Baths (located in the same area) are very cool if you read about the history beforehand, as there are no informational signs anywhere. 
As this is also a dog friendly hike, unfortunately there are ZERO garbage cans on the trail. Being a responsible pet owner, picking up poop is part of the game and having to carry a bag full of dog poop for 2 miles is very disgusting. As a result, there are many colorful poop bags along the trail (I am sure from people that were tired of carrying it...I was tempted to drop mine as well, but just couldn't).
Aside from a few good photos and finding the Sutro Baths interesting, I wouldn't recommend this place/hike to anyone. There are plenty of other trails and photo ops at nearby trails that don't attract half as many people.
author: Steph T.

description: Beautiful easy hike. Trails are very easy to follow. A lot of fun. Parking is limited.
author: Danny N Caitlin L.

description: Incredible views.. Great trail.. Very scenic and relaxing.. Very happy I stumbled upon this place!!!!
author: Sara R.

description: Such a beautiful trail with amazing views of the bridge especially on a clear day.  Nice little hike down to the Sutro Bath and caves.  Since the weather hasn't been so good and there was a mudslide during the last storm, some areas are blocked off.  I'm sure they will reopen once it's sunny again. But the walk along the costal trail is breathtaking.  You really feel at peace here.  Love this spot!
author: Leizel B.

description:
I love this trail. I have some wonderful memories racing my ex's son and falling in love with the trail (and the kid). It's too bad relationships have to end (not the ex but the kid) because I would love to race him again!

Highly recommend!
author: Karen G.

description:
I can't believe such a beautiful area exists so close to the city! I would kill to have a  trail/hike like this in Orange County. 

My friend and wonderful hostess took me here last Thursday afternoon, and although we were ill equipped to hike (we both wore boots and carried handbags... I wore a dress and a peacoat, she wore jeans and a cardigan...), I had a fantastic time. The trail itself (or at least the portion I explored) wasn't too strenuous, but enough to get in some decent exercise. 

I felt very lucky because the weather was nice that day, and I was able to see a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the water. The hidden beaches along the way and the plant life are really amazing as well (check out the photos!). 

I liked it so much that I actually wanted to return again on my 4-day trip to SF, but didn't have time. Will DEFINITELY return if I'm back in the area.
author: Jane W.

description:
This is an amazing trail!! There's so many stairs though lol. For someone like me, who doesn't actually workout, it nearly "killed" me. That was coming back up though. Also we didn't do the whole trail. We went up to where the rock maze was @ and the beach area down there. It's such an awesome view of the Golden Gate Bridge and seeing the sunset. Also there's a LOT of mussels on the rocks!! I really really like it. You get a good workout, plus a reward from it. You could have a picnic down in that little beach area. There's a lot of people though, so expect it. But it's so worth it!

I want to go back!! :D
author: Akemi H.

description:
Gorgeous views, easy walk, and there are stairs on all the trails so it makes for a simple hike when going up the hills. Definitely check out the Sutro Baths and The Labyrinth. I wouldn't recommend causal clothing or anything but good walking shoes but I saw a lot of people dressed to take pictures and not to hike around. It can get pretty windy too so always bring light jackets. 
You can definitely spend hours on this trail and walk all the way to Baker Beach from the Cliff House. Just forewarned that it will be crowded on the weekends.
author: Victoria T.

description:
This is a wonderful hike. We came early and there were two free lots and plenty of street parking. But by mid afternoon, this was not the case... so just keep that in mind! 

The trail is not too difficult. It's fairly flat terrain so even if you aren't experienced, that shouldn't be an issue. You can walk down to the Sutro baths, the Labyrinth, and wonderful views of the Golden Gate bridge. 

All the trails are dog friendly. You don't have to have them leashed and the dogs have so much fun! 

Overall, I recommend doing this hike and getting spectacular views of the ocean and Golden Gate bridge!
author: Daisy K.

description: I mean...how can you not give Land's End 5 stars? Spent some time exploring this area on a Sunday afternoon and it was just great to see so many people out. Lots of families. The trails and scenery are beautiful and THE VIEW. Not everyone can say they get this view often so I was definitely taking advantage of the the time for self reflection. Although it was a bit gloomy, it was still an amazing view.
author: Anna P.

description: Went on a Saturday during fleet week around 830 am, not crowded at all and weather was perfect, all views are perfect, I was in such shock how un crowded this place was, will DEF do again.
author: Elena B.

description:
One of the most beautiful spots in the city and one of my personal favorite places to walk. If you're over the suspiciously smelly places in downtown and other major tourist areas, then this is the perfect place to getaway. It gets a little busy on the weekends, but that shouldn't stop you from visiting! It's not much of a difficult hike. There's some short areas that can test your legs and lungs, but overall it's like a "Yay, I'm getting a good workout" as opposed to "I am literally dying" kind of feeling.

I recommend checking out a map of the place so you can find out where the labyrinth and other brief rest areas are. The labyrinth area has an amazing, unobstructed view of the Golden Gate Bridge (if it's not foggy!) and the cliffs around. Definitely the perfect rest stop on this beautiful trail! Since it's by the ocean, it can get a little chilly, so it wouldn't hurt to bring an extra jacket with you.

There's a bunch of different areas you can park. The lot right next to the Sutro Baths fill up quite fast, not surprising since it has such a great view of the ocean. I recommend entering on El Camino Del Mar, where there are a lot more parking spots!
author: Karen T.

description:
Highly recommend the Lands End Trail. 

Thanks to other Yelpers, we opted to park at Lands End, and hike the trail all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge. One way was about 4.5 miles. There were certainly some challenging parts, especially if you are not in shape at all! Mainly in the form of steps. But, the views were so worth it! 

The trail was made up of packed dirt. It was wide, which made passing slower walkers quite easy. Stretches of the trail were covered by a canopy of trees, which would be beneficial for runners on sunny days. 

As it was for us, the fog was nice and thick. Temperature hovered around 58 degrees, so some spots were chilly, but you warmed up when you climbed the steps. Definitely dress in layers, and wear dry fit/tech clothes if possible, which will dry quickly when you are sweating. 

We love this trail because it is not over run by the typical tourist. Strongly recommend this route!
author: Kate R.

description:
Third time here, This place is AMAZING.  My review might be a little bias since I live in New York City, where there is really not much green around.  The hike is very easy, and the paths are all well maintained, entrances were also well marked.  My favorite part about lands end is the mile rock beach - if you come on a weekday it's usually pretty empty and you can go and explore all the tide pools down there, I've seen starfish, crabs, shrimp, small fish, and mussels galore.  I will say just watch out for the tide! It can come in pretty quick and you don't want to be stuck further down the beach when the tide comes in... you might not be able to get back to path if that happens.  

OH! and be sure to keep an eye out for whales! I saw a few whales surfacing in the bay.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Loved this hiking trail!! There are parking lots as well as street parking. We got lucky, even though it was busy. Just follow the people around to their parking spots. 

It was a beautiful cool fall day. It was cold, but the weather was great for a hike. It technically wasn't even a hike, but more like an trail. We walked down to the beach, explored the ruins and the cave. You can continue up the path and it'll lead you to a view of the golden gate bridge. It's really nice here and I'd definitely come back and do it again!
author: Vy T.

description:
Your tiny and irrelevant existence to the world as a whole becomes crystal clear when you're standing on one of the breathtaking cliffs, the powerful Pacific Ocean waves crashing underneath you, with the wide open sea on the left, and the Bay on the right, guarded by the majestic Golden Gate Bridge.

San Francisco at its best.

If you don't feel like hiking, there are plenty of other sights and activities close by. Take the Holocaust Memorial, the Legion of Honor, or the Golf course. 

Stunning!
author: Sebastian F.

description: AMAZING views, GGB in many occasions l! Find the cave and you can even go down to the beach. Not too short and not too long of a trail. This can be a round trail.There's 3-4 sets of free parking places at the starting of this trail.
author: Anna I.

description: Great trail - but I have a warning.  My girlfriend and I were robbed from the parking lot across the trails.  We witnessed criminals smash our window out and grab our suitcases.  This crime was witnessed from hundreds of feet away across the street.  Do not make the mistake we did of leaving valuables in your car!
author: Rob C.

description: What a gem of a hike. Located behind Cliff's House, this hike can be as easy or as strenuous as you like. In any case, the views are just phenomenal. There's a visitor center with maps and clean restrooms before you start your trek. There are no restrooms on the trail.Free parking in the lots and along the street. The trail is paved part of the way and dirt/sandy other parts. I wore hiking boots but tennis shoes will do. I saw some in flip flops but they were dragging along. There's some inclines and optional stairs that are well worth the view. The Land's End Trail hike can be done in an hour with stops to the Bath Ruins and detour to the cave. Its about 3 miles roundtrip. I highly recommend stopping by the Labryinth. Ask for a map follow the trail to the end of the stairs and over the hump when you get to the mound of dirt.
author: Linh T.

description:
Beautiful, majestic views of the ocean and Bay. Quite a gem of San Francisco. It can be a very different environment depending on what time of day or night you are there - dawn, mid-day, sunset, night. All awesome. 
I come here on occasion with my family to hike along the trail. My favorite visit so far was when I walked with my son at sunset. We started at Sutro Baths and walked past the USS San Francisco memorial. The fog was rolling in off the ocean while the sun was setting. Amazing. 
There is a mix of tourist groups, joggers, families, groups of teenagers, and photographers. 
It's a flat trail and is appropriate for all ages. Plenty of parking too.  I am sometimes surprised to see how few people are walking the trail, but no complaints ;)
author: David S.

description: If you love nice adventure sceneries but hate the hard hikes to get there than this is the trail for you.  Land's End is a very easy hike with very beautiful views and nice photogenic spots.  I suggest going early as parking really fills up later in the day.  The rock formation called the Labyrinth is amazing, but if you come later in the day than it will be hard to get a picture in it as there will be a lot of people navigating their way around it.  The Land's End trail has a wonderful view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the ocean.  Make sure you wear a jacket as it is really windy and cold especially down at the Sutro Baths because it is closer to the ocean.  Land's end is a great place for all types of activities (hiking, picnicking, family outing, watching the sunset and etc). 10/10 would do this again.
author: Dang L.

description:
You need a wind breaker to come here! There are so many good places to take photos here! Went with a friend and it was very fun! The trail is not bad, as its pretty flat except a few stair areas. Those baths in the beginning are very beautiful.

I love the trees here as well! Theres a nice place to sit on them. Love it!
author: Jasmina D.

description:
This is a great place to go for a leisurely hike. The view is gorgeous, they have public bathrooms (and they're actually pretty clean!), a store with a small coffee shop inside with some beverages and snack options, and you get gorgeous views of the ocean, Sutro Baths, and on a clear day, the Golden Gate Bridge. 

I'm definitely gonna bring my mom here when she visits next. :)
author: Mandi W.

description: What else can be said? Take this hike! Nice, wide pathways (with some challenging steps) and stunning oceans views at every turn. We began at the Sutro Baths heading toward Baker Beach and the GG Bridge. You are truly at the edge of the continent! A trip to San Francisco is never complete without a visit to Land's End.
author: Lara S.

description:
Its a very easy  ~2 mile trail and the terrain is pretty much flat. There are a couple of detours which you might want to take to get closer to the beach. Even otherwise, the trail itself offers beautiful views of golden gate bridge and the bay. 

Go in the evenings and you can capture some really good sunset pictures.
author: Praneeth Y.

description:
On days where I want to get out for a walk that includes scenic views but not feeling an intense hike, Land' s End fits the bill quite nicely. Whether it's a magical foggy day or a glorious crystal clear sunny sky, you will be amazed at how close you are to the hustle of San Francisco but still far enough removed to be in awe of raw and pure nature.

Over the last several years the trailhead near the Sutro Baths and the start of the trail have received a facelift, with new signage, additional placards to read and well paved paths at the start. This is where the majority of walkers converge and the trail remains crowded for at least the first 1/2-3/4 of a mile. Not that the trail is by any means difficult, but this first portion is more pedestrian friendly and those visitors in flimsier shoes or fancier clothes will partake in this part of the trail. And why not? Gorgeous, vast views abound and on a clear day you can see the Marin Headlands and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Once the obvious photo ops trickle, the trail begins to lighten up a bit with visitors and the trails become every so slightly more rugged (dirt and gravel versus fully paved.) At about .7 miles, you can diverge down the steps to Mile Rock Beach and spend some time meandering down through the pines and clamboring over rocks to view the crashing waves and powerful surf more closely. I highly recommend going down this side trail and back up again to rejoin the Land's End trail, before continuing on our journey to Eagle's Lookout Point at the end of the trail. The stairs to and from Mile Rock Beach aren't super strenuous but offer a tiny bit of exertion and not for those who aren't physically able to do a lot of climbing.

Once at Eagle's Lookout, you can opt to turn back the way you came (the whole trail is less than 3 miles round trip-not counting any side excursions) or, as I have sometimes done, continue on the coastal trail which meanders its way through the Sea Cliff residential area and takes you over towards China Beach and Baker Beach. If you really felt compelled once at Baker Beach, you can connect with some of the Presido trails and head towards the Golden Gate Bridge via the Battery to Bluffs trail as well. I've done that as well as taken a side trip to the Legion of Honor grounds, which is closer to the start of the trailhead, near Land's End. 

All in all, you are rewarded with bracing sea views, a variety of seabirds, coastal butterflies and if you are lucky (and it's the right time of year) whale sightings. A walk in this area makes me feel as if all is right again with the world and is a perfect day by the sea.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I came here on a sunny December weekday and only saw a few people jogging by. I felt like I was by myself for most of the hour and a half.  It was so nice walking along the beautiful coastal trail with its incredible views and just enjoying nature all around me. The easy trail winds through woods and along the rocky cliffs and has a wonderful view of the Golden Gate bridge.

It's fun to walk down the stairs to the labyrinth and the little rocky beach area, but not as fun walking up :-) I was a little too tired from a long day of touring the city to go all the way down to the Sutro Baths and Cliff House, but it looked pretty cool from above.

I would absolutely come back here again!
author: Catherine B.

description:
This trail provides for easy/moderate hiking, simple enough for those in casual wear to intense runners/hikers dressed head to toe in athletic gear. Dog friendly!

The Sutro Baths area offers a large private lot with plentiful free parking. There is a gift shop/info center with clean bathrooms and places to eat nearby.

The trail splits off in multiple directions for various adventures. My friend and I had the most trouble locating the rock labyrinth. So, if you are walking from Sutro Baths and are looking for the labyrinth, go LEFT at the fork in the trail. Continue until you reach the cliff area and walk towards the end of the cliff. The labyrinth will be on the other side. If you instead continue downwards, you will find a quiet rocky beach.

Beautiful place for hiking with breathtaking sights. Great place to get away from the city and appreciate Mother Nature.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
If you like the outdoors, nature, hiking, beautiful views, or great photo ops, this is a MUST-VISIT when you are in SF! 

The hiking trail is not that difficult. I don't consider myself an athletic person at all and it was a pretty easy trail even for me. It's flat terrain for the most part, and I think only 1.2 miles each way if you do the general coastal trail. The only slightly challenging part were all the stairs along the way, but there aren't too many and it's only in a couple sections of the hike. I loved how there were so many tall trees and the ocean view is also gorgeous! And there's plenty of spots along the trail where you can take photos with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background. There's also some other interesting photo ops with a big rock spiral on the ground, and also the Sutro Baths. 

Free parking in their lot!
author: Diana I.

description:
This is as close to a typical tourist day-out as I might get and let's be honest: why would you walk anywhere else to catch a glimpse of the bridge that, among other things, gives San Francisco it's name? 

Getting to Lands End, for me, was a pleasant enough bus ride down to Sutro Baths where I set out on my trail hike. Going mid-week was a way to ensure I missed the masses but there were still ample fellow walkers to keep it feeling like if I was attacked by a mythical hyena I'd still make it out alive (yes, I'm exaggerating). 

This remains one of my most fond memories of San Francisco. The walk itself is from Sutro Baths to Pacific Heights is mostly flat and easy to walk (I'd recommend wearing comfortable shoes) and while there's some stairs to it, it's not too taxing. The benefit? Sweeping views of the bay, Pacific Heights and just good old fashioned fresh air!
author: Lani P.

description:
AUGUST 2-15 From what others have told me, Land End's Labyrinth has been destroyed because of vandalism. I don't know the situation on rebuilding, but want to let others know.  DON'T DESTROY ARTWORK. PLEASE. 

Onto the review of Lands End...

San Francisco, you have me jealous of your beaches. As a SoCal local, I thought that it would be a waste of my time to visit beaches up in San Francisco since I thought the beaches would be similar. No, no. NO! Lands End Trail is unlike any other beach I've been to. 

Despite the huge amount of people and tourists (including myself) visiting this spot, I recommend coming here. The trails available at Lands End are gorgeous. Due to the weather in San Francisco,  the plant life of the beach/hills, even during the summer, is amazing. There's such a huge variety in color and shrubs and is extremely gorgeous to look at.

There's the history of Lands End Trail located in the visitor center, trails to walk down and see the location of abandoned Sutro Baths, a small cave tunnel to walk through, the beach, and many more. 

Lands End is a great spot to stop by to watch the sunset at San Francisco. The only reason I don't give it a 5 stars is because of the amount of trash that was on the beaches. I saw multiple abandoned beer bottles and even some broken glass in the water. Please be careful and watch where you're walking while on the beaches and clean up after yourself (and others.)
author: Trang L.

description:
The real life secret garden! 

We always wish to have a secret garden for us to hide from the reality and  free our mind. For me, Lands end trail is my secret garden. Of course, you may also organize some fun activities such as hiking, running, or hang out with friends, too. 

Lands End Trail is connect to the mouth of Golden Gate Park. It is located next to the historic Sutro Bath and Cliff House along the Pacific Ocean coastline. There are a few interesting points to stop by such as Eagle View Point, Mile Rock Beach, Labyrinth, and Lands End Point. At Each point, you are able to enjoy the spectacular view of Golden Gate Bridge which is located across the ocean. My personal favorite point is mile rock beach, which is still not yet discovered by a lot of people. In Mile Rock Beach, besides of the romantic ocean view at sunset, you can practice stone stacking skill in Mile Rock Beach. However, you might have to climb down the long sand staircase and walk all the way down to the beach side, so I suggest wearing a pair of sport shoes instead of regular sandals or sneakers when visiting Mile Rock Beach. 

To visit Lands End Trail is easy. You may reach there by taking number 38 or 38X Muni bus from Geary Street and get off in front of Lands End Trail entrance. You also can take N Judah Train and get off on Ocean Beach station, which is the last station of N Judah train, and spend another 30 minutes walk along the Ocean Beach to the trail. Other than that, due to lack of public restroom, you may use the bathroom which is located at Cliff House tourist center before go into Lands End Trail. Also, plenty of parking spaces were provided for those who drive. Drivers also may park their car next to Ocean Beach side and reach Lands End Trail by walking. 

In short, I love Lands End Trail. JIt is good to spend more time with mother nature rather than just stay at home or office.
author: Emanon Y.

description: This is an easy hiking trail you can do. Plus where ever you walk to along the paths there's a bit of history as you go. There's the sutro baths, the USS sf memorial, the labyrinth and a perfect view of the golden gate bridge from a far. Plus there's free parking too!
author: Tuyen H.

description: Absolutely stunning. Fantastic hiking opportunities, beautiful views, and a lookout spot for a drink for some unwinding after. Highly recommend this area for a sunny afternoon! You can go as far or walk as little as you like, and it's incredible all around. I spent a total of about 2 hours here and it was a good amount. Keep in mind if you come here and you're driving, be careful of what you leave out in the open. I didn't have any issues with this but there are signs of people breaking into cars and lots of help reviews it too, so please be smart and be careful!
author: Parenty L.

description:
Wow, this trail was definitely one of the highlights of my trip, and I only got to enjoy it for less than an hour! I was on a tight schedule, but I really wanted to do a hike while visiting the city. The invigorating feeling of breathing in fresh air during an early morning hike is just one of life's treasures! Anyway, I definitely came over prepared for this trail with my camelback and shoes,lol. The trail itself had smoothed out paths to follow, which made the path quite accessible. Unfortunately, there were cloudy skies the day I went so I didn't get the perfect bridge shot, but it was still a magnificent view.  During our hike we passed some families and even a huge group of elderly hikers. Everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves and taking in the sights. 

I really felt thankful that I was able to stop by here and enjoy the breathtaking views!
author: Kady W.

description:
Lands End Trail is a perfect hike and trail to get some good exercise while enjoying the view of SF and beautiful nature. Along the way, there are different view points of the ocean and golden gate bridge!

One trail leads straight to the ocean, here you can listen to the waves crash on the little beach cove. Many families were there with their kids and other couples were just enjoying the serenity. Another trail leads to a peak point which allows you to peer out and view the golden gate bridge. The furthest part of the trail is 1.5 miles out. One of my favorite parts of the trail is the wild blackberries! So yummy, I ate them, they were perfectly organic!

Lands End trail is an epic adventure =)
author: Rochelle E.

description:
I've walked the trail off and on since I was a kid.  Back then it was walking on part of old Hwy 1.  Then it abruptly ended underneath the VA hospital.  You could snake through and make your way to the Legion of Honor and Sea Cliff if you wanted to.

Now that Lands End is under the umbrella of GGNRA, it's vastly improved.  Paved walking trail that leads you from Lands End all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge.  Each time I walk the trail I notice minute changes.  No more snaking through thick shrubbery and unsanctioned trails. Keep an eye out for poison oak!

This is definitely one of the great places to come to and take in nature in the best cosmopolitan city.
author: Shirley N.

description:
So maybe it's not exactly the "secret hideaway" you were going for considering this place has hundreds of reviews, but this is by far one of my top three spots to explore on a frequent basis and also show visitors

On a clear, sunny day, this provides for one of the most gorgeous hikes in the city (and take "hike" very lightly--you shouldn't have an issue getting around the area). The trail takes you right along the cliffs for a beautiful view of the ocean and the Golden Gate Bridge. The air is crisp and fresh with the smell of ocean spray permeating throughout the air

At some point at the trail, you'll see steps; if you follow this part of the trail, you'll make it to the "secret labyrinth" at the cliffs which has a gorgeous rock formation and even mor breathtaking view. 

And if you climb down the cliff just a bit more, you'll make it to the rocky beach area for a nice relaxing picnic or break during your hike. 

All in all, this is a great place for hiking, running, spending time with friends, or even a romantic little date come sunset.
author: Jay P.

description: What a hike!! Drove all the way from Sacramento to do this hike. The view of the pacific ocean and gold gate bridge was gorgeous. Started our hike around 9am. Weather was perfect. I remember there was two different trails. All I know is that we took the trail going twds the Golden Gate bridge. The hike was not too hard, but the stairs though...a different story. We followed the trail and also went off the trail just so we can get close to the waters. We also saw the Labryrinth. Coolest thing ever. That is a must. We kept going and going. We finally ended up at China Beach. We did have to go through some residential areas to get there. I remember we were in the El Camino Del Mar area. Man....them houses. So gorgeous and big. The view from China beach was absolutely gorgeous. Couldn't resist we had to get in the water. I didn't bring change of clothes so only my feet and legs got wet.
author: Joann P.

description:
One of the best "hikes" to do in SF
It's relatively short and offers great views of the GG bridge. 
Parking can be horrendous on certain days but if you time is right you can grab a spot in the three parking areas. 

As of my visit on 8/15, the iconic Labyrinth is gone. All that remains is the outline of where the rocks used to be.
author: Brian L.

description:
Run Down:
1. Great view of the Golden Gate Bridge
2. Gorgeous Beach is always a plus
3. Tall deep green brush
4. Easy light trail
5. Big rocks to climb on
6. The labyrinth! 

Tips:
1. It can get windy, Bring a jacket
2. The labyrinth is down the trail and at the end of the steps.
3. Bring your camera, you'll want to take pictures
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Can't get enough of this place! One of the most beautiful spots in San Francisco with the best view of the golden gate. It's the best when the weather is clear and the scenery is spectacular. 
There's a few steep climbs but well maintained stairs to get you up and down. No bathrooms on the paths or trashcans so be aware. 
It's really not  a long hike but can feel like one if you don't have the proper shoes or mindset. 
This captures the beauty of the city and of the California coast. Definitely worth a gander
author: Naomi K.

description:
So beautiful. hiking trail right along the cliffs under the golden gate bridge and sea cliff area. Near China beach and just so pretty. The winds coming off the bay and the water crashing down below all made it so memorable and I could have spent an entire day there just walking the trails and smelling the cool salty air. 

This is why I moved to the Bay Area. For experiences like this. Check it out, find a parking spot and just go linger amidst the redwoods, the humid air of the salty ocean below and the scenic views of the Golden Gate bridge. It really is what life is all about.
author: Tanya C.

description: This is my favorite place. I love the hike to Land's End Labyrinth. And then to continue down to Mile Rock Beach. When the tide is down it's amazing to take a long walk along the beach. The hike back up is very rewarding. Please be sure to be very careful out there on those cliffs.
author: Valerie N.

description:
Both time I was there, I had a great time. This trail is known for the labyrinth but the whole area itself has a bit of something unique to explore. Parking is free which is a rare thing in San Francisco. And there's also extra parking lot on the other side, that face away from the ocean.

- Limited time: go check out Sutro Baths
- Half Day: take a short hike to labyrinth + Sutro Baths

On my first visit, we only had time to check out Sutro Baths and the cave. It was once a popular Baths that got burned down back in the 19something. As for the cave, it's a small one where you get to explore further more to the ocean. Must wear shoes for this cause the area is pretty wet. 

On my second trip, I intended to hike to the labyrinth so I was prepared to explore  the whole place. There are plenty of trails for you to choose from so it's hard to navigate anyone. As long you stay on the coastal trail,  it will take you there. We did a lot of exploring that day so we went all over. But once you get to the labyrinth, you can see the Golden Gate bridge from far away. Lucky us, it was nice and sunny that day so the view was spectacular! Walking around the maze was fun as well.

I wouldn't call this hiking since it was an easy trail. It was more of walking along the coast and enjoying nature kinda thing. Though, wearing shoes would be more appropriate and a jacket is a must because it gets pretty windy there!
author: Phung D.

description:
Classic San Fran Hike. If you live in the bay area it is a must if you like walking. If your a tourist definitely come out and enjoy the breathtaking views...hopefully on a  non foggy day.

Great parking lot at trail head with wonderful views...for those who are not inclined to get out of their cars.

Great places near by to grab lunch or breakfast: Use your Yelp app!!!!
author: David G.

description:
I hate reviewing trails.  Why am I doing it again?

It's a trail.  It's a TRAIL.  Do you know what a trail is?  That's what this is.  A trail.  You walk along it.  It has a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

I don't know what else to say.  Can I laugh at the reviews below mine?  Like the one star review with the person overemphasizing that these cliffs are dangerous?  Oh yes, stay away from this trail along a cliff because it's a trail along a cliff.  You might fall.  Also, one star all restaurants I ate at retroactively, because if I didn't chew my food properly I could have choked and died.  Or drowned in my soup...oh dear.  The world is such a dangerous place.

Is that too mean?  Am I being mean to this person I don't know?  Have I lost complete track of where I am in this review?  Yes, yes, and yes?  Good, just confirming all that,

It's a nice hike and at no point would you ever be in danger of dying unless you purposefully dash right towards the edge of a cliff (so basically don't be stupid).  I also noticed the trail had a lot of groups of teenage goths walking along it...I'm not even making this up.  There were 4 or 5 groups we passed where a couple of people were wearing all black or Dr. Martens or spikes.  They weren't causing problems but...it was an odd proportion of goths for a hiking trail.  Is this a thing in San Francisco?
author: Tim O.

description:
This little trail is well hidden on the west end of the city. It offers amazing overlook of the Pacific and optional paths that lead to the beach. Very easy to hike but also long enough to call it a workout. Gets busy on weekends but the view is so nice you wouldn't mind the crowd.

I went on this hike for the first time 8 months ago. I now live right next to it. Is this my favorite spot in the city? You betcha!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Land's End Trail is great if visitors only have short amount of time in SF.
You get to see everything here! Beaches, forestry trees, sutro baths, GG Bridge, and other scenic views!
The hike is not difficult--great for everyone. I even saw females with dresses and heels.
So yes, anything is possible :D haha
If you're up to walking miles and miles under the sun, and doing the stairs, it is possible to see the Sutro baths, caves, and labyrinth within few hours.
So much shade once you began on hiking, and it is also breezy.
There is also a paved sidewalk to get to Legion of Honor Museum if you guys want to check that out.
Huge parking space near Ocean Beach, near the gift shop and near the Cliff House restaurant.
author: Laramae E.

description:
I completely understand why everyone says this is the *must do* hike of San Francisco.  Gorgeous views (even on a foggy day).  I really enjoyed Rock Beach which is slightly off of the trail.  You have to walk pretty much down a mountain to get to it, but it was beautiful. 

I will definitely be back.  Dog friendly too which is a huge plus! :)
author: Alyx F.

description:
What a beautiful trail and just an all around beautiful place to spend your day! I was here last week on a more than gorgeous day with my boyfriend and we hiked around (I'm not sure which trail) but it led to the meditation ring of rocks as well as a little area where they balanced a bunch of rocks together. 

The hike is very zen and relaxing and not very tiring... If you choose the easier less inclined trail like we did. There are plenty of pit stops for you to take photos (and gorgeous ones at that!) and you get a pretty good, but far, view of the Golden Gate Bridge! Take your bike, take your family, and just enjoy what Lands End Trail for what it has to offer!
author: Anna T.

description: Who doesn't like an easy hiking trail with a view of the Golden Gate Bridge?!  'Nuff said.
author: Ally W.

description: The most beautiful, lovely and iconic SF hike. You see perfect views, funky trees, whales and sea life, cruise ships, all manner of people walking. My mom was inspired!
author: Andrew K.

description: Awesome hiking area! Sutro baths is near by and Rock beach. Lots of stairs leading down to rock beach, but the views are amazing!
author: Brandi E.

description:
Nice coastal trail with great views of the ocean and golden gate bridge. The Sutro Bath and Cliff House is right down there. Park at Sutro Bath and there is a gift shop with bathrooms. Come earlier to parking spots here.

I forgot how cold San Francisco is and when I looked around I was the only one wearing a short-sleeves t-shirt and shorts. Definitely bring your fleece with you when you go. 

We did the 1.1 mile Coastal Trail and went back the same trail. There were some stairs you can use to go down to the beach for some scenic views of the ocean. Easy hike but good enough with walking up and down stairs. Definitely a nice spot to bring your out-of-town friends/family to.
author: Claire W.

description:
One of my favorite places to go when I feel like hiking in SF. Came here twice and had different experiences and views (mostly the weather). I haven't hiked many places, but when my friends plan a trip to SF, we try to come here because it's very calming. It's not too difficult of a hike, but there's quite a lot of steps. Especially if you are planning to go to Mile's Rock Beach; it's all steps. The steps are covered in sand, so you have to be careful when going down to the beach and back up as you won't be able to tell the steps distinctly.  

I don't think I will get tired of this hike mainly because of the amazing views that you can see when the weather is cooperating of course. During the weekends it tends be very busy, but during the work week, there's less people, so you can enjoy nature more without as much noise disruptions. At the Lookout Center, there is a small cafe and the coffee is actually pretty good. In addition, there's a mini store to buy memorabilia items.
author: Carmen A.

description:
Awesome trail that everyone in the Bay Area should check out at least once. I like taking friends/family here because it's a great chance to get some fresh air, a little exercise (the hike is pretty flat and and easy walk, except for some steps), and awesome views of the bridge and ocean when the fog isn't heavy. 

There are a ton of reviews here that explain how to get to the Labyrinth and Sutro Baths--definitely worth checking them out! If you're going to the Labyrinth, you do have to get through a somewhat long set of stairs, so be prepared. Bring a jacket cause it does get windy!
author: Renu A.

description:
This is the perfect Golden Gate Bridge lookout. There are a couple of ways to get to the path and I believe all are beautiful. The views are unparalleled and you are looking over baker beach too. 

No need to read any reviews, this is a must when In the Bay Area.
author: Evan L.

description:
I mean, how can you give Mother Nature any less than 5 stars!? She puts on a magnificent show in the evening - be sure to stay here on your visit until sunset. Allow yourself two+ hours to experience the trails, check out the baths that are now in ruins by the shore. 

Take the trails for a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge and watch her light up when it gets dark - talk about breath taking!
author: Kim K.

description:
So we decided to head out to San Francisco for the weekend to get away from the HOT weather.  One of the cousins talked us into going on a hike in this area.  Since we went on a Sunday and got there early, there was plenty of parking.  Free parking available but there were signs posted at the store to "beware of car breakins".  So make sure you lock up your car and hide all valueables if you don't want any broken windows when you return.

You can pick up a map at the store so you can map out your walk.  There are several trails that one can take.  The weather is mild but as you hike / walk, you will warm up.  Beautiful view of the bay and at some parts you can get a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge.  There are many people casually strolling through and then you have those who are serious about exercise and running the trails.  It was a great experience and beautiful to see the scenery.  

Beware, there are stairs along the trail.  They are deceiving difficult.  Taking them down is not too bad, but going back up them is a totally different story.  So before you head out, make sure you are in shape and have at least been exercising a bit before attempting to walk the trails.  Various trails with different lengths are available.  Awesome find and will definitely be heading back to explore some more.
author: Mamie K.

description:
Lands End Trail is a trail that is a pretty walk/hike for any fitness level, and the views that you get as a reward are unique because you're looking at the Golden Gate from the West approach. Bring a jacket, there's wind and if you didn't know that San Francisco is a cool 60 degrees all the time, now you've been warned. 

On a nice day, there's going to be tourists and teenagers galore. On a foggy day, you'll probably find joggers are the only folks heading up here. It dumps you out around Ocean Beach if you follow the trail from the Richmond district. Great walk.
author: Alexander L.

description: Ponder what the Sutro Baths were, see the beautiful wind blown Cypress trees and cliffs, ocean, and shoreline - look up at the hawks soaring above you.  Read trail markers together - there are sunken ships below.  Walk up to the USS San Francisco memorial and reflect on where that ship had been and what it had gone through - it was not that long ago, really.  Keep walking along the trail and take it left down down down to Mile Rock Beach below - climb up huge rocks and watch the Pacific crash around you.  Look... there's the Golden Gate Bridge straight ahead.  When you're done walk back and be sure to stop into the Lookout Visitor Center at parking lot - it is sort of half museum and half cool SF gift shop and worth a few minutes of your time.  What a day.  So lucky and fortunate to live near this beautiful place - IN SF no less!  [Do this walk/hike during the week if you can - weekends can be quite busy.  The solace and views to yourself during the week and week day mornings are unforgettable.]
author: Dan B.

description: One of my most favorite places to hike in the city. Super easy and light hike, chilly of course, but the views, especially at sunset, are breathtaking. The parking lot is huge, never have a problem finding a spot. Just come. You won't be disappointed.
author: Vivian S.

description:
SF hiking and views do not get old. ANOTHER amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge? Um, yes please. Drive out along Lincoln or Fulton or through Golden Gate Park and then turn right and drive up Great Highway along Ocean Beach. If you've got the time, you can park at the Cliff House and walk down to check out the Sutro Baths and then up the hill to the Lands End trail, or you can follow the curve from Great Highway as it becomes Point Lobos Avenue, and look for the parking lot on the left after you pass this little restaurant called Louie's. Parking in the Lands End Trail lot isn't easy, but if you wait a little while, you'll eventually get a space. 

The visitor center is AWESOME, there's a cafe and one of the most interesting gift shops  They also have clean bathrooms that open around 9am. Perfect little SF spot for a different perspective of the ever gorgeous GGB.
author: Regina C.

description:
What is there NOT TO LOVE about the Lands End Trail?  It has absolutely breathtaking views of the Pacific Ocean and you can revel in the fresh sea air.  There is a great walking/jogging path with SCENERY.   I've jogged through here before, but it also makes for a nice leisurely walk with friends. There are places along the path to rest and take a break.  Restrooms are available at the guest/welcome center near the parking lot, but be warned, those are the only restrooms in sight for a while (I'm a practical girl).  

Watching the sunset here is AMAZING.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
We are so lucky to live in the City that offers a place like this to get away from the City is just the frosting on top.  

It's so close yet so far. 

What I mean by that phrase is it's conveniently located tucked in the North West part of the City and once you are on the trail, it will feel as if you're hundreds of miles away from the City. 

If you're just a beginner hiker, this is just the place for you. It's challenging enough with it's many ascending and descending stairs that it will give you a good workout, but it can be easily be attained by it's short 3 1/2 mile back and forth distance. You can start by the Sutro Bath Ruins as there are plenty of free parking that was recently renovated. Yes...FREE PARKING in the CITY. You know those words don't go hand in hand in the City. (And yes, I will always capitalize this City because it is THE CITY.)

You can also bring your dogs along for a good workout and you can have them off leash. Just make sure they are responsive to voice commands and watch out for the steep cliffs. Signs are posted everywhere warning everyone about the danger. 

In some sections of this trail, you will feel like you're somewhere in a rugged wilderness away from civilization, but you'll catch a glimpse of the Golden Gate Bridge on a corner bend and know that you are safely close to the general population. I don't know if that is a good thing or bad thing, but it's definitely a getaway place to get your minds off of things like work or whatever personal drama you might be dealing with. 

It's a place to relax or meditate. A place for a workout or gaze out. A place to enjoy Mother Nature without driving hundreds of miles to get there. If you're lucky, you might even catch a school of dolphins swimming near the coast or maybe even a whale or two. It's a place for photographers or wannabe photographers. A place to let your worries be carried away by the winds out in the ocean. 

And you can't beat the amazing view. You can't buy this view. (Unless you're a gazillionaire living on Sea Cliff.) You have an unobstructed view of the Pacific Ocean and then the magnificent Golden Gate Bridge out in the distance standing tall and majestic like a guardian of the Bay. 

It's a gem of a place and another jewel in the City.
author: John G.

description:
What a beautiful area to really gain some piece of mind in the crazy city life.

I have been here a handfull of times. Even took some pregnancy photos here with my husband. Even on a weekend it's never crowded and I can't understand why. Its well maintained and you get views that are mind blowing. I always feel like I'm starting into a painting. Like, how could this beauty be real kind of feeling. 

I took my daughter here recently and although I know she doesn't understand how nice it is yet, I am happy to show photos of her here one day. Who knows, we may not always be so lucky as to live 10 min away from here!

Note, that there are some benches near the parking lot and there is another viewing area after you go down about 50 stairs. There is a long trail you can hike or stroll down. I don't really recommend taking a stroller too far down the trail. If you have a baby backpack that would be best. 

I wish more people would come here to enjoy the beauty!
author: Andy S.

description:
There's A LOT to see here-from flowers, the sutra bathes, a cave, to the ocean itself...you probably won't get bored.

There's also both flat lands and hills that you can walk on. 

A good place to come for sights (we got to see a whale, and of course the Golden Gate Bridge), but also got a workout from the semi-long (1 hour) hike.
author: Christine H.

description:
Pretty little scenic hiking trail that leads up to the Legion of Honors Museum.  A tad narrow and limited guardrails, so be careful, but the view, walking or jogging, is breathtaking!

Ps- if you look down towards the cliffs, sometimes there are even sea lions
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! If I lived around the area I would run this trail everyday! 


MOST BEAUTIFUL VIEW! One of the best view from far away of the Golden Gate Bridge. Perfect weather and so many different spots to just hang out and chill. I took this trail all the way to Sutro bath. Pretty easy hike. Only difficult part may be the stairs. I love them! Great workout! 

I suggest you park at the Camino del mar parking lot then walk down until you hit Legion of Honor! Check that place also! 

Then head towards the lands end trail. Take the whole trail and it will lead you to the Sutro Bath! During the trail you should check out Labyrinth. You will see stairs leading towards there. 

Bring some snacks or small lunch to eat to just eat, sit, relax, and enjoy the view! 

Also best place to take some wedding pictures also!
author: Abigael M.

description: This is a beautiful trail with spectacular views! We weren't prepared for a hike so we didn't go too far, but we went far enough to be rewarded with a view of the golden gate bridge! Next time I'll be prepared so I can explore more of this trail!
author: Michele B.

description:
Are you kidding me?! This place is WAY over-hyped! it's always freezing, windy, and  foggy and those blasted fog horns sound like a tuba playing in the bathtub.

Even worse, people have fallen to their deaths here  - yes, to their DEATHS - and there are signs posted all around to remind you. those cliffs are truly dangerous.

Beware and tread this path with much caution! In fact, just stay away altogether for your own safety.
author: Art O.

description: We stopped over at this location on our day tour of San Francisco. The view is beautiful. The staff at the coffee shop were so nice.
author: Nadia G.

description:
The day after my interview at UC Berkeley, my friend and I went to the Lands End Trail for a morning run.  During our run, the fog rolled out and rays of sunlight pierced the branches of those gnarly, windswept trees that are so characteristic of San Francisco.  The effect was incredible, awe-inspiring, and unforgettable.

No words can describe how beautiful it was!

I knew after that moment that there was no question where I was meant to be for the next four years of my life thereafter.  If accepted to Berkeley, I would go.  BOOM.  

Lands End changes lives!  This is a great place to have a date (my parents went on a date here), propose to your girlfriend, go for a run, or decide on where you will go to school. :P
author: Brittany N.

description:
Great hike! I've been meaning to do the Land's End Trail for awhile because I always end up at Sutro Baths but have never gotten the chance. I finally decided to drop by this place on a Sunday afternoon and do the hike and it was awesome. You get some beautiful views of the GGB (classic SF). It's not even a real hike by East Coast standards haha it's super West Coast--the paths are super paved and have been walked on by a million people. You totally don't even need proper sneakers or anything. Just comfortable walking shoes are enough. 

It's a pretty short trail though--we were probably in and out after an hour. You can enter from the Sutro Baths side or the Sea Cliff side. Totally didn't realize that the Sea Cliff side was even an option. 

I mostly love this place because I think it's an awesome reminder of how cool SF is--it's crazy how you can just dive into full blown nature and trees for parts of it--you totally forget that the city is only a few minutes away by car... it's awesome. 

If you want a less touristy run, I definitely recommend coming in from the Sea Cliff side. The Sutro Baths side gets a little congested because that's where all the tourists are, but most people only make it to the fork that takes you down to the stone pebble maze. The maze is cool but definitely overrated. 

tldr; beautiful views of the ocean and GGB, super easy and light hiking trail and an easy way to be active while escaping the city life
author: Jasmine X.

description:
This place is seriously beautiful. I can't believe I never knew about it until now! 

I love how this trail has amazing views all along it.  If you don't want to walk too much, you can park at the Cliff House parking lot and just walk down the steps to see the Sutro Baths.  
The Sutro Baths are right next to the ocean, so it almost looks like beautiful ruins next to the sea.  Great place for picture taking or life talks haha.

If you decide you want to do some hiking, it splits into several paths that you can take, which are fun to explore.
The main coastal trail is very well-maintained (no litter and very few plants growing on the actual path), but there's plenty of plants and shrubs along it to keep the nature-y feel of it :) 
Along the trail, there are several "stops" with benches that give you amazinggg views of the golden gate bridge. Makes for great pictures :)

The famous Labyrinth is along this trail as well.  But beware, there are many many many flights of steep stairs that you have to go through before you can get to it.  
There's also a higher path that takes you directly above the Labyrinth so that you get a nice aerial view of it!

Love this trail and will definitely be back with my camera to get some even nicer shots!
author: Catherine G.

description: This was an absolutely beautiful experience at sunset. If you have the time, I would encourage anyone to go there to see the beach that it leads you to.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Great short hike with stunning views of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge. Very dog friendly. Some parts have long flights of stairs so be ready for a leg/glutes workout. 

After some yelping we found the Labyrinth (head down Mile Rock Lookout). Props to the highschool kid that rearranged the Labyrinth to ask out his/her prom date....I just wished he/she had the courtesy to return it to its original state.
author: Khanh T.

description: Such a beautiful trail and so much to see. The gift shop above the baths has some interesting tid bits as well!
author: Brooke W.

description:
It's probably best to check the weather before you head over here because a little fog can make the visibility disappointing. I got lucky with a clear sunny day and a beautiful view of the Golden Gate bridge! This is definitely a place I would take visitors to see the beauty of the bay area.

Check out the sutro baths first and then take a short little "hike" to get to the labyrinth area for a peaceful moment. It's a pretty short trail, maybe just a little over a mile at the most? so people of all ages can take part! Would come back here!
author: Hana S.

description:
This is an amazing place to go for locals and tourists alike! Even though the parking lot is quite small, there is a lot of street parking just one street down. 

The trail is very flat with only some stairs, and there are points of interest along the way. It's also located close to the sutro baths so you can check out that while you're there. There are various viewpoints along the trail that give an amazing view of the Golden Gate bridge (given no fog...always a gamble) and there is a fun little rock labyrinth on a small side path that you can walk to.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Another beautiful spot to visit. If you want a nice hike or a beautiful view of the ocean or Golden Gate bridge, this is the spot! Tucked away in the neighborhood of the very large houses, it is a wonderful spot to get some hiking in.

We didn't get in a hike, but we did see the views, totally worth it!
author: Tina S.

description:
This place is incredible! Sutter's Bath is a unique experience, lengthened by the personal experience brought to you by the museum/souvenir shop. Then there's the "thundering ocean" cave connected to the torn down bath house. 

Follow the forking trails to their multiple destinations, and you will find yourself discovering something different for every visit. Take the rock filled shores that require you to venture down a path of winding trees. Look out for that low hanging branch!

Another fork in the road leads you to the precipice of a cliff, pulsing with vegetation holding on for dear life from the ocean below. 

We were once fortunate to enter a clearing of low bushes to see the fog sweep past the Golden Gate Bridge for a picture that photographers would beg for. 

Interestingly enough, this was our one time visit, but it won't be our last!
author: Saemlinh I.

description:
"Best Urban Hiking Trail in SF" - this little gem is nestled between some stunning trees, views and killer cliffs.  I used to live at the foot of Eagles Point, so this became a daily ritual. About 5 years ago, I'd find myself being the only person hiking there during a weekday morning. Apparently the secret is out, especially after all the renovations and now it's full of day hikers. 

Check out the Labyrinth -- it's a steep hike but worth it. You'll need a guide book if you don't know where to find it, since it's off the trail.
author: Esther F.

description:
You can't give this anything less than 5 stars, I mean c'mon!

Went here Memorial Day.
I still consider myself new to SF because I haven't done much exploring as I should.

My friend showed me to this place & for Memorial Day it wasn't too packed. We found parking very easily :)

FYI, there are only port-o-potties. So if you can't stomach going into one of those, go before you get there. 

I honestly wasn't prepared to hike. I was wearing shorts, a crop top & some sandals.
But I still made it :)

I went passed the sign that said not to pass.
WARNING! Do not go pass that point if you are clumsy.
Sure I am clumsy but I had my friend with me who off-set that. lol.
There is no fence separating you from the cliff-edge. So please be very, very careful. Cannot stress that enough!

You have a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge & the sun was shining that day so it was absolutely BEAUTIFUL!

We sat & just soaked the view in.
author: Camille C.

description: One of my favorite trails in San Francisco. An hour is a good amount of time to spend to get in some good walking and breath taking pictures of the ocean, lush forest landscape, and Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Natasha K.

description: Easy walking trail with beautiful views. Came here around the holidays and saw families out with their kids and pets to enjoy the gorgeous scenery. We were able to make our way down to Mile Rock Beach as well. Would love to take on the Marin Headlands after this!
author: Jean Laureen L.

description:
I usually disdain going into the city. Parking sucks, it's congested, often dirty/smelly, and all around not my preferred environment for living or hanging out. It takes a lot for me to make the trek into the city from the south bay, and I'm happy to say that the Land's End Coastal Trail is worth it.

I'm a pretty nature-y person which is why I don't prefer urban environments, but the Golden Gate Bridge recreational and ocean beach area is quite pleasant. I took my dad to hike (or walk) the Land's End Coastal trail and it was the first time for both of us. It was a beautiful clear day and relatively warm for SF winter weather.

Parking understandably sucks on a Sunday late morning, but I was able to find some spots along Ocean beach, which is a short walk, maybe quarter mile, from the trail head. Plus, you get to pass by the Sutro Baths on the way which is also interesting.

The trail itself is easy and somewhat populated, but as others have mentioned, provides great clear views of the Golden Gate Bridge. It may be touristy, but it is beautiful. There are also a number of beach access points along the trail where it's a little less crowded (since they're off the main trail). The USS memorial I think is also worth stopping to take a look.

The coastal trail is 1.7 miles one way, so it can easily be completed in a morning at a leisurely pace with pauses to take photos. I think it would also make for a nice, short round trip trail run as it's mostly a dirt path and has a little bit of up and down terrain.

Bring a light wind breaking jacket that is breathable. Temperature can vary a lot depending on how far you are from the coast and whether you're in the shade. I found myself taking off/putting on my light jacket a couple times. Sunscreen is also probably a good idea.

All in all, for someone who hates making the trip into the city, I'm pretty happy I went.
author: Hain-Lee H.

description:
1.An easy walk/hike with beautiful views of the ocean, Sutro Bath & Golden Gate.
 
2. Also, it's considered as a leisure walk.

3. Pets friendly
author: Farrah G.

description:
I know I'm not in the best shape, but I wouldn't really say this trail is very easy.  From China Beach and Eagles Point to Sutro Baths and Cliff House is about 1.3 miles.  Then times that by two for a round trip.  Then add in all the extra hidden paths, which there are many, and this hike can be almost 4 miles.  Only a small section on the Baths/Cliff side is paved, and a bit in the beginning at Eagles Point is kinda paved.  The rest is a dirt trail, many places uneven, and lots and lots of wooden stairs.

We parked at the Eagles point entrance on the street.  Plenty of parking.  We started out about 2pm and it was really foggy.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lands-end-trail-san-francisco?select=9kflxrz00Kh_iEtjiVGu9Q#7nsb2V7dTT7nJhImC50IIw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lands-end-trail-san-francisco?select=9kflxrz00Kh_iEtjiVGu9Q#Bjb4h6xHbTx_w3o0-AlSQg  It's pretty cold, so if you're not running this trail I would suggest at least a light sweater or jacket.

By the time we got to the Baths and went down the steep slop to check out the cave, the sun started coming out.  On the way back with the sun it was really hot.  The views on the way back are gorgeous with the Gold Gate in the background. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lands-end-trail-san-francisco?select=9kflxrz00Kh_iEtjiVGu9Q#eEjCOwklKFV3uEutGzBsGg

The only thing about this trail was all the hidden places, which could be looked at as both a plus and minus.  A plus bc it's cool to feel like you're some place that's secret, but minus bc a lot of those secret trails you can see trash and litter from either transients, disrespectful litterers or people wanting to get high.  I wondered many times during the hike how many people go there to get high and wander off and fall off the cliffs and die.  There are many signs posted to not go past certain points but I saw many people well past the signs.  Also there was a lot of noticeable graffiti, and no restrooms that I was aware of on the Eagles Point side of the park.
author: Priscilla Y.

description: Beautiful trail but can be a bit crowded. The path takes you to all the coveted photo spots and views of the city and bridge. Plenty of parking and easily accessible by both public transportation and car. Great place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city while still being in the city!
author: Joan S.

description: This is such a beautiful hike with a view of the ocean and the golden gate bridge. The walk round trip was about 3.3 miles by starting the walk from Sutro Baths all the way to El Camino Del Mar including the labyrinth. To get to the labyrinth, midway of your hike... you'll have to go towards the stairs going down on the left. There are no signs directing you there but on the map, it's where "land's end point" is. It's truly a hidden gem and making the stop here is a must! Overall, pretty easy trail mainly flats with a good set amount of stairs. Had a good workout on my thighs. Follow the Coastal Trail sign and you're in for some beautiful views. Check out Mile Rock Beach while you're at the labyrinth... Nice area for a break.
author: Nancy N.

description: Very scenic and beautiful.  Best hiking trail in SF hands down.  It's about a 4 mile hike to the end and back.  Went with my husband after having a nice breakfast at Louis' near the cliff house.  It's a great hike for a romantic stroll or scenic workouts.  Dog friendly as well.
author: Rosie M.

description: Outstanding views of the Golden Gate and Pacific Ocean on the way to Eagle's Point.  Great morning activity to get your weekend or work week started off the right way!  A little crowded on the main trail but ton's of secluded watch areas if you have just the slightest sense of adventure.
author: Taylor K.

description: This trail is beyond amazing!!! We ended up hiking from the end of the trail (labyrinth location) and then we headed towards the beginning of the trail and enjoyed a nice hike to bakers beach and towards the GGB. The neighborhood and the houses here is so pretty! It definitely didn't have that usual busy SF vibe (which is something new to me considering I'm in SF) lol.. But I loved this hike, definitely one of my favorite one in the Bay Area.
author: melanie l.

description: Too nice to be true. This is a nice place with great ocean great view. Love it so much. A little bit crowded with parking during the weekends. Sssssssooooooo good.
author: Kkjk C.

description: I've gone on quite a few hikes but this is still my favorite. The fresh air, the view, the trail- nothing beats it. From start to finish, it is absolutely breath taking! Def plan to do it again soon!
author: Hena A.

description: Came here on the month of August and i must say what a wonder hike and amazing view. I recommend to arrive early and bring a sweater. We got here about 10am and there was plenty of parking as we were leaving close to 1pm the lot was full and everyone was arriving. If you are planning on doing a 4 mile walk bring water and snacks, great places to sit and enjoy a cool ocean breeze. Hope this helped.
author: Maura A.

description: Love this hike. Perfect for all ages and all levels of hiking abilities. Beautiful scenery the entire way. If you do the whole thing it's around 4.5miles I believe to the end and back.  You can even grab a coffee at the coffee shop. :)
author: Jami E.

description:
I love Lands End! Great location to capture BEAUTIFUL views of the Pacific Ocean, Golden Gate Bridge, and nature. Relatively easy hiking though the steps / stairs when heading back up from Mile Rock Beach go on and on and on... Hence, productive cardiovascular exercise! 

Not too far from the ruins of the Sutro Baths, a cool cave, Legion of Honor, and Ocean Beach. The labyrinth is neat, too = a must-see; I've read that it was compiled in 2004 and intended for meditation & relaxation. Anyhow, check it out! 

Grab a FREE map from the Lands End Lookout (visitor center) - which also has a cafe and clean restrooms. Ample parking (several lots) in the area. Though you may have to walk a bit - dependent on where you find parking. 

To reiterate, I love this area of the city & plan to revisit again and again and again... 

Tips...
--Hope for clear weather so as to catch amazing views! 
--Dress in layers! It can get chilly & windy! 
--Wear comfy shoes (not sandals)
--Bring along the camera :)
author: Pina U.

description:
If you live in the Bay, you should check this place out at least once. The views here are absolutely gorgeous and so relaxing. The trails here is more of a walk instead of a hike (although there is a small section of stairs for those of you that has an issue with them).

There is a medium sized parking lot here but I can't comment on how it is during the weekend. There are some other lots down the street for some beach areas though. The bathrooms and visitor center are actually pretty nice for a public park. 

There's only one downside that I've noticed so far. The area around Sutro Baths is not the cleanest; there's obviously a lot of bird poop but also trash from inconsiderate visitors. One flip flop, a beer bottle, and an empty Cheetos bag were only a few of the things I saw on my last visit. :( Please remember to pick up after yourselves.
author: Cammie W.

description:
So gorgeous!!!!


Walk all the way down and you'll get to China Beach (another great destination). 

There are a lot of steps and it gets muddy after it rains (slippery), so wear appropriate shoes when walking on this trail.
author: Diya L.

description:
Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful!
Came on Saturday around 9:15am and there was so much parking!  Started at Sutro Baths and walked to Eagle's Point.

I can't wait to come back and bring my friends here.

The next time I come, I'd probably go straight to Eagle's Point, check out Miles Beach on the way to Eagle's Point, come back, and THEN save Sutro Baths for last.  The cave was fantastic and it was just gorgeous all around.

BUT my favorite was definitely the Sutro Baths. That's why I'd save that for last! :o)
author: Jun K.

description:
One look at Lands End, and you'll know exactly how it got its title.

Sure, the steep precipice and its location at the end of town should make things obvious, but it's the atmosphere that drives this point home. I went this Labor Day weekend on a warm summer day, and the weather got cloudier and cloudier until the whole area was enveloped in it. The skyscrapers and noise of the city were traded for trees and the sounds of waves crashing on the ocean.

The atmosphere here is incredible, and the multiple walking trails make things even better. Want to check out that cave? How about the Sutro baths? Maybe you'd rather take this path to Eagle's Landing? The choice is yours.

Definitely worth a visit at least once...if you want to get away.
author: Casey S.

description: So relaxing and you could literally spend forever here. The stairs to the bottom and to the maze were worth it!
author: Ashley S.

description:
How are some people giving 4 Star reviews? Lands End is an amazing easy-to-moderate hike through the wooded area near both Ocean Beach and the Golden Gate. After my old boyfriend brought me for the first time for a picnic in the hills, I told my friends about it and brought some of them out there. Also you can walk down to the Cliff House after for Bloody Mary's and appetizers, if you're into that kind of thing.

The parking lot is free with porto potties if you gotta go. You then walk down the steps to the main trail where you can see a full view of the Golden Gate Bridge and some awesome, tasteful graffiti. Keep on going and you'll hit a crossroads where you can go up and see the bridge again and see the rock labyrinth, or go down and take the wooden stairs to the *not so* secret beach. 

This portion of the beach is awesome because not a ton of people go down there so it's kind of private, the Sutro Bath remains are stacked up for you to climb on, ladybug mating season is a real treat as the tiles get covered in tons of the little red bugs, lots of cool graffiti, big climbable rocks, and tidepools during low tide. I think it's the perfect place for a picnic as it doesn't get too windy since it's surrounded by hills. Beautiful spot in SF to get outdoors and give your legs a stretch.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Amazing views and lack of crowds.  What more could you want?  Unlimited and free parking?  Check and check.  This trail is enough to make me want to move to the Richmond just so I can run or hike this everyday.  The views of the water and bridge never get old.  I only wish there were more variations of steepness.

Whether you're a tourist or a local, there's no doubt you'll find at least one thing to love about this trail.

Note: There are multiple entrances to the trail.  Each entrance has ample parking and the trail is even appropriate for beginners, kids, and senior citizens!  Go visit now!
author: Michele L.

description:
Seriously. I really like this trail!

I finally dragged the boy out with me to hunt down the Labyrinth and we brought his puppy/ dog. Shes medium sized and we were worried that we would have to carry her after a bit but she was able to finish the trail.

To get to the Labyrinth. Park at the end of El Camino Del Mar, a little past Cliff House. When I got there around... 11:30AM on a Sunday it wasn't that crowded and we found a spot easily.

You head down the long stairs towards the water and turn right. (if you're facing away from the stairs) keep going down until you see stairs down on the left. take the stairs, and when it splits off into a sketchy looking path and more stairs. Take the sketchy dirt/ tree-filled path. Keep going and you'll see a cliff-type ending, kind of like the lion king where they hold up Simba. Walk to the edge of that. Look down. TA-DAHH. the labyrinth. I didn't walk all the way to the end so the cliff was blocking it and I kept looking around for it. (hella dumb) loll. 

If you miss the dirt path, the stairs go down to the beach and you can see the people on the high cliff on the right and that's where the labyrinth is.

We walked back up to the main trail and kept going to the left from where we split to go down the stairs to the beach. You go up these intense stairs and keep going down the trail, eventually you will hit Baker Beach.

Overall, a really fun hike with a lot of dogs. Can't wait to come again and do the Sutro route.
author: Rachel C.

description:
What can I say, this place is definitely all it is cracked up to be. Came here as a first time Hiker and got the full experience. We veered off the trail a bit and dropped down to the shore line, walked along the sand barefoot, then found a staircase and went back up to the main trail. Great Hamstring workout with all those stairs. Take the bike trail route for an easy way back to the parking lot. The views are gorgeous, makes you want to take a zillion pictures but they wont do any justice. I enjoyed being in the bay air and away from life's schedule. 
I recommend this place to rookie hikers everywhere.... even though there are signs posted everywhere that appear to say no hiking. Picture of man with back pack and stick with a line crossed through it... If they are serious about the whole no hiking thing they should probably think of remodeling the side of the mountain ;-)
author: Sharen C.

description: By far one of my favorite scenic walks/hikes out there (and I've done many)! This is an extremely easy hike with very minimal shifts in terrain, however, there are a good amount of stairs. I went for sunset, which seemed like a popular time (but not too overcrowded). I would recommend starting the walk from the baths and ending at the park- I went the opposite direction and had to keep looking back for the view of the GG bridge. It's beautiful and serene. You really forget that you're in a city.
author: Melanie M.

description: It was a great little hike and not too hot because there was a breeze. The scenery was great. I would go back again.
author: Okapi C.

description:
What: 
- Hiking Trail
- USS San Francisco Memorial
- Lands End Point
- Labyrinth at Lands End
- Mile Rock Beach
- Mile Rock Lighthouse
- Eagle's Point
- Scenic viewpoint of Marin County, Point Bonita lighthouse, Golden Gate Bridge, China Beach
- Birds - Pelicans, Sea gulls

More Info:
- Free parking and free admission
- Visitor center at the parking lot
- Restrooms at the visitor center
- Two parking lots, each about 0.2 miles away from the other
- Bring flash lights if you decide to stay back until sunset
- Bring a jacket, it gets cold close to the ocean

Lands End - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#4cQPe4hmgpX7EMbYQTuPOw

Coastal Trail

Length: ~3 miles; Time: 4 hours; Difficulty: Easy

Hiking the Lands End has been on our to-do list for a very long time. As soon as we found a warm and sunny weather forecast that week-end, we grabbed the opportunity. The Coastal Trail in the Lands End begins in the parking lot next to the Visitor Center. We parked our car here and merrily took the trail that soon connected with the second parking lot where the USS San Francisco Memorial is located. The memorial was built to honor those who fought on the navy cruise ship in the Battle of Guadalcanal in World War II.
