After skimming through the placards that offer profound information about the battle, we continued on the picturesque Coastal Trail that took us along the Pacific Coast, offering sweeping views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Marin County, Hawk Hill, Point Bonita Lighthouse, Mile Rock Beach, Mile Rock Lighthouse.

View of Golden Gate Bridge from a lookout in the trail - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#sm5MXzLxEms8CMcU5ioMTw

Located in the rockiest north western corner of San Francisco, the Lands End is known for its history of landslides that took away the lives of many people. The wild ocean currents, treacherous rocks and foggy weather have also caused 300+ ship wrecks. Although we could not spot, it is said that the remains of three ships can be seen from the trail during low tides.

Following a devastating shipwreck in 1901, the Mile Rock lighthouse was constructed in 1906 in the ocean to warn ships of the perilous rocks. The lighthouse was later dismantled and converted to a helicopter pad. This is the first time I saw a lighthouse constructed in the ocean itself!

Mile Rock Lighthouse in the middle of the ocean - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#aE1i7sjIx0WEbByZYIg6bQ

We reached a point in the trail where a detour took us down through a long fleet of stairs to the Lands End and the Mile Rock Beach. The Lands End has a labyrinth, which was originally created by Eduardo Aguilera in 2004 for meditation purposes. It was a lot of fun walking in the maze. Another fleet of stairs took us to the Mile Rock Beach. It is hard to miss out the sea gulls and pelicans flying over the ocean.

Trail to Lands End and Mile Rock Beach - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#pGu3vsT_qTW7VqXfj25O9w

Labyrinth at Lands End - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#_9rJSJaguKIP4mzm9Gb5MQ

We continued on to the Coast Trail and reached the Eagle Point, which is the entrance to the San Francisco harbor. An amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge and China Beach to the right awaited us here. This marks the end of the Coastal Trail and we returned to the parking lot via the same route.

Eagle Point; Overlooking China Beach and Golden Gate Bridge - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#T2Sp9QDySyQWasso7cbHZg

However, as it was time for sunset, we stopped by the Mile Point Beach to capture a breathtaking view of the sunset. The strong ocean currents, huge rocks, Marin County on the other side of the Pacific, Point Bonita Lighthouse in the Marin headlands and Golden Gate Bridge to the right offer dramatic views that any photographer would fall in love with.

Sunset at Mile Rock Beach - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?userid=nx7hGb1sjJFtmdNh5RHYQg#Vm2l7UXKbliTRWYnhV0QVw
author: Anu M.

description:
Truly a beautiful side trail that allows you to view the sunset, a labyrinth made of rocks, foamy beach coves and lastly but most certainly not least the Golden Gate Bridge. 

I take all the tourists and visitors here and they truly all love it. It is a lovely trail and a great serene spot to take in nature in the busy metropolis of SF. I think it's dog friendly too (at least people bring their dogs here anyway). No this isn't a true "hike" if you consider hikes to be something that requires hiking boots, a walking stick, snacks and a hydration backpack. It is quite casual and is something you can definitely do in jeans and flats. 

This is truly one of my favorite spots in the city if not THE favorite spot. I have such a strong affinity for both city life and for nature so places like Lands End are great compromises of both components. My memories here linger with me when I am in Denver and am missing home. It's definitely one of those spots I can just sit at and stare out into the water and be at complete peace and happiness with myself. I wish I could capsulate the view, the sound and the feelings that were experienced here.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Living in San Francisco, the beautiful thing about being in this crowded, metropolitan of a hub, there's absolutely no compromise when it comes to being spoiled with naturesque views.

At Lands End Trail, when you walk along its path, the views of the Pacific coast are utterly breathtaking. 

As the powerful waves press alongside the cliff, the roar of the ocean can be heard from miles away. The sunsets mirror a sense of deep thought and romanticism, as if it were perfectly painted by the hands of Michelangelo Buonarroti, himself. 

The quiet trails lead to a secluded labyrinth and lays a perfect canvas for clearing one's mind and for open eyed meditations. 

What's nice is that you can get an adequate workout, yet can also appreciate the beauty that surrounds you. 

So if you ever need to step away from the fast paced, quick moving, traffic jammed, electrifying pulse of the city, the nice thing is that you also get the gentle, quiet, awe enveloping, and tranquil quality of its split personality. 

A definite go to!
author: Ann S.

description:
I thought I wrote a review on this already, but I guess I forgot!
But... in 4 words.. THIS PLACE IS BEAUTIFREAKINAMAZING!

I recommend going about an hour+half before sunset on a nice clear day. 

The trail is nice. Not difficult to walk at all. But even before the trail, you get some really great views of the water. The trail itself is quite beautiful. (definitely take a camera) The trail is longer than you expect, so take your time to walk down the whole thing. At one point, we reached an area that was closed off, but you could easily just duck under the rope. I recommend you do it. You get some pretty great views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Just be careful!

My favorite part, however, was the sunset, on the beach. there is one path that branches off the main path. Take these stairs down off the path and it will take you closer to the water. On one side, you can see this cool design made of small rocks (like something alien-ish), and if you keep going down to the beach, you can get up right to the water. The sun will set from that side, and the views were breathtaking. I felt like I was in a postcard or a photoshoot. I wish i had a DSLR but my galaxy s5 was still really good at capturing the awesome views of the sunset over the rocks, beach, and water.   ... words cannot describe...

I think this was one of the prettiest trails and views I saw in SF. 
I would love to go back and just sit on that beach watching the sunset. 
i also heard there are some kind of "baths" that you can go see near the parking lot before the trail, but I didn't get a chance to see that. 

So yes, DEFINITELY recommend this trail for those who love beautiful views.
author: Yong K.

description: Quick trail not to hard. Made it all the way to other end with friends. Enjoyed the labyrinth and there was also a great view of the golden gate bridge!
author: Joseph T.

description: I finally did the trail! Last time I only had time to just pop into the Sutro Bath but didnt get to hike or anything. First off, parking here is difficult. You will be circling for days as I did around Saturday at 1ish. So this trail is not tough at all. This is touristy so you will see those Asian buses and bunch of cameras. You dont need to wear workout gear for this but having flip flops would be cool if you want to chill by the beach. So if you want to see the labyrinth which is that circular maze that you see everyone and their mom pose at, then it is 1.5 miles to get there, 3 round trip. While getting there, you can wander to the beach and climb rocks and go through the trees and what not. It is a fun place to just explore and spend your day after a classic brunch in SF. I spent a good 3-3.5 hours just exploring and taking photos. You can get a view of the Golden Gate bridge and I think you can hike further if you please. Just to warn you, SF may be cooler especially near the Pacific but bring sunblock if it is sunny! Jeez I burned for dayzzzz
author: Amy H.

description:
We parked our car at Lands End Lookout Visitor Center (it was difficult to find a parking spot and we had to go around couple of times) and walked till Eagles Point. Its about 3.2 miles round trip and moderately strenuous with lot of stairs to climb and descend. But the views are totally worth it.
This is now my favorite spot in San Francisco.
author: Hema G.

description:
Beautiful.  A hike that is simple with a lovely view and perfect weather, either sunny or overcast.  I say this because the trail is so close to the coast, you can feet the ocean wind and if it's over cast, the place looks majestically.  

Pretty easy.  The only problem that I had was the stair length being inconsistent.   Short people, you know what I'm talkin about, the two step all the way up or down. If there was any suggestion that I'd give, it would be to not wear heals!  haha, Saw this poor woman with heals and her baby strapped to her chest... I can only imagine the pain she was in!

We started at the beginning of Land's End.   We headed down the trail which was about 1.7 miles and then ventured off to Suetro's Baths and then walked back with a stop at the labyrinth.  I'd say around 4 mile hike or somewhere around there.  It was fun and enjoyable!
author: Lea M.

description:
There is everything in this hike. Views, ability to go on trail runs, take your kid on a stroller or just look at the views and get lost in another world all together!
Parking is tricky but if you could park at the beach and walk up ... It's worth every bit of your time! We have seen dolphins seals and whales while hiking in this area. Don't miss hiking the whole 6 miles or stop at eagle point... Or even going to the beach. This is a must do fun thing in Bay Area
author: Aj J.

description:
Its a great hike within the borders of San Francisco, but like everyone else is pointing out wear the right shoes, and clothes,

Some of the trails can get steep, and because of the fog even without rain the terrain can get a little muddy. 

Several easy ways to get in here though I tend to prefer starting from the Parking Lot next to the Sutro Baths , but you might also want to consider using El Camino Del Mar which is right behind the VA & Legion of Honor ,
author: Joseph A.

description:
For my vacation in SF, I did some researching on place to hike and I'm so happy I found this place.

It's an easy few mile hike long the water with amazing views. As you get get a few miles in, you'll start seeing the Golden Gate which adds to the experience.

I was there in July and I wore light pants and a light weight long sleeve shirt. I almost went into the store to buy a jacket, but I couldn't justify the money.

Once I my heart rate started to go up, being cold was no longer an issue.

If you haven't been yet, check this place you. You'll be happy you did!
author: Nichole K.

description: Lands end is definitely a great trail to walk through. Although it's short, it makes for a light stroll. We went after the rainstorm, so it was muddy, but no biggie. Be ready to go off on different detours because that's where all the sights come alive. Like go down some stairs and check out the rocky formations that were made from aliens. After halfway, if you really want to finish the trail all the power to you. But after that, it gets boring. The best part is the rocky formation near the middle.
author: Bryan W.

description: Gorgeous walk along the coast where you can see beautiful wild flowers, plants, wildlife, huge waves, and cute dogs. Definitely recommend it! It's beautiful when it's sunny, but also very fun when it's foggy or rainy.
author: Luki S.

description: Came here on Easter Sunday. Plenty of people hiking on a super windy day. The hike was relatively easy until you try to get to the labyrinth. You have to be careful hiking/climbing down the rocks. Still doable but make sure to wear comfy shoes. Finally seeing the labyrinth and the view of the ocean and the Golden Gate Bridge was definitely worth it!
author: Kathleen P.

description: This was the most beautiful part of San Francisco.  There's a ship wreck in the area and is kinda cool to be able to be able to see a party of history there.  There's also an area that nicely frames the golden gate bridge and makes for a nice picture.  The hike is a great workout too.  There's a beach at the bottom but it's not for swimming.  Still one of the most beautiful places in the US
author: Fazle H.

description:
Gorgeous walking trail along the coast with breathtaking views of the Pacific! You can park either by the golf course where I'm pretty sure Google Maps will take you, or in the parking lot for Sutro Baths. Great for running, dogs, kids...everybody. 

Don't miss the turnoff for the labyrinth.

Also, this is not a hike. Most people say "hike Land's End," but they should say "walk Land's End." I'm from Utah and when we hike, we hike mountains. So no need to wear tennis shoes or workout clothes (unless you're running, of course).
author: Ashley E.

description: Must stop and visit this place. The views are amazing. I have an 8 and 10 year old and they loved the short hikes, the cave, and the views! I highly recommend. We got there at 9:30am on Friday and we were the only ones there. It was a great day to start our day. Then we headed to Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center. Both have plenty of parking and are FREE!
author: Lexie B.

description:
Gorgeous trail that I always take my friends to when they're visiting form out of town. 

There is plenty to do, multiple trails and many beautiful sites to see!

You can see the golden gate bridge if you go to the right (facing the ocean).  There is also a "graffiti graveyard"  if you search hard enough and are willing to hike a little bit down the cliffs! There's also the Lands End Labryth that is quite beautiful.
author: Kristin C.

description: Did this hike again.  Easy parking in multiple lots.  And a pretty easy trail to walk/hike although there's a couple sets of stairs.  Nice views of the GG Bridge from so many places.  Go enjoy tranquility and beauty in San Francisco.
author: Tim L.

description:
Beautiful walk! I'd call this more of a "walk" than a "hike." It was relatively easy. Nice walk with the view of the golden gate bridge and the bay:

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yniMfk_yS1sk9dxPLDVchg?select=ALmxhnBnmNzQd12Q2k0X3w#NhTH3DEdc82mxF2ZpCholw

I highly recommend doing this while you're in SF. I've lived here for 23 years and can't believe I just found out about this now! I'm glad I got to walk it though :) I'd walk it every so often if I didn't live so far. 

Enjoy the scenery, nature, and weather while on this beautiful walk in the infamous San Francisco :)
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Easy, low impact hike for those who are looking to reap the benefits of a gorgeous view without having to put in too much work.

They are known for the Sutra Baths (now ruins).  You can actually walk out to the structure remains, but could be scary with high tide.  Saw some folks who came here to fish.

The trail itself is pretty short and they blocked off the end of the trail that loops around--don't know when construction is going to end, but it's pretty unsatisfying to get to the construction fences and the trail just ends there.  Nothing to do, but turn back around and retrace your steps back to the beginning.  Once it's fixed and I hike the whole train, I'm sure I'll be giving this place 5 stars.

Further west is Baker Beach and a restaurant and souvenir shop.  Passed on it, but seems popular.

Free parking is a plus, but you gotta be vigilant and fight for it.  Upper parking deck is for permit-only cars (which houses cars that do not have a permit from what I saw).

Lots of shade, but can get hot if you're getting hit by the direct sunlight.  Plenty of pit stops for those photo ops.  Very nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge and Marin County.  Swing by in the morning for the best sights.
author: Fanny H.

description:
none of the reviews are true. DONT come here. they're lying, it's not majestic. the views are ugly. hike is uglier. it's not fun. bad for tourists, worse for locals.







(jk..best coastal hike i've been on)
author: Asmita J.

description:
The best of the best. Perfect for families, working out, people of all ages and pets. The views are spectacular and it's not that crowded. This is great for all hikers and even people who haven't been hiking before. 

The facilities (bathroom, information center) are new and clean. Free parking too!  Absolutely love Lands End and try to go every other weekend. 

Definitely wear sunscreen, go down to Mile Rock Beach and up to the Labyrinth. There's also a cave if you follow signs down to the Sutro Baths, which is pretty cool.  There are no regrets to coming here -- SF in all it's glory.
author: Louise Z.

description:
4/5 stars
Yay!! Another yelpmark removed!

I've been wanting to go here for years! The trail is fairly flat and pretty easy with the exception of the stairs (about 60 steps); A great trail to stroll and catch up with friends. The scenic view is amazing--great view of the GG bridge from afar. 

A little hidden, but we found the famous labyrinth. We initially missed it, and went to the end of Lands End, and walked back to find the maze. If you're walking away from Sutro Bath (the parking lot) towards the GG Bridge, follow the Mile Rock Beach trail on the left, and you will find the Labyrinth maze. I was amazed how small the labyrinth was in person; I guess in pictures, the maze appears bigger. 

Great perk--Free parking on Sundays! I am not sure if there are fees on other days. I didn't pay attention.
author: Jen H.

description:
It's easy to forget that you are so close to a bustling city when you are surrounded by so much natural beauty and quiet! My boyfriend and I ventured to and along the Lands End Trail on our recent visit to California, following a morning walk through the Golden Gate Park (We joined the trail near the Sutro Baths -- note that if you are would rather walk downhill more than uphill, you may want to enter the park on the Camino del Mar side).  The coast was somewhat foggy, so the spectacular views of the Golden Gate Bridge that other reviewers have raved over weren't as apparent, though we didn't mind since the park itself offered so much to see. Just when we thought we'd seen an incomparably wonderful view, an even more spectacular scene was only a few steps ahead! 

We're relatively fit (we already walked ten miles by the time we arrived...), so the trail didn't pose any difficulties to us, but judging by the number of children and older folks that seemed to easily navigate the trail, it doesn't seem as though it's very strenuous. It was definitely a highlight of our California trip, and we enthusiastically recommend it to anyone in the area!
author: Katelyn R.

description:
Great walk, stunning views.

I have no idea why people below are saying the labyrinth is gone - we were there on Christmas Day (2013) and it was in place. Perfect for a little contemplation or entertainment above the Golden Gate.

Only downside: some parts of it feel a little too close to steep edges with young kids. Still, great with kids once they're older than 5 or 6.
author: Paul H.

description: I gotta say that this is a hidden gem and is now my favorite go to hiking destination in San Francisco.  If you park at the Overlook center during the week most likely you will get a parking spot and not to many people walking around verses on the weekends I hear.  Lots of trails and beautiful coastal views to be seen.  Be sure to go to the gift shop for a FREE map of the place.  Couple of the sites to see are: Sutro bath ruins, USS San Francisco Memorial, Mile Rock overlook and off the path are China Beach and Baker's Beach.  You will see beautiful views of the Golden Gate bridge along the path.  Great place for photography which we saw plenty people doing.
author: Christine G.

description:
My bf and I have been wanting to go to this place for a long time. It's just pretty much out of our way b/c we don't even live in the city and when we do go to the city, we go to mainly eat at the many sf extravaganza.

This time I made a plan and stuck with it. Tried to come early but was stuck in traffic forever and finally got here around 10. Was behind schedule but fine. We were lucky it was such a nice day! The sun was out, a lil cool breeze (I appreciated later after the sweat). 
We got lost for a bit, stopping at the legion of honor until we found the parking area that leads right to the trail.

I love the cool steps. Definitely better than hiking on uneven pavements. I love how the trees/ plants grew and surrounds the trail so it made me feel like I was in Alice in wonderland. I had no idea where we were going and didn't really use the map. Eventually got a nice view of golden gate. And then onwards towards Sutro Bath. That was an odd place. I feel like I was part of game of thrones ruins. 
We found this little off-the-trail hidden path and decided to scope it. I think we found some hobo's den down that path. I'm hindsight that could've been a bad idea. Idk.  I just wanted to get closer to the beach. Some parts of it were definitely quite nice and lord of the rings feel to it =]

Walking up the stairs/ hills was the real exercise. I love it tho cuz you can do lunges! 

Finally got back to the lands end trail. That was awesome! Felt like I was on top of the world (sorta). It was fun even tho I was afraid I was gonna fall off the cliff and die. If only I lived in the city, I'd be here more often.
author: Katie T.

description: I wish I had known about this place sooner. I will be returning. The trail is easy enough for beginners, but was still a good work out. I appreciate the visitors center and restrooms were clean. There were plenty of places to go eat after my hike.
author: karen s.

description: Beautiful stroll. This place has stairs as well so you can have a casual walk with a loved one or get a really good workout on. You have to climb a bit to get a really good view. Nice fun hike. I'll be back for sure
author: Lauren Ashley G.

description:
This is definitely a lovely trail. It's a pretty easy stroll, majority of it being stairs. That being said, going down is no sweat, but going up can be a little slower. You don't need special hiking shoes. I did it in converse and I saw people in open toed sandals. 

There are several paths you can choose from. The more well known ones are the ones that end with the "maze" (see pics attached) and Sutro Baths, which I did not go to. Amaaaazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge and stunning views. Beautiful plants along the way. So go! Stop and smell da nature we forget we have!
author: Annie T.

description:
Lands end is an easy to intermediate hike depending on your level of fitness. Most should be able to do it. Although it is not as steep as other trails, there are a ton of stairs. Wear comfortable shoes that you don't mind getting dirty/dusty. 

I would recommend to bring a light jacket or wear a sweater as it tends to get windy. It appears to be a popular trail for dogs. There are also a few benches on the way, but you really won't feel much of a need to stop. 1.5 miles to the end and 3 roundtrip isn't bad. 

On the way you should look for the sign to the mile rock beach. It will take you down even more stairs, but the beach and rock labyrinth will be worth it. 

I spotted a few folks running, and based off the trail I'd say it's totally doable. I may just attempt to jog this soon. 

You'll have plenty of places you'll want to snap shots of the golden gate bridge. All in all, a fun, yet still physically rewarding way to spend a beautiful day in San Francisco.
author: Trish S.

description:
Great hike, especially the steps. MY GOSH! Made me feel so out of shape. 

Also, beautiful view. What's not to like?
author: Audrey N.

description: We have been to SF many times but this is our first visit to Lands End.  What a great place - you can get to various vista points and see the GG Bridge.  The trail itself is not that long or difficult at all.  Beautiful views, highly recommended!
author: Shawn T.

description: If you're looking for a easy casual hike, this is perfect. You get to see the beautiful ocean side and on some areas the Golden Gate Bridge. Absolutely stunning, and the breeze is fantastic. You see a lot of local there walking or doing their run. I would totally come back on this trail.
author: Sally L.

description:
Note: The Land's End Labyrinth no longer exists.  I have no idea when it got destroyed, but there's a sad little mock-up that someone tried to make in its stead and sadly no more than 10 feet away, someone had made a giant awkward cartoonish looking p*nis next to it.  I was so heartbroken as I've been hoping to see the labyrinth after all these years.  Imagine my disappointment when I came around the overlooking rock to find...an awful mockup and a giant p*nis.  (I went on 8-9 July 2013.) 

Land's End is a hidden gem along the beautiful San Francisco coastline.  Growing up,  I revered this trail as a magical place.  Breathtaking views of the bridge when the sun is out, and sheer awesomeness when the fog steals the bridge away and you are left with the fog horns bellowing and singing to each other beyond the mist.  Land's End will always hold a special place in my heart.  My review can't even do it justice.  Just go.  See for yourself.  Words can't even begin to describe the magic that is Land's End.  There's no way to get lost on this trail.  If you stick on it from start to finish, you'll either be at a residential neighborhood that leads up to the Legion of Honor and at the other end will be Sutro Baths.  Plenty of hikers and runners.  Be prepared for stairs, too.  The trail is suitable that a girlie girl in flats or impractical shoes can still enjoy the trail.  :)

This place IS MAGIC.
author: Viva C.

description:
Best trail in the city. I find myself coming here every Friday morning to get a work out in. You'll have sweeping views of the Golden Gate Bridge throughout the hike. The Coastal Trail goes right along the ocean, and the waves crashing against the cliffs give the place a dramatic atmosphere. Truly breathtaking. You will completely forget you are in the middle of a city! It can get a little bit windy and cold since you are right on the coastline, so come prepared with a jacket.

Quick tips:
-Easy, free parking: park at the open lot off of Point Lobos Ave by the Cliff House restaurant. 
-Take the winding, paved trail to the Golden Gate Bridge outlook. Continue straight onto the dirt path that takes you through the forest along the coastline.
-Dog friendly!
-Trail is mostly flat (with the exception of two spots with stairs), so you can take visitors/family and it won't be too strenuous.
-The trail is what you make it, so you can certainly get a good workout in. This trail seems to be popular with joggers. 
-About halfway through the hike, you'll see some stairs leading down to the coast. Take those stairs. This leads you to Mile Rock Beach and you will end up at a beach cove. Here is where you will find the Labyrinth overlooking the bridge. Depending on the time of day, there will be no one else in sight and it feels like your own private beach cove :)

FIVE STARS!!
author: Justine M.

description: Honestly I don't understand the hype of Lands End. First of all, this is more of a trail than an actual hike, so it bothers me when someone suggests hiking then wants to go to Lands End. Mind you, this is still a pretty good workout. Or maybe I'm just out of shape. Second, the only decent thing about the view is the fact that you can walk closer and closer to the Golden Gate Bridge and if this is your first time in SF, sure I can see how you would like this trail... but there are a million places with a better view of the city. Lastly, there is graffiti everywhere. This is not the prettiest "hike" but there are several beaches along the trail you can stop by. Overall I would honestly never come back here on my own, but I know many friends from out-of-town who want to see the "sights."
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I was trying to find a place to take some sunset photos, but the day we went didn't bode so well. I still took some photos and plan to go back next time I'm in San Francisco. I visit the city, maybe once a year. 

This has some nice trails and a lovely view of the Golden Gate and of the bay connecting with the ocean. I will definitely make a trip out here again.
author: Melissa A.

description:
One of the easier favorite "hike" in sf
nice on both sunny and foggy days, can get a bit windy.
unfortunately the labyrinth is no more, does anyone know why?
author: ray l.

description:
Aww I was really looking forward to seeing the labyrinth, but it's no longer there =(

regardless, it's a nice place to go for a easy walk/hike with a beautiful view! And free parking!
author: Noelle H.

description:
I like this trail. Yes, it's not paved, BUT, I like that the ocean breeze and fog make the hike a lot easier for me so that I'm not melting under a scorching sun.

I loved the view of the Golden Gate Bridge, Legion of Honor and even a small detour to the Seacliff neighborhood. 

We took the dogs with us and they thoroughly enjoyed the hike, although one of them (Jasper, I'm talking to you) saw the green for the golf course, went tearing off and ran in huge circles while the golfers had to wait until my friend called him back. 

The parking lot can get crowded but at least their bathroom next to it are nice and clean.

I wouldn't mind hiking here again....the fact that I didn't get sunburned because there was fog is a huge plus for me.
author: Nette T.

description: Beautiful trail with beautiful views! It leads all the way to a beach. Highly recommend!
author: Esther M.

description: Absolutely breath taking. Beautiful area to hike with your dog. We loved it the views were amazing. there is plenty of places to take breaks and enjoy the views. I want to go on a less cloudy day to enjoy it more. overtime i go its pretty cloudy(san francisco weather). at the end of trail there is some pretty sweet designs.
author: Yasuko R.

description:
It was simply perfect today...not too warm, and not too cold. Everybody and his mother was sunning at China and Baker Beach, it seemed. Fun to see the cargo ships and watch the sailboats floating to and fro.

Awesome views, great for photos. Nice trail, steps great for the glutes..and great for digesting food after some yummy Shanghai noodles and XLB/dumplings..
author: Jana C.

description:
My favorite place (outside of Golden Gate park) to go for hikes/photography!

There's a lot of 'replay' value.. depending on weather conditions, every trip can be different, and it's really a joy to experience it.

Highly recommended for everyone!
author: Davis W.

description: Not really a fan of hiking, but I do love this trail.  I start at the Cliff House then end up on Clement St after passing the Legion of Honor.
author: David S.

description:
It has been so long since I've been on this trail. Things have really changed!  The trail is now well maintained and there have clearly been restoration projects in place to restore native vegetation. There is also the brand new Land's End gift shop where you can look out on the ocean, buy a coffee, or a gift. 

This is both good and bad in my opinion. Before, hiking the trail seemed very adventurous to me. In fact, we should to go past the safe portion when the trail extended all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge. Quite scary. Now the trail is very touristy. There are tons more people hiking it and it seems rather tame. That said, the restoration projects have made a huge difference in the vegetation. It was so pretty. A variety of flowers and decent exercise too if you hike down to the baths, go up to the coast and hike down to beach and the maze (lots of steps so be warned). The labyrinth was disappointing (I vaguely remember the old), but it satisfied my 7 year old. 

Gorgeous views. Made me realize anew what a special place San Francisco is. I was born here and it still remains my favorite city. Yes, it is always chilly, but the weather is perfect for hiking and running up and down stairs.
author: Nora S.

description:
I've been to lands end, the tennessee valley trails, and dipsea trail. 

Lands End: best for views. almost reminds me of big sur. but least strenuous of the trails I've done. The "labyrinth" is NOT impressive, so don't get your hopes up.  It looks like something a kid can make in 2 hours with a pile of rocks about fist size. You can finish this trail in 2-3 hours (we went all the way to through sea cliff to the lookout at china beach). If you want a workout, would recommend running this trail.  But easily accessible - just take Geary all the way west and you'll hit the parking lot. 

Dipsea trail (to stinson beach): 5-7 miles, least accessible, but best workout, thanks to the steps.  Definitely will have some soreness the next day. MAKE SURE to plan out your logistics.  We drove to the mill valley parking lot, took a bus into the city, and had to find the trail from there. There are some hand-written signs but make sure you do your research about how to find the trail head.  Coming back, you need to take a bus from stinson beach back to the parking lot, which is a 45minute bus ride that comes only every 2 hours or so.  

Tennessee Valley Trails to tennesee valley beach or muir beach: Any length, as there are tons of trail heads.  You can take it really easy and choose the flat route (with lots of kids), or climb over various hills.  I like this one for how flexible it is and is only a 20-30min drive from SF.
author: Alice Z.

description: Not a big hiker, but I definitely enjoyed the walk. Its quite scenic, and not a hard hike at all. You should wear proper sneakers when you come though. Appreciated the free parking too!
author: Tia M.

description:
Probably the nicest hike within SF city limits!

You get an awesome view of Marin County and the Golden Gate Bridge for most of the hike since you get a pretty good elevation gain on the cliffs along the water. You walk through forests, one of the richest neighborhoods in the city, and Baker Beach (best beach in the city!). Near Baker Beach there's also some old bunker/army stuff that will be fun for the guys =).

if you are on public transport and start at Ocean Beach, you can end the hike in the Presidio at the Golden Gate Bridge and then go through the Crissy Fields area (useful for me, living in Russian Hill at the time). 

I heard that the Park Ranger's center at the parking lot on the Ocean Beach end of the trail, which was being built the last time I was there, is really nice now. I'll have to head back for another hike!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
My husband and I came by here one Sunday last month while out driving. As the weather was nice and warm we parked up and took a walk - the views really were amazing of the Golden Gate Bridge and rocky Beaches. It was also surprisingly quiet for being right on the edge of the city.
On a good day you are also able to see Shipwrecks just off of the coast which was a real shame we couldn't see on our visit.

The trail offers many benches and spots to capture a gorgeous picture, Parking is ample but I would guess fills up pretty quick in the summer months and the trails are also ok for Dogs if you want to take your Kanine buddy for a walk while taking in some views and getting some exercise yourself.

Simply gorgeous.
author: Emmalouise B.

description:
Awesome easy trail! Great for those who aren't in the best shape because it's mostly flat haha. Lots of great photo ops for those who are visiting. 

Start off at the sutro baths and work your way from there. There's a small cave that's pretty cool to walk through. Be careful of the rocks and the "walkways". Be polite and let people off before you go on.

About 5-10 mins into the coastal trail, you'll see a bench where you can sit and look at the Golden Gate Bridge if it's a nice day. :) about another 5-10 mins after that, you'll see a pathway to rock beach. There's another path when you reach the beach that will lead you to the labyrinth. This is where all the rocks are placed in that maze looking thing. Don't be stupid like me and climb dangerously up the rocks to get a pic from above. Go around the labyrinth, there's a safer path to get up there. You can also see the bridge from here too. 

The coastal trail is beautiful and a great place for runners too! I've seen people bring their dogs as well. Just be sure to pick up after them :)

Theres free parking at the sutro baths and bathrooms inside the gift shop/cafe building.
author: Athena L.

description: The trail is nice and paved, and the views seen from this trail are awesome! There are so many different points, and the paths are marked pretty well (except for the labyrinth, which we asked about at the Lookout Center regarding how to get there so we were okay). The trail is mostly flat, except for the stairs at the end. There's really only one path, so the way you walk to the end is how you're going to walk back. A lot of people walk their dogs on this path, and if I lived closer, I would definitely come run here! Great views, pretty flat, no complaints!
author: Andrea W.

description: this is one of my favorite trails.  and no i do not consider this a hike...more like a walk in the park.  its really really easy.  only tiring part is probably all the stairs to get down to that area with all the cool rocks.  we started the trail at lands end, and took the coastal trail all the way through.  it takes you to sutro baths at the end.  we packed our lunches and drinks to eat at the beach-y area at the end.  very scenic.  lotssss of people.
author: mong linh n.

description: Amazing! It's far away enough from the hustle and bustle of the city to make you feel like you've entered Mother Nature's realm of zen and calm yet close enough to give you beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge. The coastal trail is pretty and flat for the most part. Ditch the trail if you can for at least some parts though and head down to the beautiful beach! There's all kinds of mini rock pyramids and even what looked like an old piece of some building with a spray paint mural on it. Pretty cool! It's also pet friendly which is always a plus! There's a parking lot right in front of the lands end visitor center and another one across the street from there.
author: Lauren N.

description:
What a breath of fresh air. 

The hustle and bustle of San Francisco is part of the city's charm. But after awhile one can yearn for a little serenity and quiet. Lands End is the answer!

A fairly easy trail, Lands End runs along the ocean side of the city and gives spectacular views of the water and the Golden Gate bridge. My favorite place to just go for a brisk walk, find a place to pause and take in the beauty of nature, and clear my mind. 

Find the rock maze! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lands-end-trail-san-francisco?select=4lWLTvmnMCv0cDg-EoT-iw#4lWLTvmnMCv0cDg-EoT-iw)

There are a couple parking lots I know of if you intend to drive yourself over. The one at Point Lobos is easy to find and has plenty of space. The parking lot itself already has a great view of the Sutro Baths.

Breathtaking. Do yourself a favor and just go!
author: Sally T.

description: This place is AMAZING! Great easy hike for all ages with some slopes and stairs for a bit of a workout. There are so many amazing views. Bring a picnic lunch in a backpack and you're set for a perfect afternoon. It's worth making the trek in from out of town - they have a parking lot!
author: Anna V.

description: many trails to chose from and they are all beautiful ! Bring a light jacket because t might get cold !
author: Aliza W.

description:
I love this trail. 

Pros (+): 
(+) Ocean trail! Beautiful trail with a lot of history (Sutro Baths, Memorial, etc.) and great views pretty much all along the way (unless Karl the Fog is around!). 
(+) Dog Friendly - one of the few Golden Gate Parks that is dog friendly. Love it!
(+) Free parking lot and admission - it's a big lot too! Lots of parking space
(+) Nice cafe area with coffee, food, and gift shop (and restrooms)

Definitely one of the go-to hikes in the city with great view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Lands End Trail was a magical experience. We had started our morning all the way in Outer Sunset and walked up to the Sutro Baths and Lands End Lookout and the trail was the icing on the cake.

It was a wonderfully foggy morning and we had a chance to walk on a good bit of the trail. We had nothing but the sound of the ocean splashing below and great views ahead and out into the water. It was such a wonderful scene to round a few turns and see the Golden Gate standing majestically out in the distance. 

I can see how you could kill some serious time walking the trails and all of the combinations of routes you could create for a run or long walk with the kiddos in a stroller. I would love to make it back and take the trail from the Lookout all the way to the Presidio. I'm sure that would be a crazy long walk, but it was such an amazing setting for being so close to the bustling city. 

Can't wait for next time.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
This is a very easy trail. Most is actually paved. I went down to the baths to try to see 'Sutro Sam" the otter but there were some disrespectful dog owners with their dogs right next to the baths and digging in the dirt next to the signs which say "dogs not allowed in this area and be quiet there is an endangered otter in the area" 

There is a cool cave you can check out and see the waves crash into the rocks and feel the salt spray. It's pretty intense. The wave action is quite strong. 

There were a lot of bikers runners dog owners and kids on the upper level next to the golf course. Beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Marin headlands. And a good opportunity to meet (and pet) dogs.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I wish there was an option for another star because this place is breathtakingly beautiful a must when in San Francisco... Whether it's a beautiful sunny day or overcast you cannot go wrong... Where good shoes and comfortable clothing plan on exercising
author: John S.

description:
I love this trail! My gf took me here to get out fitness on and I absolutely fell in love with this place. The view of the vast ocean and the Golden Gate bridge made this hike an extremely enjoyable experience and definitely tops my list of favorite trails. There are information boards along the way that tells bits and pieces about the history of the area.. But you probably won't even notice since you'll probably be in awe with the trees and flowers all around you anyways! The Sutro Bath houses connects along the way, which we also visited, but that's a different review in itself. Definitely worth it to check it out! We were lucky to have gone on a nice and sunny day and were able to take in everything that we could on this trail... the nature and the spectacular view. 

I can't wait to come back here!
author: Kathleen N.

description: This is probably one of my favorite places to visit on a somewhat regular basis. I found out about this hidden gem in December of last year and have been obsessed ever since! I always park in the first parking lot, right next to The Cliff House, and start the trail there. The entire walk itself is peaceful and the views of the ocean and the Golden Gate are beautiful, even when Karl the Fog makes an appearance! Making it down to the labyrinth is just so beautiful. If you continue up the trail you get an aerial view of the labyrinth, and if you walk down you can walk it! Its so peaceful, has such an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge, and if you walk down the trail you end up on the beach. Love this place and would definitely recommend anyone who comes to SF to visit it here!
author: Elena V.

description: Incredible. This park had breathtaking views. Walk down to one of the beaches and see if you can see the mussels on the rocks or any of the caves. There's so many wildflowers that are indigenous to the area. Would go again in a heartbeat!
author: Gabe C.

description:
This is a great running trail.  Difficulty is pretty easy/moderate.  Bring your running shoes.  

Along the trail is the beach cliffs and you get some great views of the Golden Gate / beach.  We hiked (walked) for about 2.0 hours and it was about 4 miles.

Lots of cool stuff to see like caves, small hills to climb, and a man-made maze thing.
author: Mike T.

description: The most gorgeous hike I have ever been on. But then again... I have only hiked in LA. The weather was perfect and the history of this trail makes it quite unique. As I was walking around, I thought to myself, "This is such a nice date spot." So I would recommend it for a date. The incline is not much so a very casual exerciser like me felt fine.
author: Annie L.

description: We enjoyed our hike and relaxation. Lands End is extremely beautiful and I recommend for day get away.
author: Shay B.

description:
Dont let the thick fog scare you away, if anything it makes it more beautiful. The trail is wide and mostly flat, stairs and steep in some part but anyone can do it. You'll see beautiful trees, a cave, secluded beach and numerous beautiful lookouts. Don't forget to go down Rock mile beach. 

If you're going to do any one hike in San Francisco, make it this one! Take the bus to one end an take the bus home at the other end.
author: Thao T.

description: Great trails, plenty of parking, but these trails (while comparatively easy) are not suitable for those with mobility issues. There are inclines and steps almost everywhere. Very scenic views but there are some dangerous areas where people go off the trail.
author: Shaz P.

description: Really can't go wrong with this trail. It's perfect if you wanna see some stellar views but aren't in tip-top shape (ahem, mission peak). The trail itself is quite short at 3.5 miles round trip, but you will definitely work up a sweat if you decide to explore (there are stairs leading to different cool spots & going up is a challenge if you aren't a gym-regular). Don't have any complaints about this trail...so get off your phone, put your shoes on & enjoy this super fun hike :)
author: Victoria A.

description:
Gorgeous views of the Golden Gate bridge from a different angle - Checked!
Amazing view of the bay, water and land- checked!
Nicely paved dirt trail - checked!
Stairs for the fitness crazed ones - checked!
Dogs allowed - Checked!
Shade and green trees - Checked!
Free easy parking and near by public transportation - Checked and Checked!

Note - the trail is somewhat dangerous - it is after all the land's end, so keep young kids near you don't let them go too close to the edge, or climb the rocks.
Also the trail is unsuitable for wheelchairs (more of a nature trail in its character, then the usual urban trail).
author: Stephanie A.

description: It was a sunny day and this is a very pretty natural area offering great views of the bay and lovely wildflowers, too.  We enjoyed our visit, took plenty of photos of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge in the distance, and met some nice people doing the same.  Plenty of parking and easy to find but also seems it wouldn't be hard to get here by public transit, bike, or even walking if you lived nearby.
author: Tina P.

description: If you want to feel like you're out in nature, forget Golden Gate Park, this is the place to be. One of the only places I know of in the city where you can't hear the traffic, just the ocean waves and the wind and chirping birds. I can't believe it's taken me nearly thirty years to discover this trail (especially one so well reviewed) but I'm glad to have found it today.
author: Amanda P.

description: I love coming to this trail. It's beautiful to overlook the water and see the beautiful bay bridge. The intense level on this hike is easy, but there are trails in which you can choose if you want a little more of a challenge. Always my go-to trail while in the city. And what makes it that more amazing is that they serve coffee in their little shop! Also, great nature shots if you're in to photography- it's beautiful here!
author: Lovely L.

description: Probably the most beautiful spot on earth. I highly recommend taking a second date here. You'll get a workout and take in some breath-taking scenery.
author: Emyli V.

description:
Let me start by saying, I'm not a hiker or athletic at all, for that matter.  BUT, this hike was awesome! Super easy, mostly flat besides a couple of points where you have to climb a bunch of stairs (good thing I had my inhaler handy). 

I definitely recommend wearing workout gear, although you'll see some people looking like they're headed to an interview. I saw one gal strolling along in her loafers. First of all, not cute, and secondly, you'll get dirty!  

The views of the water and the Golden Gate Bridge are breathtaking! I'm totally going to go back because we weren't able to check out the Sutro Baths area which looked beautiful.  We were starving, so we headed over to the Cliff House (which is literally across the street from the parking lot) for some drinkies and grub.
author: Suki B.

description: This was a hidden gem! Fun place to scope out and see the golden gate WITHOUT the crowds and tourists.
author: Cc R.

description: Let me start my review starting with the statement that this is the best trial there is to hike on a weekend. Will definitely come back for the awesome views and relaxing beaches on the way to Golden Gate bridge from Lands end Sutro Baths.. The total 12 miles walk from Sutro Baths to Golden Gate bridge is not only spectacular but also a good cardio for the day.
author: Gopi V.

description: I loved this place. There were so many little tiny trails and spots that you can explore. My favorite was the old bathroom remains overlooking the ocean and definitely the labyrinth. I passed on first try walking through that maze; yes, I am proud. If I lived in SF, I'd go here every weekend!
author: Yin I.

description:
Lands End is right up against the Pacific Ocean, just north of the beaches, and a great getaway from the city where you can walk, jog, or bike along the coast with great views of the ocean and the Golden Gate.

On a nice day, finding parking around here will be just as painful as finding parking anywhere else in the city. According to one of my friends who comes here often though, on a foggy day there will really only be a few cars in the parking lot.

At one end of Lands End, you'll find Sutro Baths, which sits along the bottom of the cliffs where the parking lot is. If you're short on time (like an hour), Sutro Baths will be plenty to see by itself. If you have a bit more time than that, take a leisurely walk along the coast. Part of the walk will be through a small forest, and from the cliffs you can see Marin and the Golden Gate Bridge. They say you can find some shipwrecks along the bottom of the cliffs as well. Eventually you can find a "labyrinth" which is actually more of a work of art.

It's a great way to spend a couple of hours checking out some of the city's natural scenery.
author: Allen C.

description: Very scenic hike. I love coming here just to get away and enjoy the view here. Very peaceful and quiet.
author: Leia S.

description: Beautiful views of the Bay and the Golden Gate Bridge!  We stopped here right before reaching the Legion of Honors Museum and took some gorgeous pictures!
author: Rose L.

description:
Flippin' Gorgeous. One weekend Mr. L and I decided to drop the kids off at their grandmother's house, and set out for this Pacific coastal hike we had been planning for months. I love San Francisco. Not only for the culture, diversity, and feel- I love it because there is ALWAYS something new to discover. Brush up on your bay area history and plant biology and you'll have one helluva time. 

We started on Ocean Beach, where we quickly and fortunately found a parking spot of the Great Highway. Up we hiked, listening to waves crash angrily against the rocks, towards Seal Rocks, a marine preserve, where the colony of sea lions (the Pier 39 ones!) originally hung out. You can spot them from Land's End on clearer days. 

Next, you can look down (and even go into) the Sutro Baths, which was a large public bath house constructed in 1896 serving SF until 1966 before it burned, oddly enough. Soon, you will discover the Labryrinth- thank you, artist Eduardo Aguilera...this was truly a cool thing to see. 

Enjoy the different views of the golden Gate- no photo will do them justice. You can keep going, past Baker Beach, up the stairs- (not for the out of shape) Catch a bus back at the Golden Gate entrance, and then grab a fat burger, because that is some adventure!
author: Rosemary W.

description: Beautiful hike that isn't too hard.  Good for a mid day stroll if you want great views of the bay!
author: David C.

description:
A good trail for those that do not want to make a long drive out of the city.  Be sure to go early on holidays and weekends as free parking is somewhat limited.  The Camino Del Mar parking lot was my lot of choice as it provided quick access to multiple areas.  There was also a helpful map posted at the end so you can get your bearings and make a plan.

The trails were well paved and traveled.  You will get great views of the Golden Gate bridge and the rocky coastline below.  Not overly challenging, with a long staircase being the most strenuous activity.  

Dogs are welcomed but be prepared to bring your own bags as there are none along the trail.  I also did not notice trash cans on the trail but there are some around the parking lot area so you can pack it and drop it off there.

A bit too many people and some parts of the trail narrows.  And I wished there were more signs along the trail to see where you can branch out and find places like the labyrinth.

Not a bad escape from the city.
author: Roy L.

description: My friends and I came here to take a bunch of pictures. There were various trails to choose from. It was a nice and beautiful day to enjoy mother nature. Thank goodness from friendly people and cute puppies to make our hike fun. We found a couple of gems on the trail. If you go on this trail try to find them!
author: Jay B.

description: This is a stellar hike along the Bay. There are a few paths you can take but I highly recommend taking the waking path next to the water. You get breathtaking views of the bay and the Golden Gate bridge, framed by trees along the path. There are also some turn offs you can take down towards the water where you can get even better views or see an art installation: Eagles Point Labyrinth. Parts of it can be challenging. There are lots of steps if you want to go down to see the art installation but totally worth it. This is a great hike. I loved all of it.
author: Joanna V.

description: Had an awesome time here. Went through the whole trail and even off course to get to sutro baths.
author: Alex B.

description:
Happy 300th review! My calves are still crying from the hike last Saturday. I must have gotten a really good work out in or I'm just weak sauce. 

Took my girlfriend here so we could do some catching up and exercise at the same time without having to be in a gym where you're always interrupted by guys hitting on you. When we got there, we found parking immediately. That's what I love about this trail! Unlike Mission Peak on weekends where you have to park far away and hike to the trail just to start your hike. But I digress... For a beautiful Saturday day, there weren't too many people, which was great. It's probably because most San Franciscans were at home watching the Niners beat the Saints a$$. I'm just sayin... 

The trail wasn't too hard, but it wasn't super easy either. Going back up the stairs will get ya if you're a noob. But I did see kids on the trail so it's not THAT hard. I love the super clear views of the gorgeous Golden Gate Bridge from this trail. There are so many different trails to take within this trail so lots of options. Needless to say, I'll be back and I'll be bringing some more friends. Highly recommend! You should try it! 

PROS: Plenty of parking, excellent views, pretty decent hike, lots of trails to choose from, you may run across some cool secret spots like the labyrinth!

CONS: Not that hard of a hike. Depending on which trails you take, you could end up on the concrete trails, which I dislike; I like real dirt hikes. Also, it's a popular trail so could get kind of crowded, but not too bad.
author: Lucky N.

description:
The trail is beautiful. The trail is a really cool way to get a little bit of exercise and hang out with family, friends, or loved ones. And it's somewhere you might find 17 billion dollar CEOs. On my hike through Lands End I happened to pass Facebook creator Mark Zuckerberg walking with a friend and his dog. I wish I could upload my picture of him picking up his dog's poop, and yes even billionaires do it. Anyway it was a good little hike, here is my opinion of the trail in numbers.

Trail Difficulty: 3 out of 10, 10 being extremely difficult
Trail Views: 7 out of 10, Great view of the Golden Gate on a clear day
Overall Experience: 8 out of 10, great outing for family, friends, and dates!
author: Diego S.

description:
Definitely a must when in the bay area! The hike is very easy, its more of a walk. 

I went on a Monday morning, around 10am. It was perfect. There was still a handful of people on the trail. A lot of dogs as companions on the trail as well. Of course, the fog was blocking my view of the GG bridge, but it was still gorgeous being able to overlook the bay while taking a relaxing walk.

I highly recommend it. It is a brisk hike, and will take about an hour and 15 minutes round trip. There are also some restaurants next door overlooking the water, which would be a great pit stop after the hike.

Don't miss out on taking the stairs down to the sand! It can be easily missed!
author: Alique B.

description: Beautiful trail for run'n, walk'n, strolling, viewing, etc... But please leave room for everyone to enjoy! Don't block the trail.
author: Leslie E.

description: I love this place! It has nice, easy hiking trail and a beautiful view of the ocean! Plus, there is free parking! It's nice and relaxing to just walk around the area :)
author: G T.

description:
Amazing trail! Not very strenuous at all. 

We started off the trail very mild. It was just a straight road and you can see the gorgeous Golden Gate. I went on a fairly sunny day and yet, it was kind of cold. My body felt so conflicted with the temperature, it was ridiculous! Because this trail is mainly by the water, one should wear a jacket. I was rather confused while on this trail because I really wanted to go to the famous maze! 

First off, once you go down to the Mile Stone trail (which very stairs oriented) and once you hit the end of the first set of stairs, go to the right. Not left because if you go left, you'll end up at this rocky beach area. It took us two tries to get to the maze. Kind of ditched it the first time and we had to go through those painful stairs again. 

This is one of the prettiest hikes I've been on, just because I think it's by the water. If you keep heading on the main trail,  you'll end up getting to the cliff house where the bath house is at and this little cove you can go into. Although this hike was not that strenuous, my calves are in pain now because of all the stairs! I've been up the Duomo and that wasn't as bad! Which is rather sad. I think it's because the steps are sort of wide and not consistent in its size which makes it harder to walk down/up. My calves are crying right now and I stupidly didn't streatch!

This is a great place to go running and taking your dogs for a walk (which is what I saw a lot of). Love this place!
author: Denise L.

description: Is there a more beautiful five-star trailer and all of San Francisco? I dare you to find one. This is my Go to trail that I go to whenever I need to go on a hike in San Francisco.  The weekends can be crowded and so can the holidays but the rest of the year you basically have the trail all to yourself. I find myself liking both sides of the trail but on most days I prefer to start at the Legion of honor.if you go when it's busy you will probably hear about five different languages because people from all over the world come here to see San Francisco and the views of the Golden gate Bridge.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Pretty simple trail, seems like more of a walk. If you don't do a lot of cardio or stairs, then it can be challenging, but overall very do-able. The trail goes by the water and it really is beautiful. There were people running through, walking around, in regular clothes...so whatever preference you'd like to go in, go for it!

I took my camera so I was able to get some great shots of the water, OK shots of the Golden Gate Bridge, but great nature pics. The sutro baths and caves are amazing. These are the areas where you should really watch your children if you bring them. Great tourist spot for an SF trip...considering it a "must do"
author: Darlene B.

description:
Land's End hike is a good easy hike if you don't want to catch yourself out of breath, cramping up or sore the next day. There are a few stairs and incline here and there, but if hipsters in their boat shoes and chino shorts can do it, so can you. 

This hike is a great hike if you want to be along the coast of the water with great views of the golden gate bridge the whole time. The trail eventually leads there. 

Don't forget to visit the Labyrinth maze while you're here (coastal trail). 

If you don't take the trail, there a small tiny walk down to sutro baths you can venture out to.
author: Shirley D.

description: This trail is one of my favorite places in the whole city. For me it is a place I can come to get away from the stresses and craziness of city life. There are a lot of divergences off the trail, secret beaches, rock graffiti, etc. Depending on whether you start at the lookout parking lot down by the Cliff House or park on the street at 34th, you will have a different workout but can't go wrong! I love watching the seasons change here (well as much as they change for SF) through the flowers, views, and plants. Please respect the land and trails here and let's all work to keep Lands End special :)
author: Rachel G.

description: It is a divine experience, connecting and learning about nature and history. The trail is breathtakingly beautiful: native vegetation restored by volunteers. rocky shores from which you can see shipwrecks. You can anjoy a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands. The peace, the sense of greatness, it is overwhelming. And as this is not enought magic to enjoy, you can relax at the Cliff House, a restaurant where the ocean views are marvelous. The place is absolutely gorgeous. I am coming back for sure...!
author: Diorys P.

description: One of my fav places. Hiked with the dogs and hung around all day. Beautiful views. People often here for photoshoots. Easy hike.
author: Kermy K.

description:
Great place to 

hike
sight see
jog
take pictures
check out nice scenery 
grab take out and just chill


Fantastic hidden gem below Legion of Honor.
author: T C.

description: The name is perfect for this place! Really felt like I was at the edge of world staring at the pacific ocean as the huge waves collide against the rocks. Was quite gloomy and windy on the day I went, which was probably why it felt like the world was ending haha
author: Sam C.

description:
This place is beautiful! I really can't think of anything bad to say, despite coming on a partly cloudy day.

My friends and I got off the main parking lot near the cafe area, and right away, you get a nice view of the Pacific Ocean. From there, you have a couple options to hike down. We took an adventurous route (by talking a somewhat of a narrow dirt path). On our short hike down to the ocean, we encountered a very small snake. Regardless, that was a bit of a surprise. 

Once we reached the bottom, there seems to be an abandoned building area. You get to walk around it and reach the rocky shore. Pretty fun, it's like a labyrinth. Be careful though, some of the walking platforms have pot holes, so don't be like me and try to post your Instagram photos while you're walking. The reality of the many "Danger" sign may become true if you end up falling in the rather colorful (read - algae filled) ponds. 

From here, we went into an AWESOME cave. Waves are crashing right below you, so you get to hear the ocean roar. Quite an experience. 

The rest of the trip consisted of a nice hike up to Eagle Point ( I think that's what it was called). We thought that was the path to the Lands End rock/maze/thing. But we didn't find it. Maybe another time? At the end of the hike, we found an exit (and mankind - hallelujah). We dreaded the idea of having to walk the entire way back, but thank god we didn't. 

FYI - Uber from Montgomery Station (closest BART station) is about a $13 uber drive there. Well worth it if you're sharing a ride with friends!
author: Larry F.

description: Great place to hike (even for amateurs) with AMAZING views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Begin your hike after 2pm for the best views!
author: William L.

description:
I love a good trail just as much as anyone else and I usually deduct stars for a trail that is too crowded and filled with strolling pushing, Starbucks drinking, cel-phone in hand, dog-walking soccer moms but the scenery and views are just that good too overcome these inconveniences. It's a quick walk (not too strenuous) but you can always extend the walk (hike) by continuing on once the trees overhead open up a bit. I would recommend coming here during the week (off-peak times) if possible if you really want a little more privacy and less noise (especially for a date), but if not, that should not deter you otherwise from coming on weekends. 

Be sure not to miss the labyrinth!
author: E E.

description: Happen to come across this place right here on Yelp. Took a bus ride from our hotel to the west end of the city to enjoy this place. Found ourselves alone on this gorgeous beach for a while before anybody else had shown up and saw magnificent views of the Golden Gate as well as beach rocks with trails that go through some pretty cool vegetation. I was lucky because my favorite flowers are lilies and we came across a group of wild pink lilies in the middle of tons of green shrub. I didn't see many tourists where we were (which is funny because that's what we were while we were there), and would most definitely say that it's worth the time to travel to for some time away from the chaos in the city.
author: Nathan G.

description: My first time here and I live in the bay area for over 20 years now. Reply great place to realign with the way things were during the golden days of SF. There was a cave that led to the edge of the lands end and it was moist, very damp and dark. It took me back about 150 or so years and I gained a sense of how it was like walking through coastal caves such as this one. It made me felt like I had just landed on the shores of California as a goldsman. Lots of stair climbing, definitely workout on the stair master before coming here. Bring hiking shoes if possible.
author: Michael M.

description:
Love, love, LOVE these trails.  I try to go everyday but sometimes the weather sucks.  Have to take 1 star off for that, even though it's really MoNa's (mother nature) fault.

BEAUTIFUL views when it's sunny.  Fairly safe but sometimes I worry about vagrants hiding in the bushes waiting for young girls to walk by.  You're pretty much isolated when it's foggy so be sure to go hiking with someone.  You can go hiking alone when it's sunny, since there will be more people.  Utilize the stairs for a super cardio workout.

If you go geocaching, you will find this amazing view of the bridge that no one else gets.  You can get more details here: http://www.geocaching.com/

Visit the Legion of Honor for spectacular views of the city and an extra dose of culture.  Boudin's The Thinker resides here.  You can't steal it, we tried.

(And by the way ladies, if your date tells you he's taking you for a walk by the ocean and you can see the GG Bridge, PLEASE don't wear heals.  You are just asking to embarrass yourself.)
author: Victoria C.

description: Nice easy trail with beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Sutro Baths, and the ocean. The trail was mostly, if not all cement so you don't even need hiking or running shoes to walk it. It's a great place to run and sunset is so beautiful here. It gets really packed on weekends especially on nice days, so I suggest not even entering the parking lot and just park in the residential areas nearby.
author: Stephanie G.

description: My two friends, my dad, and I came here on a sunny but windy Saturday afternoon. There weren't very many parking spots because of the amount of people but we were able to quickly grab one. Depending on where you wanna go I suggest not wearing sandals or flip flops unless you want to go to the beach. If you want to hike all the way out to the end it is a little tiring! I love the views no matter where you go there because it's all so beautiful, I recommend it.
author: Izzy C.

description: I've been here 3 times and each time was unique and fun! The beach is a great place to enjoy the view and relax, and the trails provide a great workout with an amazing view of the ocean as well as the Golden Gate Bridge. I would definitely recommend this area for both scenery and exercise!
author: Emily W.

description: Parking is past the cliff house if you circle around a few times you'll find a spot. Do not go on weekends way too many tourists and if you do go early morning. Not so much of a hike more of a walk with some incline but to get to eagles point there are quite a few stairs. Stop to check out the secluded little areas along the way. Lots of beauty here one of my favorite trails.
author: Gabriella M.

description:
The world is not flat. 

Yet, walking on Land's End trail makes you feel as if you're standing on the edge of the world.  You cautiously lean over to the side and you know you're secretly thankful you're wearing your sturdy rubber-soled shoes, (and also glad that the trees and shrubbery are there as a barrier) because that sheer drop into the cold, choppy waters of the Pacific is something you don't want to happen.   

You can access this trail from the Seacliff neighborhood (find parking along El Camino del Mar and 32nd Ave)  or from the parking lot near the Sutro Baths (coming from Point Lobos Ave).  I'd say allot at least an hour or so for a leisurely hike on this 1.5 mile trail which gives you plenty of time to stop and shoot photos. 

Gawk at the wide expanse of the Pacific Ocean.  Take in the dramatic views of the coast, with the surf personally responsible for carving these rocky cliffs.  You'll pass twisted cypress trees, rock formations, poison oak (!) and the verdant surroundings will surely inspire you to write a poem.  (or maybe just read one)

All through the hike, I kept asking myself: "am I still in San Francisco?"

Hearing the fog horn in a distance reminded me that indeed, I still am. 

I love SF.
author: Janice C.

description:
My friends from socal were visiting and wanted to check out this trail. I have never been there and personally avoided it because I thoight it was a tourist thing and I tourists annoy me....unless I'm the tourist. 

We followed google maps to get there and was a bit confused on where it started. I think we ended up starting in the middle of the trail. We didn't really care though. We just wanted that famous photo op at the end. My friends and I had recently done an intense trail so one look at this one we were like, oh whatever.

It was a short easy hike. There is sand everywhere which got in our shoes. It's also flat for the most part, then some stairs and slight incline to get to the photo op parts. I wasn't expecting sand, but I guess it makes sense since it's at the cliff. There are a lot of tourists, people training, and even more tourists. The number of tourists slightly bothered me when they would just stop in the middle of the trail to do a photo op, but at those parts, the trail was wide enough to accommodate other hikers to go around them. I guess the hardest part would be going up the stairs. We ended up having a lot of fun.
author: Christina L.

description: Nice way to spend an afternoon.  Parking was surprisingly available, and the trail was very manageable with spectacular views.  Good coffee and gift shop at the head of the trail for a little extra something special.
author: Mark P.

description:
A gem tucked away in the outer border of San Francisco. Fitting with its name, the the sheer cliffs and views from this hike make you feel like you're on the edge of the world. It was cloudy when I was there which cut off the view to the city but gave the whole hike a more mysterious ambiance. It felt like being in a dome of clouds. The hike is fairly easy with only a few uphill portions. There's a pit stop you can make halfway in that takes you right down to the beach. There are tons of raspberry bushes along the way and if you're there in the right season you can forage a nice snack. The trail ends by presidio where you can loop back through some main streets are just backtrack.
Amenities: There is plenty of street parking even if the lot is full. At the head of the trail there's a cafe, gift shop, and bathrooms.  Just keep in mind that the bathrooms close in the evening time.
Also, the Sutro Baths at the head of the trail are fun to check out.
author: Candy W.

description:
Main points that make me love this place: 
- Not too long, not too intense. Makes it the perfect place to bring parents from out of town or an early morning date hike (wait that's a thing to me now? OMG I'm getting old) 
- Sweeping views of the bay & Golden Gate Bridge. 
- LOVE that it's dog friendly. 
- Hop skip and a jump away from Sutro Baths
- Walking distance to Pacific Beach (Bon fires?! haaayyy) 
- Walking distance to Cliff House for a post hike lunch!
author: Alex K.

description: Awesome trail in the city overlooking the water and with great views of the Golden Gate bridge. Don't miss if you are visiting the city.
author: Dave B.

description: I love hiking this area!  We hiked from the Sutro Baths to the GGB and it was a great day!  We explored downhills and had to go back uphill but the lookouts, old navy bunkers and views made it all worth it.  I highly recommend at least several hours for this hike and taking public transportation or Uber back so you can go as far as possible without turning back and hiking the same trail.  Bring water!
author: Chris L.

description: Beautiful hike. Pretty easy most of the way, but nice for an easier walk. Make sure you stop and see the baths.
author: Therese M.

description:
There are so many people on this trail now that always running into people. It is nice on warm summer days and scary on foggy nights. The trail is slippery at points and full of dog's poop because dog walkers do not pick up after them. 

It is mainly the dog walkers and people who still ride their bicycle here that makes the trail so bad.
author: M C.

description:
i haAAaaAaAaAaAaAAAAaaaaaAAAaAaaate the outdoors

and i walked away pretty happy with my life choice of getting there at 9am and walking around outdoors for like two hours

so uh, 5 stars
author: Kaycee C.

description: The Lands End Trail is a great trail to go for a leisurely stroll. If you're looking for a moderate or challenging hike, this is not it. LE is relatively flat minus a few stairs if you want to go down to the beach. But - come here on a nice day and enjoy the nice views of the bay along your walk. It can be very touristy and might be a bit crowded during the weekends though. Very family and dog friendly. My grandparents like to walk here often. We usually park over by Sutros or Ocean Beach and walk up to the LE trail and loop back around. If you're adventurous, you can go over to the Legion of Honor too.
author: Liv A.

description: I really like this trail. It's super easy to get to via both public transpo via the 38 or 38L and there is bountiful, easy parking for those who want to drive in. The trails and views are magical and if you venture out to Eagle's Point you get to enjoy the hand-made labyrinth!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Beeeeautiful trail. And easy, too. Great for tourists who want some outdoors exercise and stunning views. We just hiked along the paved trail and after a while, we got to a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Excellent photo-op. 

I can't exactly describe which trails we took since we just sort of went wherever we felt like. But at one point we ended up on a small secluded beach - not the kind where you lay out and tan on, but the kind with driftwood and rocks. It's surrounded by giant cliffs - very picturesque. Warning - if you go down there, there are A LOT of stairs back up.

At another point, we ended up on top of the cliff where there was a labyrinth another great view of the Golden Gate Bridge. We sat down at the edge of the cliff, and it was beautiful and thrilling.

We also got to the Sutro Baths, which look pretty cool from afar, but kind of stink up close. To the side of the Baths is this really cool cave. Definitely check that out. 

Overall, it's must-go place when you visit SF. Also a great place to exercise or walk your dogs in general.
author: Jamie C.

description: What a wonderful gem of a trail! The ocean air fills your lungs as you hike this trail, and you are rewarded with spectacular views of the ocean and infused with the oxygen from the surrounding trees. There is a bit of elevation to give you a challenge. The view from the top gives you a superb sunset vista, and you can also bring your canine friend or bike it if you choose! A true natural treasure of San Francisco.
author: David B.

description: Our favorite place in SF! The trails are really easy with the most amazing views of the ocean and GG bridge. Family friendly too! We sort of go off the trails into the trees for a shortcut to the beach. From the beach you can still go up to the labyrinth or over to the Sutro bath ruins.
author: Cody And Jamille V.

description:
Best trail ever for both me and my pup Penny. I was just walking Penny and stumbled upon Lands End Trail. The weather was great, the scenery was amazingly breathtaking, especially the Golden Gate Bridge, and there were dogs everywhere. Penny met a new friend Buster and enjoyed playing tag with each other for over half and hour. Great easy to follow trail. 

What I recommend:
-- Great place to walk your dog.
-- Great picture location.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I absolutely hate hiking, but this place is not too bad of a hike but the views are spectacular. Amazing and breathtaking. From the ocean waters, to the rocks, to the Golden Gate bridge in the background, it's all so beautiful.

It does get sort of windy so a light jacket might be nice. The labyrinth is really cool as well!
author: Carmen C.

description:
