I think we poked around in almost every nook and cranny, and it took maybe 3-4 hours. So far, one of my favorite places in SF! Planning on coming back at least 3 times in the next month or two.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
With a gorgeous day at our disposal, we decided to cruise on over to Land's End to soak up some breathtaking views + a  lil' bit of beach. This trail really took our breath away w/ a nice view of the GG bridge, the ocean, and a route leading down to a pretty little beach w/ lots of tide pools and rocks to climb on. 

And if you're not very outdoorsy, don't fret. This is a fairly easygoing trail thats got a big payoff.

It's hard to believe that this serene, nature-oriented spot lies w/in the boundaries of SF. How lucky are we??
author: Tiffany M.

description:
SO BYOOTIFUL. The smells, the sounds, the tastes, the SIGHTS! Who would've thought such a place would exist in San Francisco? I fell in love as soon as I stepped out of the car. This is the perfect place to get away from the bustling city life. There's little signs that give passerbys the historical facts about certain places on the trail (which were actually really interesting). Easy, peasy hike with incredible views. You definitely won't regret visiting, even if its just for a few minutes.

 Can't wait to come back!!
author: Mindy C.

description: Great place to take the dogs! Parking isn't terrible or at least it wasn't in my experience. A loooot of people come by noon but the trails are pretty wide making it accessible for decent to fairly "big crowds" to walk. Runners are courteous and say, "Pardon Me". Just an overall great atmosphere! A must do.
author: Sweets N.

description: Love this hike! Very mellow and easy for people who aren't really hikers. Lots of natural beauty.
author: Matt B.

description:
the lands end trail is closed at the end of the trail due to construction.. it blocked at the end of the eagles point.. when i went around the blocked area and tried to go up to clement street.. accidentially went into the golf course and got lost.. the security guard was yelling and gave me confusing direction on how to exit.. i guess i should have turned around in the first place... but i met a coyote first time.. on the golf
course..
author: D F.

description:
Great place to walk around and a getaway from the city life. 

Secluded places that feels like your secret spot. 

Spotting a fisherman on a secluded rock surrounding by water makes me wonder how one even gets there. 

Facts around the trail, they had trolleys going through here. Amazing. 

Who needs StairMaster when you can't feel your legs after going up those stairs.
author: Mandy D.

description: A must-see spot in San Francisco. A lot of locals come here and it's beautiful to see the bridge from a different spot.
author: Erin L.

description: Absolutely awesome, great views of the coast. Worth the trip a little sad the maze wasn't as big as the one pictured.
author: A C.

description: Came here with my dad. We both loved it! I love the multiple stairs for added workout. The view is amazing throughout! There's plenty of parking. Layer up because of gusty winds. Several times, I felt like I was going to be blown away.
author: Malou M.

description: An excellent hiking spot with both treelined trails and several routes down to the beach.  It would be very hard for a visitor to see the Golden Gate bridge from between the trees, with the fog rolling in right after sunset, and not want to live in San Francisco forever.
author: Charles Y.

description: I nice, easy hike around the coast of SF.  Everyone knows about the rock maze, but there is so much more to explore!  The mini beach has some cool stuff to climb around and there are detours you can take around here.  Very fun to go in big groups indeed.
author: Sam K.

description:
Friday was a glorious day - sunny, warm enough, and just a few clouds in the sky.  The three of us parked at the Legion of Honor and decided to head to the Lands End Trail.  We wandered down the hillside on a small trail, slipping on the leaves, crossing a mini gully on a log, and wondering if anyone was at the nude beach.  We reached the main trail and headed towards the bridge.

We had absolutely beautiful views of the Marin Headlands, the cliffs, and of course the GGB. 

Wandering back the car my daughter needed to use a restroom.  No problem, I'm a DeYoung/Legion member.  We popped in, used the WC, and took a peak at some of the cool exhibits I saw when there for the Cinema Supper Club ( http://www.yelp.com/events/san-francisco-cinema-supper-club---berliner-film-fest )

Walking back outside 40 minutes later we were shrouded in fog.

Yep, we are in San Francisco.
author: Jeff H.

description: this is also one of my favorite hiking trails, it's very relaxing place to go for a walk and enjoy the view, the cool refreshing ocean breeze is energizing and makes your hike more enjoyable, you get a pretty good workout since you have to climb trails & stairs. Plenty of free parking too
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: Oh My Godddddd. Saw dolphins. Automatic 5 stars.
author: Michael T.

description: We've been on this trail twice. The first time we only walked half way and then just turned back since we weren't in proper shoes. I took my dog Muffin here the second time and she loved it too. She started eating mud the moment I unleashed her...must be some kind of premium SF mud. The trail is easy and scenic. It's definitely one of the places you should bring your out of town guests to. If I'm going to be picky and must complain about something, then I would say the trail is a bit crowded and a little too short.
author: Sherry Y.

description: This is a great area for quick, easy hikes and nice scenery. Several easy hikes for kids too. There can be crowds, but for good reason.
author: Brent A.

description:
The view is spectacular. there are various pockets that lead to secret trails and secret spots. on a clear and sunny day, u can see the golden gate bridge in its full glory surrounded by sparkling blue water.. it is the very essence of an ideal-picture-perfect san francisco. i come here often with my girlfriend. we hike here all the time. 

this is truly a san francisco treasure, and i would highly recommend anyone to hike here with their freinds or family :)
author: simon k.

description: Great hiking trail that overlooks the ocean. You get great views all the way to marin. And it is great for pets too. It is usually very cold and windy so bring a jacket and wear long sleeves. Even after hiking about 5 miles, I was still chilly. It is a good 5 degrees colder here than the rest of the city. Because I came with a group of younger people with no kids, we were able to hike the steep trails and the rocky cliffs.You really have to watch your balance in some of these places. Overall, fun place to come for a short hike.
author: Cecile S.

description:
This is, unquestionably, the best hiking trail within SF city limits and rivals the Marin hikes in beauty and views.  Endless panaroma of ocean and mountain coupled with little surprises like random, hidden rocky beaches, cypress forests, and even shipwreck remains, it's hard to believe that this raw slice of nature abuts a dense urban grid.  You can only hear the ocean, wind, and fog signals, making it the perfect escape from the city noise.

I'd also recommend checking out Lands End in both pristine, sunny skies and rolling fog as it takes on a different personality depending on weather conditions.
author: Mike B.

description:
LOVE THIS!  It's the perfect kind of trail for a lazy person like me.  If you decide to walk all the way down one end, it's 1 mile so 2 miles roundtrip.  The scenery is spectacular... makes the walk more pleasant.  Depending on the time of year, bits of the trail might be muddy.  About halfway into the trail, you can take a side trail to Legion of Honor but there's a big golf course in your way.  I like how there are a couple stops along the way where you can read about the history (how a cable car use to run along this cliff, how many ships sunk in that area, etc.).  

Walking 0.8 mile into the trail and back took us about an hour?  We were slow and veered off a couple times.  There was even a guy who wanted us to take a survey about the park but that only took 8 minutes, just like he said it would.  Parking around the wealthy neighborhood wasn't too bad.  We found a spot down the street immediately and truly enjoyed walking by the million dollar homes.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Amazing place to walk on a nice sunny day. The hike is easy with some stairs. 

Different views of the Golden Gate bridge is a huge plus.
author: Sujit N.

description:
There should only be one rating available for this trail, five stars. It is incredible, I love how you can go ten minutes from your house in SF and find yourself looking out on a breathtaking view. Land's End Trail is something all visitors to SF should check out (I'm kind of scared to say that since I'd hate for this place to turn into another Fisherman's Warf).

It was super windy today but I feel like that just made the hike more enjoyable, it was amazing to watch the big waves breaking against the rocks at the bottom of the cliffs. I'll definitely be back and feel like I should add this to trail to my outdoor running schedule.
author: Bryan B.

description:
Lands End is officially a part of my weekly long runs. On a beautiful day, it provides a wonderful backdrop while scrambling up the long set of stairs. On rainy days, the trails provide addition challenge for dodging muddy puddles.

Did I mention there is a maze hidden away behind a cliff? It is awesome and should be visited by everyone. My friend and I were able to get to the center of the maze in 1 minute 15 seconds. Go on and try your luck.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Two years ago, the idea of "outdoor activity" horrified me.  Today, 5 miles is a "short" run for me, and I'm always looking to go camping and hiking (anyone?).

I've walked the Land's End Trail in the daytime a few times before it was re-done, since I used to live 3 blocks away.  Then I moved across the city a year ago and didn't go back until last night on an impromptu night hike.

Even though it was foggy across the bay (darn SF summer), we had no problem navigating the trail with a flashlight, and because most of it is pretty flat, you don't have to worry about falling into a hole or tripping on a rock.  It's such a nice change of pace from the hustle and bustle of downtown, and it'd been awhile since I'd experienced such silence.

If you're a scaredy-cat like me, you'll probably want to bring a few friends so you won't be scared at the thought of animals jumping out or creepers lurking in the bushes.  Not that I was, like, scared or anything.
author: Tori S.

description: The best walk/trail in San Francisco!!!  The views of the ocean are magnificent so bring your camera.  It won't be a private trail due to the high volume of people that take the trail from the Legion of Honor area to the Cliff House area, but it's definitely worth going whether you're visiting or live locally.  While on Lands End Trail, it makes you feel like you're not even in a big metropolitan city anymore.
author: Albie F.

description: Absolutely beautiful. I am definitely not a hiker and have knee problems, but took it slow and it was exactly what I needed (but if you are, I saw many runners on the way as well). I went alone early in the morning, which was a concern of mine (I'm a petite female) but it was no problem at all. Everyone was really friendly and there were many photo ops :)
author: Xue H.

description:
Simply, it's breathtaking.
Leads you all the way to mini beaches, baker beach, the old fort, then gg bridge.
LOTS of stairs and bugs.
Wear comfy tennis shoes!!
I highly recommend it here.

Starts to get busy around 12 in the afternoon.
author: Jae T.

description:
When my gf told me about hikes in the City, I was imagining walking up big streets that have staircases for sidewalks. Not this place.

Land's End is magical place. With the trail running on through a forest on the cliff's edge, ocean crashing below, this is the stuff dreams are made of. That is, if your dream is an escape from the hustle and bustle of city life.

The trail is well maintained in most parts. The views are stunning on a clear October day. (Yes, October is one of the best month's to visit San Francisco...Perfect weather.) There were not very many people on the trail, but enough that I wouldn't have been worried about a person walking by themselves.

There is a challenging hill with wide stairs. Since it had rained the night before, we enjoyed the smell of the dirt. The hike itself is about and hour and half round-trip. I would rate it as moderate because of that steep hill. It's not flat and easy. I did see some spry elderly people. Baby carriages are not a good idea no matter how welcoming the beginning of the path is. Also, dogs should be on leash! 

This is a place we'll be coming back to for years.

If you want to be reminded about what's so special about San Francisco, this is a good place to renew your faith in the City. Land's End is awesome and awe-inspiring.
author: Dave B.

description: This is a beautiful piece of the city but not a lot of people know about it apparently. There are a few trails and on the weekend it feels pretty safe with dogs and families walking around. There are beautiful views of the ocean and the golden gate bridge. If you've got folks visiting from out of town I recommend taking them here. The aroma of the plants adds to the visual experience. Even if you don't have a car you can easily get down here on the 38 bus route for just two bucks.
author: Yolanda Y.

description:
Ok, so this is the most amazing run I have ever been on in the two years I've lived in San Francisco. 
You start near Sutro Heights Park, go through Lands End, up through the most amazing housing you have ever seen (all with the Golden Gate bridge in the back ground), through China Beach and up to Baker Beach. You can run all the way to the Golden Gate bridge which is just beyond Baker Beach and then loop back down. The whole thing is about 7 miles, some hills, some steps, flat areas, shade and sun- ALL along the coast line.
I am so blown away at the beauty in this city and this run absolutely warmed my heart yet again. 
If you haven't already, you must at least walk this route- your appreciation for San Francisco is sure to grow!
author: Janell D.

description: so ive never been to this place...Saturday afternoon my mom and me are sitting at home not doing anything ...and I tell her and go checkout this place I found on yelp...and my ohh my...iam really glad I made that decision this place is just more than awesome...hiking, sightseeing, relaxing, family time, photography, golf ...this place comes with a package....I did not get a chance to cover the whole place but am returning very soon...wooohoooo!!!!
author: Pritika M.

description:
Having lived on 44th Avenue in the latter half of the 1990s, this was my near daily go-to trail .... weekday evenings and weekend mornings.  I usually started the walk with a stroll through Sutro Heights.  Then my partner and I would walk through to Land's End trail from the west end and make it all the way to the China Beach vicinity.  She would always want to visit the "million dollar homes" (now multi-millions) of Sea Cliff and stroll back along Clement Street so we could swing in the kid swings ... we're rather little people: she claims to be 4' 10" .... I claim to be 5' 2".  So we never stressed out the swings.  

This trail has many favorite spots for looking out across the Gate at the Bridge, the Marin Headlands and also out to sea.  

It's also easy to change plans quickly and dash up the many steps at the midpoint and cut across the little single track pathway and the golf course path to the Palace of the Legion of Honor.  It's possible to drop down from there through the Avenues to Yu Zhen for sushi ... or to the Golden Gate Park for further walking.  

I truly love this little circle of pathways and have traversed it surely 1,001 times for as many stories as Scheherazade can tell.
author: Em S.

description: Great hike, one of my favorite places to go to see the bridge. I started exploring the city a lot more lately, and found that this really has become one of my favorite scenic places. Near the end of the trail there is a passageway to "Deadman's viewpoint" you might miss it, but when you walk up during the time the sun sets the view is amazing. The area around just seems so natural, and the sun light over the water is purely beautiful. I give it 5 stars just for that view, it was just really serene.
author: Wells Y.

description: A wonderful hike and scenic outlook. Great views of Golden Gate Bridge. Every San Franciscan should know of it and very tourist should make it a mandatory stop in the itinerary.
author: Umair K.

description: Still my FAVORITE spot in all of San Francisco! Amazing how this exists in a city as crazy as San Francisco. You get a view of the waters and the golden gate bridge. This view is hard to beat.
author: Philip M.

description: Great trail, great views, and not that crowded. Please bear in mind that the conditions may be brutal in bad weather.
author: George T.

description: I will let your silence speak...I can see it, I can feel it, I can touch it, and I can also taste it.  Allow you to heal my heart so I can see clearly what yoy want me to see.  Show me you love me too.
author: Salonje R.

description:
As you can see me in my picture, I'm a big guy. Most hot days, i go to pool and just kill time. One of my close friend ask me to go this trail. I've heard this trail before. It is long. He has been campaigning me about this trail for few days. I basically went out of reason not to go there, so i went. I guess Him and his GF seems having fun there all day. I am not saying i didn't had fun. There was fun going there in my car. My stupid navigation didn't work so we had to cum all da way the other side of city. and we had to stop by at Safeway store so i had to get some munches AND we also had to go to Starbucks so we needed some caffeine before go to trail. Fine. that was three fitty five PM. That was it. Moment we got off da car, there was ENDLESS trail begun. I myself from Monterey. I've seen all those views. i don't even know how many times i've been to BigSur. I went so many time camping in Carmel highlands. and Carmel Vally. I used to live on 17mile Dr. I Hate those wave noise from ocean. OMG, There was 3 hour nonstop noise there. I don't even looks like i can do 3 hour hiking, i didn't have enough sleep night before, my leg and ankles are hurting like there is no tomorrow. I don't even know if i should go to work tomorrow or not??? all these Mofo can call me what The F**k they want. I just DO NOT do 3 hour hiking. I'm not design to do that. All that trail was BULL F**King SH*T. 

All i'm saying is MUNI better have extra weekend schedule for person who wants to give up those Endless trail early and there better be shuttle service so i can only walk half way or quarter way and be on shuttle the rest. That is all i'm saying.
author: Danny P.

description: Nice place to hike at. Great views of the bay/bridge
author: Jack J.

description:
I have a soft place in my heart for this trail.

This trail used to be part of my 6 mile routine run around the central Richmond area. It's one of the things I miss most since my boyfriend moved out of the city and I no longer frequent the Richmond area as much. It's a perfect trail-y jog complete with tourists-as-obstacles, stairs, sand, gorgeous views of the Pacific, and ample shade. I've taken many people here in all months and no matter how foggy it is, it's still a breathtaking view. Seriously, it's a gem. 

And it's a mild enough trail for your older, out-of-town relatives if they want to hike.

I miss it. Wish it existed on the East bay!
author: Debora L.

description:
Beautiful trail. Lots of hills, steps, and a little bit of an off-road feel. See the Golden Gate Bridge. See the Pacific Ocean. See the Palace of the Legion of Honor. See the coyote. 

What the crazy?

So I was happy wandering around with my then 5-month old puppy. Found a new trail, didn't know how far it would go. Sydney was getting tired, so I kinda wanted the trail to end soon. By the time I took a short cut behind the Legion of Honor to get back to Clement Street, I noticed what looked like maybe a German shepherd walking off leash.

But this was no German shepherd.

About 100 yards away it spotted us, and before you know it, was trotting over.  I've never come in contact with a coyote before. So I was pretty scared. And I'm sure to the coyote, Sydney was looking like a six-pack of Chicken McNuggets.  I hate MacDonalds. But I love chicken McNuggets.

Anyway, the sun was already going down, and soon the coyote was right behind us, maybe a good 50 feet away. Luckily there was a couple up ahead that I caught up to, and with that, the coyote disappeared.

I'm pretty sure an incident like this doesn't happen often, so for for most people, go ahead, it's an awesome hike.  But if you do decide to do land's end, please don't bring a bite-sized pup.
author: Tony L.

description:
5 stars. Period. 

p.s. Look for the ravens, pelicans, poppies in spring, seals/dolphins down in the water.
author: Ken L.

description:
This used to be such a great trail when it was an undiscovered gem and used mostly by locals.  

Now thanks to the Park Service putting up tons of trail markers and signage everywhere, and heavy promotion in guidebooks, this trail is completely overrun with tourists.  

Mind you this is mostly a SINGLE TRACK trail, which means you have to walk SINGLE FILE so others can pass by.  Naturally, every idiot group or intertwined couple walk side by side so no one can pass in either direction.  With such constant obstacles, good luck trying to go for a run on this trail.

Can't we have even one little miniscule part of the city to ourselves that isn't overrun with tourists?
author: SFnativeGal ..

description: GORGEOUS! If I lived closer I would definitely be more in shape because I'd come walk more since it's such a lovely trail. Lots of trees, flowers, ocean and nature to soak in. I went a bit late so didn't walk through the whole trail (a hiker told me it's around 5 miles?) Definitely coming back for the whole trail next time!
author: Christine C.

description:
Nothing new here, another 5-star review.  Took my first trot along the Land's End Trail this afternoon.  It's not the longest run, just a smidge over 3 miles, but I don't think there's a more beautiful run out there.  You're perched above the mouth to the Pacific, with views of Marin, the Golden Gate Bridge and tons of boats coming in and out.

There are a lot of strollers, so the run can be a bit stop-and-go, but there are some great stairs to hoof up and down to make up for the shorter distance.  Certainly a new staple in the workout regiment.
author: John R.

description: What a beutiful place. Nice long hike. I will definitely be back.
author: Grazi S.

description:
I enjoyed this trail. It's more of a leisure walk than a hike.  It was moderately crowded when I came here during Valentine Day weekend. The main trail is paved and very easy to walk on. I walked to the labyrinth and it was very cool! That spot provides a cool view of the GG bridge.

I think the best time to go is at least an hour before sunset. That way, you have time to check out the labyrinth and catch the sunset on the way back to the parking lot.
author: Kristina N.

description:
This is an awesome view and walk. You can't beat this because you get to see the left side of Golden Gate Bridge (while all the tourist are on the right side)

Definitely worth the walk, it's a short trail so enjoy!
author: Eric A.

description:
I am so, so lucky to live so close to this fabulous act of nature. I go here on my daily (more like bi-weekly or weekly, actually) jog. I love hiking here with friends as well. Gorgeous scenery everywhere--the Golden Gate Bridge, blue blue water, and lots of plants! You can also access side trails that lead you to various beaches, and the Sutro Bath Ruins (another favorite site in SF)!

A wonderful place to feel like you're not in a city.
author: Trish P.

description: It's definitely beautiful here.  Trails aren't too difficult in my opinion but definitely breathtaking.  Definitely bring your camera to take pics of everything.  It gets pretty busy here with lots of people coming and going...and I even saw some tour buses stop by as well.  I've only been here once but would definitely come back if I'm trying to go for a hike and be away from hot San Jose during hot unbearable summer days.
author: Kim D.

description:
Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful! One of the city's best walkable scenic routes. You get magnificent views of the city, the Golden Gate Bridge, Marin county, and more. On a sunny day, it's even prettier so choose your walks wisely :) 

A great place for a quick run or walk. Can get crowded on the weekends but haven't been phased by it.

At the trailhead, you can also choose to walk down to the Sutro Baths which I highly recommend. There's a sweet cave you can walk through and come out the other side - another view of the ocean and more rocks.

Best of all, FREE PARKING!!
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Like everyone else has already said, this place is AWESOME! The view is amazing, there is ample parking, dogs are allowed (only so many parks/trails allow dogs nowadays) and it's completely free! 

I believe this spot has become more of a touristy scenic walk and doesn't really count as a real hike because half of this trail is extremely man made (but nice!) with the cemented pavements and all. If I lived closer, I would come back on a more consistent basis. But regardless, I'll definitely come back (and bring the dog too).
author: Ede S.

description:
I've come to Land's End many times for hikes, and always enjoy it.  The trails are well maintained (although at times steep, rocky and there are stairs) and unobtrusive signs mark the way to specific landmarks.  I like the information plaques too.  

There are multiple places to park and pick up the trail.  The new parking lots above the Sutro Baths are one good place.  The recent additions of overlooks and new planting are great touches.  And you can't beat the views!  From the Marin Headlands all the way to the Golden Gate and past that into the Bay (depending on the fog of course).  

Be prepared for any sort of weather here, dress in layers!  But regardless of it's sunny or foggy, I love this trail.  For a leisurely walk with friends or a sweetie, or going for a workout on my own, it's great.

Today I successfully found the Labyrinth, hidden off the Mile Rock Beach offshoot trail.  LOTS of stairs down to the beach, but right before you hit the sand, take a right up to a ledge, and there you will find the labyrinth.  The rocks are a little scattered, but it was peaceful and beautiful.  A couple kids and tourists came along as I was walking, so if you're going to walk it as a meditation, be prepared for possible interruptions.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I came here with two friends to do a little hiking in San Francisco. Not knowing exactly what to expect, and only hearing such good things about this place (see below reviews)- I was pleasantly surprised! 

Near the Sutro Baths is a really cool cave with two openings where you can see the waves crashing in!

The actual trail is pretty short, but we went off the paved trail and romped around in the vegetation. THAT is the way to do it. The view is absolutely gorgeous! I'm use to seeing the Golden Gate Bridge from the bay side so it was really neat to see it from the Pacific Ocean side. 

I highly recommend going and romping around off trail.
author: Christine A.

description: Super fun, super easy hike!! Well maintained trail and signs clearly mark what you are going to be getting into.  Beautiful views of the bay and it's just a super nice trail to go on to try and get away from it all for a bit.
author: Paul M.

description:
This is my most favorite place in the city for a short walk.  From the parking lot off of Geary, you can walk to Sea Cliff and back (with a walk down to the beach) in about an hour and 15 minutes.  It's a great place to take out of town guests, as the trail is not that difficult.  You can also get there with the 38 bus as well.  Weekdays are much better than weekends, but it's not too bad on the weekends.  As far as I know, it's the only ocean
 walk, on the cliff, in the forest in the city.  I come here on a regular basis and take many out of town guests here.
author: Sameer D.

description: Great views of SF and on a clear day you can see the GG Bridge. It's an easy hike and the dogs will love it too. Make sure to cross the street and go to the park where you can see where Sutro house once stood.
author: Maverick W.

description:
One of my favorite areas of the city for a jog or walk.    The view the whole way is one of the best in the city, including different angles of the bay area.  It's also nice and rare to find a scenic dirt trail and away from paved paths in the middle of a city - embrace it.  

First time I did it was with a bike, but there are stairs in both directions so be aware.  There are a lot of areas where you see trek marks going off the trail into the wooded areas, but I didn't have my own bike so I played it safe with the dirt path.
author: Lindsey M.

description: This trail provides GREAT views!   I was constantly stopping to take pictures of the GG bridge, the ocean, the cliffs etc.  It's a pretty good distance too.   If you don't explore the other trails and just stay on the main trail, it's probably close to 3 miles round trip.  We walked parts and ran others.  We went down steps and up steps!  It was a pretty good workout.  There's a ton of interesting history along the route too.  Parking wasn't difficult as we got there before noon.  When we left it did seem that parking was more sparse.  I really should make it out here for often.
author: Dina H.

description:
Another trail (2.5 miles). You  can either park by Sutro Baths/Cliff House or near a residential area on El Camino del Mar and 32nd Ave and walk.

There are some semi-steep terrains but for the most part, it's good for a hike and gives you a good sweat.

Walk down toward MILE ROCK/BEACH is where you will see the "Labyrinth"
author: Jboogie L.

description: To get away.. without really getting away.  Awesome weekend hiking spot.
author: Mel G.

description:
Man, I had a great time hiking this trail over the weekend and recommend this to anyone.  It is beautiful out there.  

I started the hike at the windmill (corner of Fulton & Great Hwy) and started north where I found a set of stairs leading to the path that took me above Sutro Baths and then around the Lands End trail to the Golden Gate.

The vistas are amazing and KUDOS to all the work they've done out there in preventing erosion and saving the natural plants etc.  Wear your hiking boots and bring a camera!!!!
author: Linda H.

description:
Well, you have to climb over a wood thing to get there now.  I guess they are afraid of people falling off the cliff, and they should be.  The path has really disintegrated A LOT in the last decade.  I was amazed when I went there a month ago.  I was afraid my mom was going to fall.  This is my favorite view of the bridge at night.  Grab some 40s and your friends and BE CAREFUL and go down the path and talk and look at the bridge and listen to the fog horns.  

Beautiful.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I can't believe I've been living here for almost 2 years and it's taken me this long to visit this part of town.  

I'd heard about this trail earlier from some friends who went, but didn't think anything of it.  Then lately, I've been on this kick to go out on weekends, get some fresh air, and maybe go to some areas of town I hadn't been yet to do some urban "hiking".  After a failed attempt a couple of weeks ago (where the foul cold weather encouraged us to go to a bar instead), I thought this weekend would be perfect.

And it was.

The trail starts at Point Lobos Ave and El Camino Del Mar at one end (if you follow the road past the Cllff House and on up the hill to the first intersection, that's it) then follows the coast through Lincoln Park, past the Legion of Honor, and comes out at end of the Park at El Camino del Mar and 23rd Ave.

If you start at Point Lobos end, it's flat, paved and wide (wheel friendly: wheelchairs, strollers, or bikes) with a great lookout point where you can see the GG Bridge.  As you progress the paved path gives way to a still very easy dirt path (however, not so good for wheels unless you are on a bike), down a couple of steps, then you're behind the Legion of Honor.  There's a side route down to a beach.  Lots of steps but well worth it for the view.  If you continue along the main path there are many more steps.  Or if you want, you can cut up to the Legion of Honor  (recommended for cyclists).

Pretty crowded on nice weekends so probably not the best trail for runners or cyclists.
author: Jean K.

description: When I came here I didn't know that this was gonna be a long hike. I was thinking more along the lines of taking a "stroll" ... BOY WAS I WRONG! Get prepared to get your butt, thighs, and calves moving! Also be prepared to expect your body SORE AS HECK! When I came here I was carrying about two HEAVY cameras which made the hike a bit worse but I must say that I got some pretty darn amazing photos!! The hike is long and strenuous (if you haven't exercised in about a year) ... heh heh, I should really start working out again... all an all, I can't wait to come back!
author: Susie N.

description:
Lovely, lovely, lovely easy trail for walking (and I guess running, if you do that, but I don't). The area is also littered with hilarious but I'm sure well-intentioned warning signs that provide excellent periodic humor (here's a sampling: "CLIFF AND SURF AREA EXTREMELY DANGEROUS. People have been swept from the rocks and drowned.")

If you want to conclude the end of your walk with a visit of the Legion of Honor museum, as I had once planned to do, budget a sufficient amount of time. By the time I arrived, the museum was closing in only twenty minutes so it didn't seem worth the price of admission. Still, I got to take photos of the very beautiful building.
author: Ada T.

description:
San Franciscans have and can live the good life when the weather is beautiful. Although it seems like many of those days are few and far between, when it is picturesque, sunny and warm, San Francisco is a ten.  Lands End Trail is another example of a San Francisco ten.

Nestled behind the Lincoln Golf course, next to Sea Cliff, and near the Legion of Honor, you can feel like you are in the woods and with nature.  The stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge, watching the waves crash the rocks and the rocky beaches, smelling the Eucalyptus trees, seeing the beautiful wildflowers takes you to a happy happy place and you can't help loving life after wards.  After breathing that fresh air and sweating out all of your impurities, you feel like a fresher, rejuvenated person. And, it is all free, compliments of our park system! 

This is the good life.
author: Natalie S.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite spots to take a walk in SF.  Whether to work out, get some air, hangout with a friend, or just wander and think.  The scenery is beautiful and if you happen to visit on a beautiful day, you can see across the bay, the Golden Gate Bridge, and more.  This trail is also located nearby Ocean Beach and Golden Gate Park.  

It's usually cold so it would be wise to bring a jacket or sweatshirt.  On warmer days, this place is packed.  You'll find people jogging, biking, walking their dogs, or tourists taking in the breathtaking views of coastal SF.  There are other trails off the main path, either up the hill farther into the trees or down to the rocky beaches.  

If you follow the residential streets all the way down past the end of the trail you can actually walk to China Beach and Baker Beach.  It takes a couple hours to walk from the Land's End Trail parking lot to Baker Beach, but if you have the time I highly suggest packing a snack, water, a camera, a friend and enjoying the walk.  

In terms of safety, there are some roped areas to ensure no one falls off the cliff, so if you're scared of heights, some spots might intimidate you.  There are signs to be aware of coyotes, but I haven't run into any (fingers crossed!)  I wouldn't suggest walking here in the dark, and it would be wise to stay aware of your surroundings if walking alone since the main path can get narrow and there are a lot of trees and bushes.  

Overall, a beautiful SF spot that locals and tourists alike enjoy.  Love it here.
author: Karina C.

description:
Gosh this trail is what I needed today. I just got back feeling very refreshed and in tune with myself. This morning, I wasn't feeling too "cheery" and while I was in the shower I decided I should go check out a trail. Fort Miley came first to mind and I'm so glad it did. Must have been fate. So I got my backpack, grabbed my sister and went for it.

Beautiful day in the city and what better way to spend it than outside, right. Plus I love how the greatest things in life are truly FREE. No one can buy that breathtaking view or the feeling you get when you're on that small hike. I walked and walked, taking pics after pics. I think there's like 3 or 4 official named trails to go on, but there are plenty more man-made trails that you can wonder off on. Go ahead, try it. It's safe. 

Instead of going down to the beachy area, my sister and I decided to walk the other way. I'm glad we did because after you go down the kinda long set of stairs than up and glance over the edge. TAAAA DAAAA! you found it. It comes out of nowhere, well at least for me and is GORGEOUS. 

My sis and I took pics of the circle of rocks, which we kept referring to it as the "sign". Than we wondered around and it's cool cus there's the 2 benches that you can sit on and watch the view or take pics. Everyone on the trail is at ease and very nice ( who wouldn't be)

This place is definitely a place to go when you feel to stressed or just want to appreciate mother nature. Yes, this place is the best =)
author: Sarina I.

description: Easy hike along the rocky west coast between Sutro baths and the GG. Great views, good for kids, dogs, running, etc.
author: Kevin H.

description: Truly a gem in San Francisco,   I was visiting here from Los Angeles, and my friends took me on a walk here.   The view of the GG bridge and the Marin Headlands were wonderful, and everyone around was taking pictures.   We walked all the way to Sea Cliff and it was amazing because you feel like you are on a country path, because there are no cars, not even the sight of cars.   Only the sounds of the surf and the birds. Great!
author: Axa M.

description: Stunning views almost the whole way through. I loved hiking this trail! We got lucky and came on a day with zero fog and warm temperatures. Parking at the Lookout was easy, there's also an upper lot in case the one by the visitor center is full. It was nice to start at Sutro Baths and admire that before getting on with the hike. The hike back will take you past Legion of Honor, which is a nice sight. I didn't love walking through the parking lot area, found that kind of weird and tacky, but what can ya do. Overall it's a very easy hike and I highly recommend it for out of town visitors and Bay Area folk alike.
author: Lydia W.

description: Absolutely the best of golden gate park area. Avoid stroller on this trail at all costs.
author: Krish C.

description: Breathtaking cliff views, overgrown wild flowers and fresh ocean air at Lands End are reasons I'm getting to love SF.  (NY is still my No. 1, but all this easy access to nature is super exciting!) The trail is easy going; great for jogging and leisurely hikes. Make sure you bundle up. Winds are crazy strong and heavy fogs roll in with little warning.
author: Sabrina F.

description: Beautiful views. Easy hike. At trail end, a few more steps to China Beach in the Sea Cliff neighborhood.
author: Inigo M.

description:
This is my favoritest place in SF.  It's a beautiful trail along the edge of the peninsula, between the Golden Gate Bridge and Ocean Beach.

For some reason, not many people come here.  It's great for running, because of the low traffic, and the absence of bicyclists.  Here and there, you'll find people who think the leash laws don't apply to them, and so loose dogs will sometimes chase you.

The downside is that the trail is very rough at points, so you can't bring disabled or elderly family there.
author: Des Esseintes I.

description: What a great, great trail.  This is better than going to the Golden Gate Bridge and taking pictures there.  We parked at the Land's End Look Out, and walked down to  Louis for lunch.  After that, we went back up to the trail head and took off around the corner towards the Golden Gate.  I can not even describe the views... you go from forest, to cliffs, to sea, to bay.  I am so sad it took me so long to find this - it's amazing!  As mentioned, it's an easy hike, with only a bit of stairs.  It was a great way to start out our annual trip to the city, and I would do it again in heart beat.
author: Shelby B.

description: Great place to go hiking. That's if you can hang. I live here and yet I have not finished all the trails that they have got to walk on. Lastly, I love the views and cold weather. Perfect hiking spot!
author: J C.

description: Love this trail! Went here for the first time last week and it was great! The trail isn't very hard, perfect for a nice stroll in SF. I saw a lot of families with kids and kids in strollers. If you go further out, you reach these stairs and they are killer if you don't stretch ahead of time, like me. I cramped, haha. Other than that, I would definitely come back to this trail. Great tourist attraction because you get to see beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Lots of people in the beginning of the trail, but the more you walk, the less people there are and I went on a Saturday. Parking wasn't too bad either for a Saturday, so I imagine there would be plenty during the week.
author: Faye M.

description: As the other reviewers all put it, beautiful and stunning.  Overall, a pretty doable hike with amazing views of the Golden Gate, shipwrecks, forest, and rocky beaches.  The helpful signage throughout the trail points out the different flora and fauna as well as other noteworthy facts.  Towards the north end, you'll be spit out near the Legion of Honor and wide open fields.  True to the au-natural nature of this place, no pit stops or trash cans along the way, so be sure to prepare accordingly.  We brought our dog and people overall seemed dog-friendly.
author: Tara C.

description: Labyrinth exists and it is beautiful.  If some punk destroys it again, it will be rebuilt. That is the way these things work.
author: David S.

description: This has to be one of the best hiking trails in the world, with the phenomenal views, consistently pleasant climate, and just-right end-to-end distance and elevation changes.  I've come here a few times, and every time I surprise myself by the new things and the beautiful serenity that I find during my hike.  It is the perfect foil for my stressful day job, and I will definitely come back here more often on weekends and whenever possible to destress and recharge for the workweek ahead.
author: Josh Q.

description:
I am a poor college student. That means I like parks, I like walks, I like nature (aka I like  free stuff) and I like experiencing new things. The hike is not difficult--more like a nice stroll with amazing views, but the beauty of the bridge is absolutely stunning. I walked, I talked and I enjoyed the company on a lovely San Francisco afternoon.

Overall, there's not much you can say. Wear appropriate shoes and bring a camera, because everything about this trail is perfect. I really just don't have the words to further describe it.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
So Land's End was on the "pro-side" on my list as I slowly calculated and analyzed the differences between San Francisco and New York. I was debating whether or not to move back to San Francisco (where I was born and raised) from Queens, New York.

Being close to nature, having places where I can reflect, relax, and ground myself were goals I had in the top 5 of my list. The image that came to mind as I wrote that description was Land's End. 

I remember coming here many years ago with someone I was dating at the time and working out our relationship troubles. There was something about being among the trees and foliage while watching the waves hit the rocks and the Golden Gate Bridge in the distance that helped us calm down, concentrate, and not attempt to yell at each other. We talked and walked along the trail which not only helped us let out steam physically and emotionally, but it helped ground us at the same time. We would realize that our problems were so miniscule, that the world offered so much, and how we took a lot for granted. 

Although that relationship has been over years ago, and I would hide my face if I ran into him anywhere today, the lesson from my experience was how valuable this place really is. Needless to say I've brought others there since then and every time I feel even more connected to the world.

California, you must continue to conserve and preserve your natural wonders like Land's End Trail. Your residents will appreciate and love you for it.
author: Catherine M.

description:
This is indeed a wonderful, gorgeous trail with a spectacular bay view the entire way. There's also a view of the Golden Gate Bridge if you're walking in the easterly direction.  It includes a good workout for the heart with the long series of steps in the middle of the hike.

My favorite part had also been the large parking lot at the end of El Camino Del Mar which, in my opinion, offers an incomparable view into the Pacific during cloud-covered days. Too bad the parking lot is closed for construction this recent time I came. I know the westernmost part of the trail had been undergoing reworking and improvements. Maybe the current parking lot work is a part of the overall effort.
author: H K.

description:
July is not a good month to be living in the Central Richmond.

The weather is a total mindfuck.  Each day I leave downtown at 6 PM and it's sunny.  Cross Van Ness and it starts getting foggy.  Over Divisadero and up the hill, it just gets worse and worse.  By the time I get cross Masonic, it might as well be February in London.

However, this is offset by being a 10 minute walk to the Land's End Trail during the month of August.  I mean wow.  I can walk this trail back and forth for hours and never get tired.  There are some steep peaks marked dangerous and I love walking out on them and looking down.  If you've got the time, take the stairs down to the maze and hit the beach at low tide.  The wrecked ship is cool, but more surreal is the old bathhouse that collapsed on to the beach several years ago.  

Another little game I like to play is to time the cargo ships coming in to the bay vs. leaving.  They travel about twice as fast when they're going back to Asia - thanks to having nothing to carry.  Yay trade deficit!
author: John H.

description:
Fan of the city?  Want to get in a good hike and upgrade your photo porfolio?  Spectacular views, caves (I felt like a Goonie), love this place!  
Take pix of the Golden Gate bridge, Sutro baths and read a bit of history on this gem.  Careful certain areas not for small children as one can slip on very narrow paths.  Don't need an oopsie on this adventure!!
author: Chellen G.

description:
The Lands End Trail is a perfect way to escape the city, within the city.  It's even accessible by transit, within walking distance of the 38 and 18 bus routes.

At the Eagle Point trailhead, you may notice a drop in temperature and an increase in wind speed, so you already feel like you're entering a different kind of place.

The open expanse of the Pacific Ocean beyond the bluffs can take your breath away.  Beautifully framed views of the Golden Gate Bridge serve as one of the few cues reminding you that you're not far from the bustle of city life.

It's a great place to take a leisurely hike or sit and rest for a while on a warm, sunny day; still beautiful, and maybe a little more mysterious, when the fog is rolling in.
author: Jamie T.

description: Gorgeous, easy to moderate hike. On a clear day this hike definitely gives you some of the most beautiful views of the ocean / Golden Gate Bridge you can get in SF. With the exception of one BIG set of stairs, this is a very easy hike. Kid and "non-athlete" friendly. Highly recommend!
author: Alicia B.

description: Freaking beautiful.  Can't believe such a cool place is so close to the city.
author: David P.

description: A perfect place to go for a run.. the scenery is so amazing that I ended up taking off my ipod and just ran with the sound of the ocean in the background. There are numerous vantage points to gaze into the rocky sides of the park meeting the ocean or beautiful viewpoints of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Henry W.

description:
A hidden gem of glory!

The trails and vistas are beautiful beyond belief. It's a great place to take a date or a puppy or both.
author: N M.

description: peaceful, pretty even when it's foggy (seems spooky or romantic looking to me) ..  and smells like natural eucalyptus.
author: Muriel D.

description:
A very easy trail at the beginning from the Sutro Baths parking lot but as it closes near the Eagle Point bifurcation, the paved road becomes a dirt road.  Dogs are present with owners but not all owners abide with the leash requirement nor pick up after their dogs.  Bad owners!
Do watch out for the poison oak along the side of the road.

It's a great way to spend all day on this trail, get exercise and rejuvenate from the fresh air.  If you plan to spend the day here, pack a lunch to enjoy it while sitting on one of the wooden benches or look-outs along the way.  The ocean view is free and awesome.
author: Ry T.

description:
Misty, mysterious, murderous... 

An evening walk through this trail was pleasant; the noises of the city are far away and the quiet sounds of wildlife are comforting. My first experience with the trail was spooky, as the fog was rolling in on the horizon. The path can be uneasy and there are some steep hillsides and cliffs--just a trip over a branch away. Signs warn of imminent death from risky diversions from the path. Better than: "Gorgeous Views: Do Not Enter." It's also unsettling that the vast, swallowing ocean is so near. But I did see a cute pod of dolphins. And the views...I ain't never seen nothing this good back east in Virginia.

I'm looking forward to returning at a sunnier time of day to see the baths and the shipwrecks. This tip of the land does not disappoint.
author: Allison B.

description:
The hike is beautiful and the views are spectacular...but I hate that it's so cold every time I go there! Even when it's sunny out, I still have to wear a couple layers and a sweatshirt or jacket over the layers!

Who knew San Francisco would have such amazing trails where you can hike and enjoy the views?
author: V M.

description: A nice trail to be able to get some pretty pictures of the bridge and nature. The trail isn't too bad, but your shoes will get dirty and filled with some sand, so prepare! We had wonderful weather for it and it was not too hot or windy. This trail is also cool because you can go off of it to the Legion of Honor and check out the museum before returning to the trail. It's a short trail, so completely doable.
author: Aly M.

description: This was a really cute place to just walk around and experience nature without too vigorous of a work out.  We kind of just stood by the Sutro baths (and saw a baby sea otter!!!) and then walked to watch the waves hit the rocks - breathtakingly beautiful.  We went on a mini hike as well, just strolling through the woods and it was so much fun to explore!
author: Rebecca D.

description: Lands End trail is a San Francisco gem! I only recently discovered this place and it has quickly become one of my regular hiking places. It is especially nice during the summer. And there are some amazing views of the Golden Gate. I often hike the trail alone but there are always tons of people around so I always feel safe. Along the main trail there are some smaller ones that tapper off to explore. I discover something new every time!
author: Alice K.

description: Wow so beautiful! Everywhere you turn, there's beauty. The Pacific ocean, cliffs, rock islands, trees, flowers.. it never stops. It's truly like heaven on Earth. Gorgeous views of the Golden Gate bridge as you approach Eagles Point on the eastern end of the trail. On the western end by Sutro baths.. breathtaking views of the ocean. Esp on a lightly foggy day.. it's like a dreamscape. So beautiful!!! The trails are on the easy side. But lots of steep climbs, esp if you take the trail that takes you to the beach. That was quite a workout! Lots of people go jogging, or walk their dogs, or walk, or sightsee. I'm newly local and even though there are lots of tourists, I plan to come here as often as I can. Just pure beauty!!
author: Vol T.

description: Beautiful. This is a treat for me every weekend as I run across the city. The views are incredible, the challenge of the track is moderate+, and it dumps you in Seacliff, which is a really nic place to take the next step. I find that the casual hikers are super aware aout letting runners pass (vs. GGB where evryone is state fair stunned and unable to move) as they make their way to a long run toward GGB.
author: Chuck H.

description:
The best trail for walking and jogging in SF - it's usually not crowded, there's ample free parking, the trees provide shade even during the hottest days, and the sound of the foghorn adds a serene feel as you gaze at the coastline and the waves crashing against the rocks.  While the streetcar no longer runs along the trail, the incredible view remains along with the wide paths that are perfect for a stroll or jog.  The walk is suitable for all ages and for dogs as well.  

You're far enough away from the traffic to really feel like you're in another place and yet you're close enough to the city that you're not going to run into a snake or mountain lion.

Not only is Land's End Trail gorgeous, it has history as well; you may be able to spot shipwrecks off the coast and the memorial as well as the remains of the bullet ridden USS San Francisco WWII cruiser can be found in the Vista Point parking lot off 48th Avenue.  

I usually start at Vista Point and jog over to Mile Rock Beach where I climb up and down the stairs a couple of times and jog up to the cliff area where the labrinyth is.   Then I continue on, up the other flight of stairs, down the winding path and eventually to the end of the trail by Eagle's Point.  If you wanted to keep going, you could jog up to the Legion of Honor (turn right) or jog down to China Beach (turn left).

The trail is about 3 miles round trip.  The parking lot on Merrie Way was recently finished, providing even more free parking.
author: Lolia S.

description: Highly recommend going a little before sunset. Absolutely stunning
author: David K.

description: Best trail in SF - nice coastal views of the entrance to the bay; always felt safe - I run it at night too
author: Vik B.

description: Beautiful views of Golden Gate and the ocean. If you stay on the main trail, its a relatively easy hike -- but if you choose to veer off into side paths the treck becomes more difficult (e.g really steep steps). However, the hike only becomes really worth it if you do choose to adventure off the main path to enjoy the incredible views.
author: Anjali M.

description:
Nice trail.  Great views.  Too bad there's a sign at Painted Rock that reads:

"DO NOT ENTER: PEOPLE HAVE FALLEN TO THEIR DEATHS".

That just makes people more interested in crossing the barrier.
author: Justin C.

description: So lovely! If you're not one for stairs start at the trailhead and go until you can't, or start at the end of the golf course and do the same.  There's some of the best views you could imagine.
author: Ramy S.

description: love this trail.  too bad sf is so windy
author: Anna W.

description:
I don't have a lot of money. I don't have cable. I don't speak Italian. I can't drive stick. My share values have tanked. I don't smile enough. I'm not particularly well-read. I don't use the left side of my brain enough. I don't own an iPhone. I don't understand ledger sheets. I don't like the Pixies (I'm sorry). I don't know why.

But I do love the view.
author: Keane L.

description: Awesome !!!   Loved this hike !!!  No thing bad to say ! Not possible !! Easy and fun !!!
author: Adenna S.

description:
I love coming here.  Its a great hike with wonderful views.  I recommend the sutro baths and Mile Rock beach.   

A lot of great hills, cliffs, views of Pacific Ocean.
author: Raja D.

description:
Even with the fog and wind chill this place ROCKS!!

I went for a jog here with my friend Serah who pretty much kicked my ass.  She's like an energizer bunny. She keeps going, and going, and going...

I had to practically beg her to take a breather.  

When we finally did get a chance to rest I took in the scenery it's amazing!  I could only imagine how great it would be when the weather co-operates.

Never a bad sight with the exception of pile of dog crap we encountered along the paved trail.  Shame on you dog owner!

It felt great, fresh air, cleared my mind, light sweat, Serah telling me to stop being a "b*tch" and keep up.  Yeah, good times. =D
author: Sun T.

description: So peaceful & Absolutely beautiful!!!  I have been going to San Francisco & only this year did I discover Land's End. What a discovery!  Spectacular views & calming. The Legion of Honor Museum was a great ending attraction to the trail. From Union Square, the Muni #38 then #18 takes you to the Legion.
author: Terri P.

description:
A great addition to your catalog of runs- you forget you're in SF and feel more like you're in Oregon. Suggest heading up there on foggy days when it won't be as congested and you'll get in some good alone time. 

Ditch the headphones on this one.
author: Rachael W.

description:
My grandpa used to take a walk here everyday for the past 30+ years, today was the first day I took the torch from him and began to run the trail as my daily jog.

Everything my grandpa told me about this trail is true, the views are amazing, the sea breeze just rolls into your lungs, and the trail is a historical land mark. I can see myself running this trail for a long time, not only because it reminds me of my grandfather but because it's an amazing part of the city.

p.s. but if you're jogging, mind the rocks, rolled my ankle this morning. : \

[APPROVED]
author: Eric T.

description:
Sometimes you find yourself angrily rushing about the Financial District getting to and from work, just trying to stay alert enough not to get run over by a bus crossing Market. And you forget that you are just miles away from the Pacific ocean and the beauty of Land's End. 

On clear days I love nothing more than to take the long drive up the Great Highway and park at the Land's End trail and take the gorgeous hike around the Sutro Baths and Fort Miley headed to the breathtaking views of the GG bridge. Whenever out of town visitors come they aways want to see the GG bridge and I find myself forgetting just how pretty it actually is, until I do this short hike and see the views for myself. The trail is great and the views are stunning, and if you take the time to read the plaques you can learn about the ship wrecks and light houses that were in the area. When you look out to the ocean you really feel like you are at the edge of the world, and not just the edge of San Francisco. All and all, this is a great place to relax and take visiting family or friends to show them another side of the city.
author: Dana H.

description: This is a very nice easy walk/hike along the coast. There are some parts that are a little bit steep and on sand, so make sure to bring the proper walking shoes.
author: Scoot S.

description:
Way back when we were young men, my friend Paublo would make some insane comments which I always disagreed on:

"Democrats are evil"
"Rush Limbaugh for president"
"You're going to hell"

We got to know each other better on an Arizona road trip. Paublo was one with the desert and would insistently talk about the cloud formations over the barren miles of road before us. I could hear the satisfaction in his voice when he remarked on the variation of clouds in the distance, all while grinning at the sky. 

I would be thinking, "Are you  f#%*!#@g  retarded?" 

Instead, I wanted him to be more like me, i.e. naturally impressed by gorgeous cars, amazing architecture, exotic vacations and expensive restaurants. I thought Paublo was a simpleton for being pleased with the mundane. Kind of like that character from Of Mice and Men. 

It dawned on me much later that BECAUSE Paublo was easily impressed by the simple--such as a the splash of ocean against your feet, the turning color of leaves, or the way clouds reflect on a sunset--that MORE happy moments came his way because he didn't take for granted the simple treasures. How much MORE did quiet moments of enjoying the earth, wind and sky come his way each day?  The answer . . . they came his way MORE than mine. Paublo wasn't foolish at all, and he remains one of my best friends to this day. 

This day, I'm glad I don't have to drive to Yosemite or the Grand Canyon to take in a million dollar view. On a clear day, I can just head out to Land's End to take it in as much as I want.
author: Teddy B.

description:
This is a sacred and *secret* spot that I never knew until very recently. The stairs going down is an excellent exercise. I started running then turning into walking for about 6 rounds, before almost tumbling down on my legs, which I am still recovering from. A great workout spot, nonetheless. My out of breath at the 4th round scared some who thought it was from just one trip! oops...

But the view from the Mile Rock Beach is spectacular and breathtaking. It's quiet as it's not too packed, but not as quiet as you listen to the raging crashing waves, invigorating and refreshing, yet soothing all at the same time.

Definitely great to have some hot and sour soup on Clement Street post workout after chilling on the beach front!
author: T L.

description:
Land's End Trail is a breath of fresh air.  You feel a million miles away from the craziness of the city, views are spectacular, and it's yet another reason why I love San Francisco...not many cities I've been to have views like this.  I go running here a lot and the trail goes all the way from Cliff House to the Golden Gate Bridge.  If you haven't been, definitely put it on your list!  

Here's a website with more info on the trail: http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/park.asp?park=52#History
author: Beth J.

description:
When I lived in the Richmond, one of my favorite things to do on a weekend morning was walk/run the Land's End trail.  The view is gorgeous, it's not crowded, and you can truly forget that you're in the city.  If you've never been, GO!

I went back today for the first time in almost a year.  They've made "improvements" to the trail, mostly on the west side, the part that starts at the parking lot just above the Cliff House.  They cleared a lot of trees, widened the path, and put in several concrete viewing areas.  I have to admit that I kind of preferred it when it was a bit wilder, eroding trails and non-native vegetation and all.  Still, it's good that the wider, paved paths have made at least part of the trail more accessible for the elderly, handicapped, etc.  

A note to the guy on the bike: dude, 99% of the people on this trail are on foot, and most don't seem spry enough to jump out of your way as you zoom by, especially on the narrower parts of the trail.  Slow down!  Oh, and I'm pretty sure I saw a "no bikes" sign at one point...
author: DD B.

description:
Beautiful view. Many different trails to get lost on. Get it lost on. Man I am crazy fun.

It's a simple trail, anyone should be able to do it as long as they know how to breath deeply and walk.

Good for a "get to know you" date.

SFCritic
author: David J.

description:
My favorite walk/hike ever for these reasons:

a) views, views, views
b) leashless dogs
c) no bikes
d) side trails that lead you to even better views
e) easy parking
f) restaurants nearby for when you are done; park chalet or cliff house
author: Veronica P.

description:
This is my first non-food-related review.  The Land's End Trail is so magnificent that, though I was only going to write about food on Yelp to keep myself focused, it compelled me to write about it. 

*Sigh*....The Land's End Trail makes me wish I were a poet, so I could do justice expressing how amazing it is. Alas, as a laywoman, I can only list out ordinary adjectives to praise this place: amazing, spectacular, breathtaking...DIVINE... 

The two hour leisurely walk on the trail made me grateful and fully appreciate life. It reminded me of how fortunate I am, and what an amazing city San Francisco is. Thank you.  

As a practical matter, I also appreciate that it's really easy to get to (easy parking on Sunday, too).
author: Nana N.

description:
Day or Night, Land's End Trail is amazing. Truthfully I really like it at night with the Cliffhouse and Veteran's Hospital all lit up.  The maze is also a  highlight though the steps down and up really make you earn the trip. It's also a great place to take someone who is visiting the city. 

If I was homeless I would totally live here and mess with all the regular people.
author: Allan R.

description: One of our favorite spots love to go there.   We have been there on cold windy days and on clear sunny days always something spectacular.    Different flowers in bloom or take a little different route.  Bring water and some good walking shoes and a camera pictures of the Golden Gate Bridge are priceless.
author: Grace F.

description: I love Land's End Trail so much I'm considering moving to it and living in one of those overgrown thickets leading to a mysterious hole. You know, the ones that you want to go and explore, but don't because you aren't sure if it's an animal burrow or a bum's house? You can explore my future house burrow without fear of stepping on a syringe though. This isn't Golden Gate Park, after all.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
This is one of the reasons why i love SF.  

It's gorgeous nature hike minutes away from the craziness of the city.  The views of the golden gate bridge and the beach are ridiculous, there is one path that takes you up to a labyrinth which looks over the ocean cliff.   I've never felt so more at peace then here
author: Kris M.

description: beautiful trail. just absolutely a gorgeous place to hike and take pics.  Definitely a lot of stairs but its not too bad in my opinion. definitely dont wear any nice shoes because my white jordans got a bit muddy and bring water lol i definitely forgot to bring water and after a couple hours, i did get very thirsty.  The man made labyrinth at the very end is just awesome; especially where its located. The maze labyrinth is like at the edge of cliff which just made it that much more awesome of a trip. If you got the time and if the weather is decent, shouldnt even question about checking it out.
author: Logan T.

description: This is my favorite spot in all of San Francisco. I can't think of a better way to spend my weekend than hiking or jogging Land's End. The hike is short and easy with wonderful views of Golden Gate Bridge when the weather is clear (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=4FcfCT4WFGdNI_E09htphQ&select=JCO34h6AiKjbHYa4_92LXw). I like to park at the newly renovated/expanded lot (free parking), hike until I reach the stairs to Mile Rock Beach, go down the stairs to where it branches off to this cool labryinth (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=4FcfCT4WFGdNI_E09htphQ&select=YG0QxXMJlwJB_KY90jvOjw) and then turn back. (I used to make it all the way to Eagle's Point but after the restoration they took out all the stairs I loved that led to a spot with great views of China Beach). On the way back, I take the path to the cliff overlooking Sutro Baths which is nice, esp. at sunset (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=4FcfCT4WFGdNI_E09htphQ&select=ZX2H4cYvzRUHzuYktnDc9g). This also  brings you to the top of the Sutro Baths cave, and you can continue on down to the Baths (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=4FcfCT4WFGdNI_E09htphQ&select=5-3Md3QaPpTyfBzUTQEK1w). You can walk down to the Baths from the entrance between the Cliff House and Lou's as well (check out the poster in Lou's window for how the Baths looked when they first opened in 1896). Then I hop over to Sutro Park to catch my breath on top of the parapet while overlooking where the city meets the ocean (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=4FcfCT4WFGdNI_E09htphQ&select=gpiwPqZ79L9BEY51l5MRmA). If I have time I head down to Ocean Beach to the Dutch Windmill at Wilhelmina Garden, which is esp. beautiful in the spring when the tulips are in bloom.
author: Diana B.

description:
I've said it a million times, but the best part of living in a place like San Francisco is that it never runs out of things to do. In this case, I'd heard of Land's End (no, not the catalog/clothing company), but hadn't really heard stories of people having gone there.

In a weekend quest to combat the unhealthy weekend food and copious amounts of wine and liquor, Tara decided we should go for a walk this morning, and chose Land's End as our destination. Despite the chilly December morning air, it couldn't have been a better idea.

I also love further getting to know San Francisco geography, and Land's End is a peculiar part of the puzzle. I knew that the northwest corner of the city was perhaps the most interesting, geographically. I knew that between Sutro Baths and Baker Beach the coastline became, well, complex. But being at Land's End gives you a good understanding of exactly how complex it becomes.

There are high, steep cliffs rising right out of the water, and negotiating sharp curves and crags. It was lush as hell today, December 7, so I'm gonna go ahead and assume that it's always like this. In addition, there are multiple revegetation efforts all over the park. It's refreshing to see them reintroducing native plants in such a beautiful area.

The trail, or as much of it as we walked, takes you along side the coast, and high about it. There are alternating areas of openness and canopied overhangs. There are, of course, INCREDIBLE ocean and bay views, including great angles on the Golden Gate Bridge.

Land's End is a great way to get to know an amazing bit of nature left in this otherwise most-urban of cities. It makes for a great weekend daytime outdoor activity.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Ingredients:

Wind swept Monterey cypresses
winding foot trails
billows of ice plants
shimmering water
Sutro Baths remains
the sun setting
low fog
flocks of pelicans

Shake gently.  Sip & enjoy nature at her best.  Even better when shared with another.
author: Jen L.

description:
We were in the process of scouting out different hiking places to impress my mother-in-law.  She visits once a year.  Two places that were very memorable in her mind were the hikes at Marin Headlands and Half Moon Bay.  I was determined to find something that would at least match that, and I think this places fits in perfectly with the plan!  I hope that when she comes, it will offer a sunnier more pleasant view, but even in overcast weather and wind, it's still amazing here!  

It takes no work at all to be close to the coast, and though there were some stairways that tired us out, that was only the case because both the husband and I are so out of shape.  

This hike was reminiscent of a hike in Hawaii.  It had some of the elements that I can recall, such as forest and trees, the coast, some archways, even what I joked to be black sand, though really it wasn't.  Hahaha.   When we hiked down to the bathhouse, we even walked through a tunnel cave that reminded us of walking through lava tubes.  And, we can't forget about the long stairs down to the beach. =P    

I was pretty excited when we saw starfish attached to the rocks at the beach, but I was 10000x more excited when I saw a pack of dolphins (from very afar).  

I thought getting ourselves to the Golden Gate Bridge would be no problem at all, but not even halfway there and I was already tired out!!  There went my ambition...saved for another day!  I remember taking a mental note about how this place allows us to see the bridge from a different side.  

So, we walked up to China Beach and trekked back on the street.  There, we were able to stop by the House of Legion, though we didn't go inside.  The outside courtyard is nice for pictures though.  

The bathhouse area is kinda gross and smelly, and I had to walk through a very narrow ledge that had my heartbeat skipping right before I made the leap!  Yah...I don't think I'm doing that ever again.  

Oh, we found plenty of parking too in the lot!  This might not be the case when we try again Labor Day weekend, but I like to count my blessings.  :D
author: W W.

description:
Not sure what the difference is between "Land's End Park" and "Land's End Trail" but I'm putting my review here cause I'm talking about the long trail...

When I first moved to San Francisco in 1990 it was obvious Land's End was the bomb. I used to go running or walking on the trail when I lived in several different places in the Richmond district. It's been years since I went back on the trail and WHOAH! It is even more beautiful now! Who'd have thought they could improve such an awesome trail. They put some kind of pavement down at the beginning of the trail - nice to see after twisting my ankle too many times in the last few years so rocky ground makes me a little nervous now. Even though the pavement only goes from the beginning of the trail (cliff house end) and lasts for about 5 minutes of the walk, it really is impressive, as is a few other spots they re-built or improved. In general, they just cleaned it up a bit and made it more "walker friendly" and safer / less prone to landsliding.  They also trimmed a few trees but it still looks awesome. 

I'm not sure what the regulations are for dogs (meaning, whether or not they're supposed to be on leashes). I must confess, when I recently went here with my friend Angela, we brought a pooch she was dog-sitting and let him go off-leash for a while, but that was just because he's extremely friendly. Needless to say, he looooooved it.

This is a great place to bring a date (provided you know the guy... if he's a little questionable, stick with crowded public areas!). The little trail down to the beach also has a few of the best makeout spots in the city.
author: Laura S.

description:
It's all been said so I'll be brief...

Land's End is spectacular. It's gorgeous in the sun, it's stunning in the fog. The air is fresh and the views are insane.

Ocean Beach and Sutro baths are just down yonder if the trails aren't long enough.

Great, great place to go for a weekend run, hike, bring the doggies, the kids, the midget in the trunk...everyone will love it.
author: Faith S.

description:
Awesome views, and great for a little late-night makeout sesh!

You can also do a nice walk along the coast all the way down to Ocean Beach.
author: Misha F.

description:
This place is gorgeous.  There are some areas that look like something right out of a fairy tale.  We even saw some dolphins popping up out of the water the first time we went.  The trail is fairly easy- the only bit that kicks my fat ass is the set of stairs about half way through.  I'm really out of shape, though, so use your own judgment.  

If you go early in the morning the fog will probably be dense enough to hide the Golden Gate Bridge.  We take our dog with us and he loves the trail.  Some people take their dogs and don't keep them leashed but we've yet to encounter any problems with that.  I will definitely take visiting relatives here.
author: Dawn W.

description:
This trail is one of the treasures of San Francisco.
You can start at the end of Geary by the Suttro Baths,
and the trail will take you along the coast.
If you want to find out a bit of the history you 
can take a City Guide Tour and get the 
historical prespective.
Every Saturday at 2pm
www.sfcityguides.org
+ its free
author: Cathie L.

description:
Having been born and raised in San Francisco, how could I not discover Land's End until now?  I don't know.  Maybe Golden Gate Park was just too convenient for me that I didn't explore what other wonderful parks and trails SF has to offer.  

It's a great hike and whether you're with a large group of people or just with your special someone, you'll have a good time.  There's  breathtaking views as you make your way up the hills, concluding with the beautiful ocean sea.  Nature made Land's End.  Before Nature takes it away, I'd recommend a visit.  Soon.  =D
author: Stephen H.

description:
I recently visited a friend in Maui and thought the drive to Hana and the beaches there were amazing.  However, I think we have some pretty incredible views and beaches here in our little town of SF too!

Despite the foggy and cold rainy days, Land's End is a great trail to do for either a nice walk with breath-taking views or a good trail run (but pick a non-weekend day since the trail can be busy).

You can take 48th Street which becomes El Camino Del Mar and make a right and follow it along and it pretty much drops you to the beginning of the trail and the infamous sign you see on posters that say "Land's End."

The trail goes as far out as the new re-furbished Sutro baths near the Cliff House restaurant (by Ocean beach).

You can do a photo tour and get full directions at this link:  http://sanfrancisco.about.com/od/environmentnature/qt/landendtrail.htm
author: Ahnee M.

description:
Very cool trail.

I stumbled onto this trail after passing my old chomping grounds called "The Scary Spot,"

Brought the pup here and it was a nice walk. I like the stairs the most. great cardio running up the stairs with the dog prancing around.

On the next nice day, I will do it again and enjoy the ocean breeze.
author: David L.

description:
5+++ stars if possible! 
LOVED it...simply gorgeous views as you do this walk! 

We started at the Cliffs House and walked to this trail.  We had to cut our walk short because it was getting dark(i forget which trail we ended at but we ended up walking through the gorgeous homes to catch the muni).  I can't believe all these trips to SF and I've never been here...I will for sure be returning next time and plan to spend more time here.
author: Ami S.
